PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Funding of Children's Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of childrens services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 budget. And further, that annual budget allocations in the area of childrens services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mrs Child,Mr Charles Jones,Mrs Kelly,Mr Kent,Mr Leo McLeay,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Mountford and Mr Wallis.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and measures of this country does not have the support of the people.
That the change is causing and will continue to cause, widespread, serious and costly problems;
That the compulsory tactics being used to force the change are a violation of all democratic principles.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed to ensure that the people are free to utilize whichever system they prefer and so enable the return to imperial weights and measures wherever the people so desire;
That weather reporting be as it was prior to the passing of the Metric Conversion Act;
That the Australian Government take urgent steps to cause the traditional mile units to be restored to our highways;
That the Australian Government request the State Governments to procure that the imperial and metric systems be taught together in schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and measures of this country is causing and will cause widespread inconvenience, confusion, expense and distress.
That there is no certainty that any significant benefits or indeed any benefits at all will follow the use of the new weights and measures.
That the traditional weights and measures are eminently satisfactory.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed, and that the Government take urgent steps to cause the traditional and familiar units to be restored to those areas where the greatest inconvenience and distress are occurring, that is to say, in meteorology, in road distances, in sport, in the building and allied trades, in the printing trade, and in retail trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Body
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That because this is the Year of the Child and because occasional child care is the right of every child and because a place which is a safe, stimulating and caring situation is a basic right of a caregiver your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will reconsider any cutbacks whatsoever in children's services and in fact will note the findings of the National Women's Advisory Body's recent survey 'What have you been doing all day' in which it can be found that child care services, above all other services, are requested.

PETITION.TITLE: Determination No. 503 of 1980
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's move in attempting to disallow Determination 503 of 1980 which was granted by the full bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has
(a) placed in jeopardy the future viability of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission,
(b) and has created a dangerous precedent for trade unions in general, by refusing to accept the umpire's decision.

2. That the Government has acted in complicity with the Public Service Board in attempting to disallow Determination 503 of 1980 and is thereby attempting to deny Government employees a fair hearing on matters related to redundancy and retrenchment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will
(a) reject any moves to disallow Determination 503 of 1980 and to exclude arbitral jurisdiction over any aspect of redundancy redeployment, retrenchment and retirement
(b) repeal existing powers to disallow arbitration determinations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that allegations have been made by litigants that unjust decisions in relation to ancillary matters are being made at the Family Court of Australia.

We call on the Government to amend Section 79 (1) of the Family Law Act, to allow all Family Courts to be open and publication of details of proceedings permitted, provided names of parties and other identifying information is prohibited from disclosure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Airlines Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting WA and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefor humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an Airline Policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bungey and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Intractable Waste Disposal Unit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Honourable Petition of the Undersigned employees at Government Aircraft Factory, Avalon Airfield Respectfully Showeth:

Strong opposition to the building of an intractable waste disposal unit in the Geelong District and in particular the Avalon Airfield Area, because the proposed buffer zone includes a working community of 500 employees within 5/8 kilometre of the hangar work areas. Also the failure of the E.P.A. to consult with the employees representatives and the possible failure to debate the feasibility of such a unit within the Parliaments both State and Federal.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will intercede on our behalf to prevent any damage to life or limb-mental or physical.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Jenkins and Mr Scholes.

PETITION.TITLE: Village of Hall, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of the Village of Hall, surrounding districts, and the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

That officers of the National Capital Development Commission gave a commitment to the Village of Hall and District Progress Association committee members at a special meeting in September 1980 that no further development would take place in the Village of Hall until the plan for the future development of Hall had been discussed in detail with the residents of Hall.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Department of the Capital Territory withdraw Block 12, Section 2, Victoria Street, Village of Hall, from the auction sale set for February 12 until such time as the residents of Hall have had sufficient time to study in detail and make comments about the National Capital Development Commission's plan for the future development of the Village of Hall.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is the Government examining the full implications of the activities of the Nugan Hand Bank? Is it aware that the bank was largely staffed and assisted by former members of the United States of America intelligence and military services? Is the Prime Minister aware of allegations that this Australian-based bank was laundering funds for Central Intelligence Agency operations in the region? Can he assure the House that the bank and its associates were not co-operating with security services of any foreign power to interfere in Australia's domestic affairs?

—I have had some communication with New South Wales in relation to this matter. It has not come before me for a little while, but I will see what information I can get for the Leader of the Opposition. As to the other part of the matter, the honourable gentleman knows quite well the standing rules in relation to security matters of that kind. I think he would know quite well also that any operations of the United States would be declared to the Australian Government and consequently agreed to by the Australian Government. I have been given no information of any breach. That is a rule that has applied to successive governments, not just to one government. I have not been advised of any breach of that rule at any time. If I can give any additional information to the honourable gentleman, I certainly will make it available to him. He knows also that on these matters a full security briefing is available to the Leader of the Opposition for the asking.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Dr Edwards having addressed a question to the Treasurer-
Mr Jacobi-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask you to address your attention to question No. 414 appearing on the Notice Paper in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of eyewitness accounts of the National Guard in El Salvador shooting unarmed demonstrators in the back with arms supplied by the United States of America? In view of the current visit to the United States of America by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, will the Prime Minister assure the Parliament that this Government will take no action to condone, endorse or encourage in any way the growing United States involvement in the civil war in El Salvador where American arms are being used by the military dictatorship in a most brutal manner to crush the aspirations of a grossly deprived and repressed population? Will the Government take steps to ensure that it obtains objective advice on the true situation in El Salvador and does not rely on an American interpretation of the events as we did, to our sorrow, in Vietnam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has asked an interesting question. He seems to have come to conclusions in relation to events in El Salvador which, at the very best, could be described only as depicting a part of a story and not necessarily an entirely accurate one. The honourable gentleman needs to understand also, as I am advised, that there is clear evidence that Cuba and communist countries have been running arms to El Salvador.
—What about Trudeau?
—The honourable gentleman might wish to support the view that communist powers can run arms into a country and create revolution. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects: 'Why shouldn't they'?
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I said no such thing. I said: 'What about Mr Trudeau's statement'? Why are we so misrepresented by this man?
—He is a professional liar.

—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I point out to the House that if interjections continue for the purpose of putting a Minister off his answer, it is to be expected that the Minister may, in fact, misinterpret some of the interjections.
—He tells lies. He is a professional liar.
—If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ceased interjecting there would be no possibility of his being misrepresented. The honourable member for Corio will withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.

—On a further point of order, interjections at times can seek further information. My interjection was: 'What about Mr Trudeau?' It had nothing to do with the accusation falsely made by the Prime Minister.
—The honourable gentleman has made clear the nature of his interjection. I ask him to resume his seat and to cease interjecting.
—The only thing I want to make clear is the--
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. He has made his point of order.
—You want to hear me further, Mr Speaker, because this has to be fair. This goes on record as to what the Prime Minister said. It was a deliberate misrepresentation.
—The honourable gentleman is--
—His hearing is not that deficient.
—The honourable gentleman has made his point of order clear. I ask him to resume his seat.
—I want to make this point: We are looking for protection from the Chair and we are not getting it.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made an unwarranted attack on me a week ago. I said nothing about it.
—I made no unwarranted attack on you.
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—I will not. If you continue to attack me from the chair--
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—I am not going to take it.
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—I made no unwarranted attack. You deliberately deceived me and you knew it.
—The honourable gentleman should maintain his calm. The honourable gentleman made an attack on me last week. I said nothing about it.
—That is right.
—Today I have said something about it. I have drawn attention to it because he has made a further attack.
—I have not.

—I point out to the honourable gentleman that, if he sits silently and does not interject, he will be complying with the Standing Orders of the Parliament. I call the Prime Minister to continue his answer.
—Are you going to withdraw your lies?

—The Prime Minister will resume his seat. I have already called upon the honourable member for Corio to withdraw an allegation of lies. He withdrew unqualifiedly. He has now repeated it. I should have thought that it would have been obvious that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made it clear that what the Prime Minister said was the interjection was not the interjection of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. That has now been satisfied and cleared up. It does not help the situation if the honourable member for Corio uses such words as 'lie'. I ask the honourable member for Corio to restrain himself.
—Mr Speaker--
—He should withdraw.
—The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat.

—I take a point of order. There is a very simple solution to this problem which I suspect will go on. It is a reflection of deficiencies in the Standing Orders and a need for some reform which I have mentioned to you and to the Prime Minister, who has expressed some interest-some only. There is a simple solution at this point, and that is for the Prime Minister rather manfully to apologise for what happened and let the matter go.
—Well, if he is not prepared to apologise, people will feel aggrieved, which I think would be thoroughly understandable in the circumstances.

—The right honourable gentleman referred to an interjection which he obviously, from the statement made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, misunderstood. It has been made clear. There is no need for an apology. But, on the other hand, a withdrawal by the right honourable gentleman would probably clear the matter up and allow us to go on with the proceedings of the House. I ask the right honourable gentleman to withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, I am very happy to accept fully what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said. But I think it is also fair enough to make the point--
—Order! I ask the right honourable gentleman to withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, I said that I accept what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said.
—I ask the right honourable gentleman to withdraw.
—Yes, I do withdraw, Mr Speaker.
—I ask honourable members on the Opposition benches to remain silent while the answer is continued.

—I also make the point that the Opposition will be open to gross misinterpretation if it continues to behave as it has this morning. If one person interjected at a time, at least that one interjection could be heard clearly at a time. But when the whole front bench is competing at one time for the Leader of the Opposition's job it is difficult to hear.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked a question about a serious matter indeed. I hope that all members of this House will try to look at the issues in El Salvador without prejudice and with a clear mind as to what is happening. Whatever one might say of the government of El Salvador-many people have views as to that and they are not necessarily particularly pleased with the nature of the government-I think it is also possible to have views, and important to have views, about the gun running to rebels inside El Salvador from Cuba or from communist sources which is deliberately designed to foment revolution of a very serious kind. I think it is also fair enough, whatever one might say about governments of the right with extreme views, to take the same kind of view of governments of the extreme left because there never has been any freedom in any communist country anywhere. I would have hoped that the honourable gentleman, in asking his question, would have a more balanced approach to it and would have paid recognition to the extreme danger to the South American continent of Cuba or other communist countries running guns into areas of difficulty or concern. Quite plainly, I believe that the United States is entirely right in seeking to cut off that source of disturbance, that source of revolution, from the South American continent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware of the problems being experienced by Telecom Australia in the Gold Coast area of Queensland, caused mainly by lack of equipment and lack of trained staff? Will the Minister ensure that Telecom carries out an urgent review of its priorities to ensure that considerable but predictable growth on the Gold Coast is not curtailed and business is not being continually disadvantaged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member on his introduction to this place. I know that his predecessor was as concerned as the honourable member about the availability of telecommunication services in the Gold Coast area. It has been a problem in recent times. I am told that the planning projections for the Gold Coast have been rising at an astronomic rate. The original projection for 1980-81 showed a 22.7 per cent increase on the 1979-80 figures. Indications are that the actual demand will be even greater than that. As a result there has been some delay in the provision of equipment for exchange capacity, junction and trunk circuits, and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also true that there has been some shortage of skilled tradesmen in both the lines and the technical fields. However, an additional 33 lines staff and 13 technical staff have been engaged this financial year. Whilst they will help to fill that training gap, unfortunately they are at the moment still relatively unskilled and they will require further training. I can assure the honourable gentleman that there is a very significant fund allocation for his area this year. Gross capital expenditure of $11.3m is designed to try to provide a range of equipment that will be used largely in that part of Queensland. There is a significant backlog, however, in the provision of services. I can assure the honourable gentleman that if it is within the control of Telecom Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister is reading his answer to the question without notice. Mr Speaker, would you please ask the Minister to table the paper from which he has been reading.
—Is the right honourable gentleman reading from a paper?
—No, I am not, Mr Speaker.
—The Minister may continue his answer.

—I was trying to give some figures that were in the paper because I am sure that honourable members on this side of the House are interested in the way in which an organisation which is being run on behalf of the Australian people is meeting the problems of the members of this place. I can assure the honourable member for McPherson that the problems that he faces because of the rapid growth in his area are recognised by Telecom. I will ensure that his question and his concern are brought to the attention of Telecom.

—Can the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs inform the House of the current state of the evaluation of SAMIN-the Statistical and Management Information Network-in terms of the experience of the operation of SAMIN in Brisbane to which he referred in his answer to the question from the honourable member for Lilley on Tuesday of this week about the extension of SAMIN beyond Brisbane?
—The evaluation is ongoing. I am not aware of a precise completion date for it. I will make inquiries of my Department and provide the honourable gentleman with an answer.

—Does the Minister for Transport know when he will announce the next increase in domestic air fares? Will any such increase be uniform or will fares for short haul routes such as those to and from Tasmania again incur a greater percentage increase than longer routes? If that is likely, will the Minister again consider the consequences for the island State and the views of members before any announcement is made?

—I have received from both airlines applications for an 8.5 per cent increase in air fares. My Department has examined their applications thoroughly and claims that an average increase of 7.9 per cent is justified. The Government has decided to defer consideration of the applications until it has had the opportunity to examine thoroughly the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. As soon as the Government has given consideration to that report and has adopted a policy position in relation to it, I will deal with the air fare increase applications. Tasmania's problem is identified by the honourable gentleman and in the course of our consideration of the recommendations of the Holcroft inquiry report we will certainly take the Tasmanian situation into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to reports, one of which was published in today's Melbourne Age, of a television interview with President Reagan in which the President appeared to suggest a change in policy towards South Africa? He is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Can we abandon a country that has stood beside us in every war we've fought, a country that is strategically essential to the free world? It has a production of minerals we all must have?

Does the Prime Minister believe, as the President seems to imply there and elsewhere in the interview, that the value of minerals in South Africa and its strategic location ought to be weighed in the balance with our criticism of South Africa on human rights grounds. If so, will he permit an opportunity to debate this matter in the House? If not, will he convey to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, while he is in Washington, the need to reiterate to the Americans the strong stand the Prime Minister's Government and the Whitlam Government have made on this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —The policy of the Australian Government on this issue is very clear. The honourable gentleman quoted parts of the report of President Reagan's speech-I emphasise a report of the speech-but failed to mention the part of the speech in which the President went out of his way to say that we ought to encourage those who are seeking to break down apartheid, or words quite directly to that effect. I think that everything the President said needs to be judged very much in that context. I hope that the honourable gentleman will agree with that objective.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware that there have been difficulties in the installation and operation of under-50-line PABX units as a result of a ban imposed by the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association? What is the present position regarding the ban and the Government's attitude towards it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that some 64 units in New South Wales, 57 in Queensland and some in other States have been affected by the ban to which the honourable gentleman referred. The ban was imposed late last year as a result of concern apparently felt by members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association that the intention of the Government was that this inter-connect market, as they called it- that is all those things that plug into the main network system operated by Telecom-was to be taken away from the control and function of Telecom.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's concern has been, firstly, to try to make sure that adequate funds are available within Telecom for the main network system. A moment ago the honourable member for McPherson canvassed the problems he has in one area, in part because of the inadequacy of basic equipment. There is no doubt that Telecom has a tremendous financial requirement to meet its prime obligation. The Government is concerned that, as far as possible, we should keep up to date with the technological advancements in the inter-connect market. We believe that there is a range of areas in which private enterprise can well assist Telecom in providing facilities to consumers and also helping to ensure an adequacy of funds within Telecom to meet its prime task.

I have had some discussions with the executive of the ATEA and I understand that a recommendation has gone forward to the union that the ban be lifted. I have not yet been advised whether the union has met and the ban has been lifted, but I understand that the recommendation has been made by the executive for it to do so. I commend the members of the executive for that recommendation. I believe it is very much in the interests of Telecom that, to the maximum, we allow it to get on with its prime task of providing telephonic communications to the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the Government's decision not to apply any crude oil levy to the Fortescue oil field in Bass Strait. Is the Prime Minister aware that by this decision the Government has forgone potential net tax revenue of approximately $3,500m at current oil prices over the ten years from mid-1982 during which the field will be in production? Is he also aware that with inevitable further increases in oil prices the total tax loss will be considerably more than $3.5 billion? As this extraordinary amount of potential tax revenue by this decision will accrue instead to Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd and the wholly foreign-owned Esso corporation, how does the Prime Minister equate this unparalleled handout to big business with his promise to ensure that all Australians will benefit from resource development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position regarding the application of the oil levy to old and new oil has been stated frequently in the past. The decision taken last year regarding the status of the field mentioned by the honourable gentleman in his question was based upon a proper evaluation of the oil coming from that field. The decision was made in accordance with principles which, I think, are accepted by a wide number of people in the resources area as being correct in applying a policy which discriminates between new and old oil. I think the honourable gentleman will be aware that there is a degree of support on his side of the House for the principles that are applied in discriminating between what is categorised as new and old oil.

ANSWER.PARA: I have chosen my words very carefully to point out to the honourable gentleman that in no way was the decision to classify the Fortescue field as being one that produces new oil arrived at other than by applying proper and, I think, widely supported principles based upon the advice available to the Government at the time.

Estimates of revenue loss or revenue that might come from a particular source if a certain form of taxation were applied depend very much upon estimates of output and a whole range of variable factors including, in particular, whether alternative taxation sources were to be available. The Government's position on the application of the levy has been made clear, and I have nothing to add to earlier statements that have been made on it. If I believe that any further information can be usefully supplied to the House I will provide it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and refer to reports that he has reached agreement with State governments on the approach to be adopted to major development projects and on the discussions with major project developers. Will the Minister inform me of the results of those discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that, following the statement which I put down in this House on 4 December last year, I have reached agreement with a number of States concerning manpower policy with respect to meeting the requirements of major resource developments throughout the 1980s. I am pleased to be able to inform the honourable member that about a fortnight ago, after very good and helpful discussions, I reached agreement with the South Australian Government. On this subject, I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the points of agreement that were reached with the South Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SOUTH AUSTRALIA MAJOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS POINTS OF AGREEMENT

The South Australian Government endorses the Commonwealth policy as outlined in the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs' 4 December 1980 statement to the House of Representatives. The main elements of the policy are:
an early assessment of manpower requirements by the project developer;
a substantial training effort on the part of the project developer and associated contractors;
given a substantial training effort, assistance from Commonwealth and State manpower programs where continued critical shortages are likely to impede project progress.
Manpower assessments should take place as part of the project planning process and be made available to State and Commonwealth authorities at an early point in that process.
The State and the Commonwealth will establish co-operative machinery:
to provide a formal point for liaison with major developers on manpower assessments;
to report on the assessments and the degree of training effort proposed by the company;
to identify critical industry wide shortages and the establishment of training programs where continuing shortage will impede project progress:

to determine the part to be played by immigration where skills are not available and where the Commonwealth and State are agreed that the timing of project schedules is insufficient to train domestically.
The Commonwealth and the State are agreed that the priority should always remain the training of Australians.
A joint Commonwealth/State Manpower Committee will be mechanism for Commonwealth and State co-operation.

The South Australian Government will examine whether a requirement to train would be part of the agreement between the State and project developers on the same basis as the State requires developers to make a contribution to housing, roads and ports.
The Commonwealth and State will be taking a similar approach with regard to their own major development projects.
The South Australian Government and Commonwealth will establish contact points for all liaison on major projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I also seek leave to table the points of agreement reached with New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia.
—The documents can be tabled without leave.

—Today I will be travelling to Tasmania for discussions with the Premier and other Ministers and I anticipate that I will be able to reach the same kind of agreement with that State. I am very pleased to be able to say that in all my discussions with the State governments-with either Premiers or the appropriate Ministers-it has been recognised that Australia has an obligation to its people to provide increased training opportunities to enable them to meet the needs of these major resource developments which will flow through almost all regions of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the things about which we are concerned is that there is not poaching from one industry to another or across State borders. Therefore, as we all see it, our obligation is to lift the overall level of trade training in Australia. While visiting these States I also had discussions with industry organisations and with some of the major developers. Again, I was very pleased with the response of all involved, not only to the need to increase the overall level of trade training in Australia but also to the need to introduce innovative practices into the trade training system. Some developers, on their own initiative and in co-operation with the appropriate State authorities, are making marked progress in this regard. Also, within the next fortnight I will be travelling to the Northern Territory for similar discussions and expect agreement to be reached there also.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I remind the Minister of his oft-stated commitment to work experience schemes for school leavers. Does the Minister agree that the Commonwealth Government should be seen to be a leader in providing this work experience opportunity? If so, why have Commonwealth Government departments been unable to participate in such schemes for at least eight months, thereby denying many hundreds of kids the opportunity for work experience in those departments? This being so, what steps are being undertaken to correct this unacceptable state of affairs?

—Great progress has been made in opening up in private industry opportunities for work experience for young people, particularly those who by force of circumstance have been unemployed for four months or longer, or for eight months or longer. Unless something were done, young people up to the age of 25 years could well become locked into a situation which could be very damaging to them personally. The commitment to the youth program, of special transitional allowances and special youth employment training projects, which came into place on 1 February, has meant literally a flooding of new activity into Commonwealth Employment Service offices all around Australia. I realise, and the Government recognises, that it is not enough simply to ask private enterprise to open its doors and provide these work experience opportunities for young people. Therefore, with the co-operation of the Public Service Board and of all departments of government, we have opened and we will be opening the doors of the Australian Public Service to students.
—When?
—As from the commencement of the academic year 1981. We will be playing our part in providing work experience opportunities in Commonwealth establishments to the young people of Australia.
—Has the Prime Minister seen reports suggesting that armed forces be sent into El Salvador in response to the communist arms buildup in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one leading foreign affairs expert in Australia who, from the point of view of the Australian Labor Party, has had some remarkable things to say about this. I would like to read his words. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest that the proper course for any of us who are interested in securing some sort of democracy and any sort of justice in Latin America would be to encourage the present government in El Salvador . . .
He went on:
We should certainly not support the overthrow of that regime and replace it with a regime of the Cuban variety. That is what the alternative really has come to.
He was then asked:
Should we encourage President Reagan to give it military aid?
He replied that were he asked:

. . . I would not discourage President Reagan from giving military aid. I will be quite frank. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will recall that a decision has been made by the members of the Commonwealth to set aside the second Monday in March each year as a day on which the purpose and achievements of the Commonwealth would be duly marked. As this is the last sitting day before this year's Commonwealth Day I would like to take this opportunity to make a brief statement to that end. This year's Commonwealth Day is especially noteworthy for Australia in two respects. First, it marks the fiftieth anniversary of the Statute of Westminster an Act of the British Parliament which gave birth to the Commonwealth. Secondly, this year Australia will host the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting for the first time.

SPEECH.PARA: To an exceptional extent the history of the Commonwealth has been one of gradual evolution, marked by continuity and subtle modifications rather than abrupt change. But if there is one event which constitutes a decisive step in that evolution, it is surely the passing of the Statute of Westminster in 1931. That event marked the decisive transition from Empire to Commonwealth. By establishing the principles of autonomy, equality and free association among members, it created the conditions for the Commonwealth to grow, diversify and establish a distinctive role in an era of far reaching changes. Thus as decolonisation proceeded with great rapidity, most of the newly independent countries found it natural and advantageous to become members of it.

A leading Australian authority on the Commonwealth, Professor Bruce Miller, has referred to the Statute as 'a masterpiece of ambiguity', and no doubt in legal and constitutional terms it was that. But politically it pointed clearly in one direction. The time when discussion of the Commonwealth tended to be clouded by rather dubious metaphysics and the search for the definition of an essence is long since past. The contemporary Commonwealth is confident enough to take itself for granted, to define itself in terms of what it does. Its form is flexible and accommodating; its bent is pragmatic and problem solving, its atmosphere is informal and unpolemical.

No one who is aware of the recent record of the Commonwealth would be foolish enough to characterise it as a 'talking shop' or an anachronism. At the two Heads of Government meetings I have attended we have agreed on an effective declaration against apartheid; we have made a substantial contribution to progress on a common fund for commodities; we have initiated an inquiry into factors inhibiting economic growth and structural change; and we have made a major contribution to the solution of conflict in Zimbabwe. We have shown a capacity to make progress on problems which major powers and global groupings have found intractable. Organisationally, we have initiated regional Commonwealth meetings of Asian and Pacific members.

At the time the Statute of Westminster was passed the Commonwealth had six members. At this year's conference in Melbourne over 40 Heads of Government are expected to attend and it will be the most important international conference ever held in Australia. The agenda will cover a wide range of issues, but I anticipate that NorthSouth issues-that is, issues concerning relations between developed and developing countries-will be of prime importance. These issues are of vital importance for the future peace, stability and prosperity of the world. Yet at present it is proving difficult to have them addressed with the urgency and commitment which their seriousness demands. In these circumstances, the Melbourne Commonwealth meeting assumes a special significance. The composition of the meeting ensures that North-South questions will be seriously addressed there, in practical and constructive terms. I hope, therefore, that in September we shall seize the opportunity to contribute towards the removing of some of the roadblocks to a progress on these issues and help generate a momentum which will carry over to other forums.

Mr Speaker, the Commonwealth is important to Australia as a link with our past. But it is even more important as an instrument which we, along with others, can use to help shape the future, to strengthen the forces of moderation, co-operation and good sense in a world which badly needs more of them.
I present the following paper:
Commonwealth Day-Ministerial Statement, 5 March 1981.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Commonwealth Day was instituted at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Jamaica in 1975. Since that time, the Parliament has noted its passing in various ways. Only once, in 1978, has it been the subject of a full debate. On that occasion the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) expounded at great length on his own achievements at the first Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting held in Sydney. On this occasion, he has taken the opportunity to begin the massive promotion of the full Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to be held in Melbourne later this year. On that occasion in 1978, I said that it was an anachronistic institution, a talk-shop of dubious value to Australia. On this occasion I remain firmly of that view. Indeed, everything that has happened in the intervening years has reinforced what I said then.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, for the Prime Minister the Commonwealth provides a handy forum in which he can strut as an international statesman. It is made up of countries sufficiently large and numerous to give it an air of importance, but few of which are big enough to prevent him grabbing for the limelight. We can be sure that, with the conference in Australia, the Prime Minister will spare no effort to galvanise the increasingly grotesque multi-million dollar propaganda machine he has built up to polish his cult of personality. It is a big and expensive propaganda machine-but then it has a big and difficult task. We can expect to hear much more of this over the coming months. This curious buildup of the Commonwealth is also a diversion from the deep-rooted problems at home, a cover-up of the sell-out of Australia's resources which will gather pace this year, and the social, economic and political problems that will flow in the course of a desirable but inexpertly controlled development.

Since I last spoke in detail on the Commonwealth I acknowledge that it has achieved one notable success. It provided the institutional framework within which the settlement on Zimbabwe was negotiated. The rebellion in Rhodesia had dragged on for more than 10 years but, as time went by, the position of the Smith Government became untenable. The murderous war between the black guerrilla forces and the technically superior Rhodesian army meant much damage in lives lost, property destroyed and social stability shattered, that negotiations were inevitable. The Lusaka summit of the Commonwealth provided the forum. There is a quaint irony in the Prime Minister, an unregenerate apostle of cold war politics, acting as the mid-wife for the new nation state of a self-confessed marxist, Robert Mugabe. I have never hesitated to compliment the Prime Minister for his role in this matter and I do so again.

The Opposition recognises that on questions of apartheid the Prime Minister, whilst totally silent in 1971 at the time of the disruptive Springbok visit to Australia, has more recently sought to atone for his omissions then by expressing suitable objections to that policy. However, strictures bandied abroad do little to help our black Australians who are the victims of racist policies in Queensland and West Australia. Their welfare is neglected as a result of a cumulative real reduction of $307m by his Government over five years. Posturing about overseas neglect, intolerance, repression and so on is fine. The Prime Minister's indifference to his moral obligations to our black Australians is outrageous. The unkind would feel justified in claiming that when there is a cost or a tough act for him at home he surrenders the costless moral passion he spreads abroad. I fear, however, that this very success of the Commonwealth over Zimbabwe may have finally robbed it of any substantial raison d'etre.

Sir Winston Churchill said, when Prime Minister during the early 1950s, that he had not become Prime Minister to preside over the dissolution of the British Empire. He was partly right. It has been the Commonwealth which has presided over the end of British rule in its last substantial colony-Zimbabwe. With hindsight it is now possible to see that the real function of the Commonwealth in the post-war era has been to provide one of the forums in which the withdrawal of Britain from its imperial role, especially in Africa, could be effected. The Commonwealth has been valuable for this purpose if for nothing else. Now that it has completed its major task, however, it is hard to see that the Commonwealth is any longer an institution to which we should ascribe much importance.

A political institution cannot be assessed separely from its roots: Whilst one can admire the resilience with which the British Empire merged in the British Commonwealth, and subsequently into the Commonwealth, its history has not changed. For the sole common link between the members of the Commonwealth is that they are all former British colonies. I do not for a moment deny that many of those colonies have received some benefits from this. Aspects of British culture-a genuine liberalism of a kind unknown to the proponents of Fraserism and a model of democratic representative government; all these and many other things-are inheritances well worth having. But is this enough to warrant designating the Commonwealth as a major focus of our diplomacy? Is the fact that heads of government of diverse ex-colonies can talk to each other in a common tongue sufficient to warrant the great emphasis placed on the Commonwealth by the Government? To me the answer is clearly no.

Developments within the various member states and a new generation of leaders mean that the nostalgia which can often unite those who have been bitter enemies in the past is no longer present. This is a new age, a new generation and a vastly different and more complex world than that of yesteryear when as schoolchildren we had to intone indoctrinating doggerel about the eternity of an empire already crumbling. We have been on our own for some time now-even though this Government seems reluctant to accept the fact. We are a sovereign nation despite the residual trappings of our colonial past. For the Australian Labor Party a truly independent foreign policy is a fundamental belief. Australia and Australians can achieve anything on their own. Whilst we have drawn much from our past, we feel no nostalgia for it, no hankering after past certainties and past securities. The Commonwealth has been an important part of our past: it has little relevance to our future. The Labor Party believes that a hard-headed assessment of our interests requires that we concentrate our efforts on our regional relationships. That is a much more difficult task, of course.

We lack a long history of close connections with countries such as Indonesia and Thailand; we do not have the same mutual understanding of a particular kind of political institution inherited from a common source; we have serious differences with some of our neighbours about their policies on human rights. But irrefutably and inescapably Australia's destiny is here in this region in which we live, and our destiny is enmeshed, not just with some of our regional neighbours who happen to be former British colonies. It is inextrictably locked in with all of them. That for me is the compelling reality and for a regional grouping-like the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting-to function without important regional nation states like Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and some of the island states of the South West Pacific, is an extraordinary deficiency and liability.

The Prime Minister has said many times that we must look at the world as it is, not as we would like it to be. Whilst he might want to believe in the comfortable good fellowship of a Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting, that is not the reality. Reality for Australia is the hard slog of building an independent self-reliant role for itself in the world and, above all, in our own region. We do not really mind very much about our membership of the Commonwealth. If it is seen as an occasional talking shop and perhaps as an administrator of some minor aid and research program it should not do too much harm. But as an international institution of major importance to Australia its day is done. Our duty is to look to the future-to an Australia confident in its ability to find its own way, prepared to learn from its mistakes, eager to build a new identity which it can truly call its own, and determined to stand on its own feet with a proper sense of national pride and aspiration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) concerning Commonwealth Day. As we have just heard from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), the Australian Labor Party sees the Commonwealth as an anachronism. Of course, that is especially so among those in the Labor Party who advocate the republican cause. That is why the Leader of the Opposition attempted today to diminish the significance of the Commonwealth of Nations and, therefore, Commonwealth Day.
—He is selling out to the Left.

—He is trying to retain the support of the Left to maintain his position of leader. The Leader of the Opposition has shown by his remarks how he is completely out of touch with reality and how he misunderstands the nature and role of the Commonwealth of Nations. We should be thankful that he will never have an opportunity to formulate Australia's foreign policy as he will never be in a position to do so. His churlish comments reveal that he is mean and envious because Australia's standing in the Commonwealth of Nations has never been higher than it is under the leadership of the present Prime Minister. Other members of the Commonwealth recognise Australia's contribution. That is why they are pleased to have Australia host the next Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It will be the first time in our history that we have hosted such a meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that the second Monday in March each year should be set aside for recognition of the Commonwealth of Nations. As the Prime Minister indicated in his remarks, Commonwealth Day this year celebrates the fiftieth anniversary of the enactment of the Statute of Westminster. That was an important event in the three fold transition from the British Empire to the British Commonwealth and through to today's Commonwealth of Nations. Progressive decolonisation has been an important aspect of this. It should be recognised that by and large British decolonisation was better handled than that of other imperial powers. This has made a major contribution towards the continuing relevance and success of the Commonwealth of Nations.

Contrary to the arguments we have heard from the Leader of the Opposition, the Commonwealth of Nations is relevant because it gives each member country an equal right to share and participate in its discussions. It enhances the role of the Commonwealth and the understanding between the peoples of the countries who belong to it. It allows the gradual development of new links within the Commonwealth as well as the preservation of traditional links. Of course it is those traditional links which the Leader of the Opposition seeks to diminish and destroy. Over the years the Commonwealth has demonstrated its capacity as a forum to discuss international issues of common concern to its members. The Commonwealth has direct relevance and significance for Australia in that it provides a vital link between the old and the new world, the developed and the developing world and the rich and not so rich world. It is therefore appropriate that this year Australia will host the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting for the first time. That meeting will undoubtedly further enhance the role of the Commonwealth.

An important aspect of the Commonwealth of Nations is the work of the Commonwealth Secretariat and its associated programs. Examples of those programs are the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation and the Commonwealth Youth Program, in which I have had particular interest. In the current financial year Australia has provided $644,000 towards the expenses of the Commonwealth Secretariat. This figure represents 9 per cent of the total cost of running that body. Australia has also provided $1.8m for the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation. This year the Australian Government has provided $131,000 for the Commonwealth Youth Program, compared with $120,000 last financial year. However, compared with our having met about 9 per cent of the costs of the Commonwealth Secretariat, that amount represents only about 7 per cent of the total cost of the Commonwealth Youth Program.

The Commonwealth Youth Program, apart from conducting various training programs, in recent years has conducted three conferences of significance. In May 1977 the first Meeting of Young Commonwealth Leaders was held in Ocho Rios in Jamaica and was attended by the former member for McMillan, Mr Barry Simon. In May 1979 the second Meeting of Young Commonwealth Leaders was held in Colombo, Sri Lanka, at which the Australian Government was represented by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). In March 1979 the Commonwealth Countries Conference on Government Policy on Youth Affairs was held in Chandigarh, India, at which I had the privilege of leading the Australian delegation. Each of these meetings has played an important role in the continuing emphasis of the Commonwealth Youth Program on preparing young people in Commonwealth countries for participation in national decision-making and on enhancing the role of young leaders within the Commonwealth.

The meetings have also made a worthwhile contribution to the development of policies relating to youth within member countries. They have therefore provided unique opportunities for young people of related nations to meet, discuss and decide together on matters of mutual concern to them and their countries. Such exchanges not only benefit those who participate in them but also advance the cause of peace and goodwill between members of the Commonwealth of Nations. The third Meeting of Young Commonwealth Leaders was scheduled to be held in Lusaka, Zambia, in May this year. In view of the value that has been derived from those previous meetings, I was concerned to learn recently that this conference had been cancelled by the Commonwealth Secretariat because of lack of funds. I think it is a serious matter when lack of funds causes the cancellation of such worthwhile events as these conferences have proved to be.

Undoubtedly, the Commonwealth Youth Program has experienced difficulties in the past with regard to mismanagement of programs and, to some degree, finances. However, under its new director, Peter Brooks, I believe these problems are being redressed. By way of example, I understand the administrative staff of the Commonwealth Youth Program has been reduced recently from 14 to six members. Its operation has been tightened up to make it a more effective and efficient unit. I therefore urge the present Government to increase its commitment to the Commonwealth Youth Program, at least to the extent that we contribute 9 per cent of the total budget of that program, as we do for the Commonwealth Secretariat. This may then allow to continue worthwhile events such as the conferences to which I have referred as well as the other significant programs which the Commonwealth Youth Program administers. The Commonwealth of Nations is made up largely of young countries whose populations contain a high proportion of young people. Therefore, I believe that it is important that there be continued opportunities for dialogue between the young people of the member countries of the Commonwealth of Nations. In conclusion, once again I urge the present Federal Government to increase its commitment to the Commonwealth Youth Program to enable its very worthwhile programs to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I was interested in the comment of the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) when he suggested that there was a republican flavour about my leader's speech. That is true. Let me place on record that the majority of member countries of the Commonwealth are republics. I cannot understand why the honourable gentleman felt that that was a problem. The other matter which interested me from a legal point of view was the reference in the speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the Statute of Westminster. It is worthy of note that we do not have to look to the Statute of Westminster for the reason we moved from the status of colony to that of independence. If it were the reason, and the British Parliament were to repeal the Statute of Westminster, which was passed in 1931, we would be placed in the ridiculous situation of having our status returned to that of colony. That will never happen. It is important for us to develop an independent national image embracing the aspirations of our people. We would not accept the view that the British Parliament had power even to amend the Australian Constitution, much as it needs amending.

SPEECH.PARA: We make the point that too much emphasis should not be put on the Statute of Westminster. A problem is already developing in Canada on this subject. A wrangle is going on between the provincial governments and the Federal Government of Canada. The remarkable view is taken by the provinces of Canada that the Statute of Westminster is an international multilateral agreement which can be amended only with the consent of all who are party to it or affected by it, including Australia. I do not see that applying in practical terms, but it shows the extraordinary positions which can develop when emphasis is put on statutes that have long since lost their relevance.

We have to realise that nations are progressing and aspiring to independence. We are not the least of them. It is quite clear that this is a very difficult Statute even to refer to. Nobody really knows what it means. It relates to the political development that took place in Australia, as a nation fighting wars in a particular region and a nation that has long since cut the apron strings of the mother country. If we are to have a standing tribute to that development at the bicentenary in 1988 I suggest to the Government that the best birthday present we could give our nation would be a new constitution which left Australia's nationhood and sovereignty in no doubt. For over 120 years we have been deemed to be a collection of separate colonies. Conservative leaders and State Premiers who want to return to some sort of colonial status are certainly fragmenting and trying to destroy the Federation.

Labor governments have always emphasised Australian content. It was a Labor Government that first appointed an Australian Governor-General-an admirable appointment. During the crisis of the Second World War John Curtin made it very clear that we had to turn our sights to the Americans as our allies, as they still are, to help us in that war against the Japanese. The records show that the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom did not place such a high priority on the Pacific area during the war as we did. That is understandable because he was in another theatre of war. But can honourable members imagine the Australian people accepting the proposition that they could be saved at a later date when they were threatened with being overrun by an enemy? I doubt it very much. I repeat that we should not put too much emphasis on the Statute of Westminster. It did not stop a constitutional coup in Australia.

I refer now to the rhetoric and policy, particularly of the Prime Minister, in the North-South dialogue. His behaviour is very much that of the big fish in the little pond. The establishment of a forum or a talking shop to discuss matters is not to be encouraged. But let us consider the posturing that is taking place in the North-South talks as against the progress that has been made. I submit that no progress has been made despite the many meetings that have been held. This is not only my opinion. It is also the opinion of the most influential leader in Africa, the President of Nigeria, where I understand, the Prime Minister will pay a visit shortly. President Shagari said:

Nigeria wants to see a new international economic order that would enable the developing countries to regain complete sovereignty over their natural resources, acquire appropriate technology, have easy access to capital funds and achieve an equitable distribution of the world resources. We would also like to see positive actions to back up the numerous pronouncements of the new international economic order so that the present ambivalent attitude of the developed nations is replaced by a genuine gesture of co-operation and understanding.

At meetings of heads of governments anywhere in the world it is normal to expect to deal with the haves and the have-nots. The poorer countries are calling for the reform of international financial institutions, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, to make them more responsive to the desperate plight of those countries. This requires Australia to put its money where its mouth appears to be. When we were asked to do this recently by supporting the establishment of a food import finance facility, we not only did not support it but also we opposed it. We should not just adopt the posture, we should also support the solutions.

Whilst there is an advantage in heads of government talking together, let us note that many have little influence in our region. We have to get our governments and Ministers to concentrate on the problems of our region. Unless that is done we will face grave and serious consequences. Our responsibilities require regional initiatives to be taken in respect of Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia and Kampuchea and in the challenging Pacific Island states. We cannot go back to the old empire days and the old imperial institutions. They are no answer to the problems of the modern world. However, there is some value in the old institutions which came from the people and not from the rulers. I refer to the Magna Carta and all it stood for, the parliamentary system and what it means and the value in having Prime Ministers rather than Presidents. Prime Ministers are subject to parliamentary control so this shows clearly that there is more value in a Prime Minister. There is value in the parliamentary institution and I give it that credit. The great contribution of the British people to the world was a thing called democracy. It is wrong for Prime Ministers either in Australia or elsewhere to promote other regimes which are always afraid of the ballot box and will never use it. They are afraid of parliaments and never want to see them. They are afraid of the wishes of elected representatives who may remove a Prime Minister and put another in his place. Democracies are of no danger to the world but other regimes are.

I now turn to the question of an effective declaration against apartheid. Again, that is commendable. Heads of government of the Commonwealth are always talking about the problems or weaknesses of countries not adhering to the principles of human rights as happens in a number of former Commonwealth countries. Last weekend Mr Moi, the leader of one of the Commonwealth countries, Kenya, appealed to fellow leaders for continued strong opposition to apartheid. Our Prime Minister is on record as saying that we are also opposed to apartheid. The words are commendable but the deeds are not there. Our trade with South Africa has doubled in the last three years. It has been suggested that at least tacit approval has been given for a trade delegation from Western Australia to visit South Africa. That delegation had a chance to visit the Prime Minister before it went. I hope that the Prime Minister clearly indicated that he did not approve of its going. I have not heard any comments about it.

The Opposition believes that it is fine to hold meetings of heads of government. But we should not place too much emphasis on the likely results. Let us consider what has happened in the past. I attended a Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Jamaica in 1975. Some countries were deploring the failure of countries such as Australia to take action. I listened to President Nyerere and President Kaunda clearly say that they were fed up with former Australian prime ministers, particularly those in the 1950s and the 1960s, telling them for 20 years that something would be done about the problems of Rhodesia. They said that nothing had happened. I remember President Nyerere of Tanzania saying to the British Prime Minister: 'I warn you that there will be warfare in Rhodesia within 10 weeks because we will not wait any longer'. That clearly signalled how President Nyerere saw the problems at that time. He was roundly criticising Australian prime ministers from 20 years earlier for doing nothing except espousing rhetoric. He was warning that there would be bloodshed in that area within a matter of weeks and saying, virtually, that it would have to be encouraged. One had to recognise, Nyerere said, that once Mozambique got its independence further pressure would be exerted. He was saying to everybody around the table: 'We have to get democracy into this area'. It has come belatedly, but it has come, and we ought to support Mugabe and others who have a big role to play in that area.

Let me also decry some of the suggestions that flowed from the Jamaica conference, where we had the unpleasant experience of the leader of the Government of Singapore indicating to the United States that he did not altogether approve of the Labor Government of Australia. I do not approve of that sort of conduct and put that fact on record. I notice that in recent months he has been saying that he felt that Australians were perhaps not doing their best, that they were loafing on the job a bit. Let us face the fact that in this nation we have oppositions and we have governments. In Singapore they are a bit hard to see. That is one of the other matters that one must talk about. We see, in the region to our north a frantic desire to support the Chinese communist philosophy on what should be done to achieve peace and stability in Kampuchea, and the urging of continued recognition of the Pol Pot regime.

I place high value on certain statements made by Mr Trudeau as far back as 1975. When asked how he saw his country's position, as one that was alongside the United States, he gave an answer that was pretty graphic: 'It is like sleeping alongside an elephant'. That is the position. We find Prime Minister Trudeau clearly indicating an independent course of action in El Salvador and not encouraging a solution through armament. I commend Prime Minister Trudeau on such aspirations and expressions because it requires courage to say to the world: 'We want leaders to meet but we want them to discuss matters as a result of which something will be done. We do not want any such meeting to be just a forum'.

While we talk of security, let us bear in mind that the people who lost their lives at the last Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Sydney were two council employees and a police officer. We should emphasise the need for security for our people. The heads of government were somewhat secure. If we embark upon world armament and its escalation, we will all be in danger.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to announce that the Government has agreed on a series of wide-ranging decisions concerning the future of phosphate mining on Christmas Island, and the purchasing and distribution of phosphate rock for Australia's requirements. The changes to be implemented are among the most significant made since mining operations first began on the island. They have a key importance for Australian rural industries, as Christmas Island phosphate is a major component in superphosphate production throughout the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions followed long and careful consideration of the many conflicting issues involved, and extensive consultation in recent months between the governments of Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. I have spoken to trade unions, manufacturers' and farmers' representatives, and the existing management organisations currently in charge of the industry. The changes that I will announce are to take effect from 1 July of this year.

Honourable members will recall that, under the existing structure, mining on Christmas Island is carried out by the British Phosphate Commissioners as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. On behalf of Australian and New Zealand manufacturers of superphosphate, the BPC also purchases phosphate rock from various sources and ships it to both countries. The BPC was established by the Nauru Island Agreement 1919 between Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom, and each government appoints one commissioner. The Christmas Island Phosphate Commission was established in 1949 by the governments of Australia and New Zealand to control the phosphate mining operations on Christmas Island on their behalf.

Last year the report of the Sweetland inquiry into the viability of the Christmas Island phosphate industry was tabled in the Parliament. It made several recommendations for changing the present arrangements for the mining of phosphate rock on Christmas Island and for the purchasing and distribution of phosphate rock generally. Other recommendations on what might be called non-phosphate matters were dealt with by the Government last year and the decisions announced by the Minister for Home Affairs on 25 June 1980. Subsequently the commissioners of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission and the Board of the British Phosphate Commissioners separately recommended to the governments of Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom that the organisations be wound up. I wish to pay tribute to the BPC for its efforts over 61 years in providing Australia and New Zealand with assured supplies of phosphate. It has performed its task commendably in the interests of the three countries.
Mining on Christmas Island

Australia and New Zealand have now agreed that the BPC will cease to be the managing agents as from 30 June 1981 or as soon as possible thereafter. The two governments are also seeking the concurrence of the United Kingdom Government to the BPC being wound up, its assets being realised, and the proceeds being divided among the three partner governments. The governments of Australia and New Zealand have also agreed that the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission should be wound up as soon as possible. This reflects some profound changes which the governments of Australia and New Zealand have agreed upon. New Zealand wishes to withdraw from the present arrangement and relinquish its right to extract phosphate and its related rights under the Christmas Island Agreement. It wishes, however, to retain the right to purchase up to half the total phosphate rock output from the island, at the same free-on-board price as that of the rock supplied to Australia. These and other changes which I shall mention shortly will be reflected in an entirely new Christmas Island agreement between the two countries.

The new mining operator on Christmas Island will be an organisation owned and controlled by the Australian Government, initially in the form of a government company. It will not be exempt from company tax. The question of establishing the company as a statutory corporation will be considered when the life of the operation has been more firmly established. I mention in this connection that the Government currently has under study a very recent report on the impact of the mining operation on the bird known as the Abbott's booby. The company will resemble other Commonwealth-owned companies and will be headed by a board of directors. In accordance with the relevant recommendation in the Sweetland report, one of the directors will be nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Another will be a farmers' representative. I hope to be able to announce the names of the directors shortly.

An appropriate firm of chartered accountants and management consultants will be retained to advise on the establishment of the company generally and the steps necessary to ensure a smooth transition from the present to the new institutional arrangements. The question of responsibility of municipal and similar type functions on the island and their operation and financing will also be examined in this context. Honourable members wil be aware that the net cost of administering Christmas Island is now met largely by the mining operator. It is also responsible for the provision of many services which on the mainland are the responsibility of local or State Governments. In the Government's view, it is timely that these arrangements be reviewed.

Because of the need to establish the new company quickly, it will begin life by replacing the BPC as the managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission under the Christmas Island Agreement. I will be seeking parliamentary approval very shortly of the changes to the agreement to enable this to occur. These proposed amendments will be separate from the revision of the Christmas Island Agreement, to which I referred earlier, under which the new company will become responsible for the mining operation.
Purchasing and Shippng of Australian Phosphate Rock Requirements

Under the present arrangements, the British Phosphate Commissioners act as purchasing and shipping agents for the phosphate rock used by superphosphate manufacturers in Australia and New Zealand. The Government has decided that with the winding up of the BPC, Australian manufacturers will assume responsibility for the purchasing of phosphate rock, including rock from the traditional sources of Christmas Island and Nauru, and for shipping it to Australia. The manufacturers are now in the process of forming the Australian Phosphate Corporation to perform these functions. I understand that the manufacturers are in touch with relevant shipping organisations and maritime unions as to the future use of three Australian-crewed ships presently under charter to the BPC. These new arrangements will come into effect on 1 July 1981. I understand that New Zealand manufacturers are to take similar steps.
Stockpiles

I now turn to the question of future arrangements for the ownership and control of the phosphate rock stockpiles in Australia and New Zealand, which are at present owned by the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. The governments of Australia and New Zealand have agreed that the stockpiles at manufacturers' plants in Australia and New Zealand as at 30 June 1981 should become the property of the respective governments, it being understood that the proportions will roughly reflect historical procurement patterns. The two governments have also agreed that it will be for each of them to determine the means and timing of the disposal of the stockpiles whilst aiming at the maximum possible uniformity of approach, and that any reduction in the stockpiles be undertaken in an orderly and non-disruptive manner, having regard to the viability of the mining operations. Detailed provisions on these matters will be negotiated with New Zealand and will be included in the new Christmas Island agreement.

As to the phosphate rock stockpiles in Australia, it has been decided that ownership of them after 30 June will be retained by the Government. The stockpiles will be managed on the same lines as at present; that is, manufacturers will buy rock from the stockpiles at current market value at the time of sale, or they will replace what they buy. Detailed arrangements for the administration of the stockpiles are to be a subject of further consideration by the Government and an announcement will be made in due course. The Government does not, at this stage, see these arrangements as necessarily continuing indefinitely. The whole question of stockpile ownership and management will be looked at again no later than one year before mining on Christmas Island ceases. I should add that in taking this decision the Government was anxious not to make too many changes at once to the present arrangements affecting phosphate generally.
The Sweetland Report

Finally, I turn to the specific recommendations of the Sweetland report on phosphate matters. The Government has accepted the first two recommendations dealing with the continuation of the mining operation and shipping targets. Recommendations 3 to 6, dealing with new institutional arrangements, have been dealt with earlier in this statement. Recommendations 7 to 12, dealing with cost reductions in the mining operation, provision for reserves, markets in South East Asia, shipping operations, a review of the manning of the mining operation including more professional training for island employees, and improved domestic accommodation on the island, have been generally endorsed by the Government and will be referred to the new mining company for consideration and action as appropriate. I take this opportunity to express again the Government's debt to Mr Sweetland for his report. Honourable members will be aware that the Government has recently appointed Mr Sweetland to undertake the further task of looking at the long term future of Christmas Island.
Conclusion

The changes I have announced are significant.
