They directly affect many varied interests-the community of Christmas Island currently dependent upon the mining operations, the shippers, the seamen who transport the phosphate, the manufacturers, and the farmers who ultimately depend on the benefits of superphosphate. Difficult decisions of such major importance demand the most thorough consideration by the Government. I have visited Christmas Island to see the mining operations and have had face-to-face discussions with those parties on the island. On the Australian mainland I have met with all those parties who wished to express their point of view. I am now confident there will be a general acceptance amongst them of all those matters which the Government had power to determine and which I have announced.

In making these changes the Government has been glad to have been able to preserve our long-standing association with New Zealand on phosphate matters, although in a different form. In conclusion, I say on behalf of the Government to all parties concerned in the new arrangements, that we are confident that, given their goodwill and a desire to co-operate, the new procedures will work well and to the benefit of us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes the statement of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) on measures concerning the future of phosphate mining on Christmas Island and the measures in regard to the purchase and distribution of phosphate rock for Australia's requirements. The Opposition has a keen appreciation of the way in which the rural sector values its superphosphate and the dismay with which the rural sector regards the $12 a tonne bounty because of the way the price of superphosphate is inflating. For example, in addition to paying a $12 a tonne bounty, recently the price of superphosphate in New South Wales went up by $4.35 a tonne. The total bounty payment this year will be $46m which is less than last year. That is due mainly to the estimated levels of superphosphate usage. The National Farmers Federation is very concerned about the price of fertilisers and it has set up a task force to investigate all possible ways of containing their cost to Australia's farmers. It is very concerned about the skyrocketing fertiliser prices, particularly the price of nitrogenous fertilisers.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that the Christmas Island deposit has a limited life, but we welcome the fact that the Duchess deposit in Queensland can again be producing by 1981-82. This will give the Australian producers a fairly long term supply of superphosphate. The price is the main thing. The only qualification the Opposition would like to put forward is that there is a need for more details on the amount of money involved in the stockpile and we need to be informed about the way it is financed now. I have been told that the value of the stockpile is about $80m. I am not saying that we oppose the new arrangements, which basically will involve a government organisation replacing the British Phosphate Commissioners. There would be a similar organisation for the fertiliser producers here. There has always been this linkage and I think the new arrangement is very sensible. By and large, it is one that the industry is used to.

The Minister already has said in his statement that there are more announcements to be made. The Opposition would like more details so that we can understand the economics of the situation. Eventually the mining will cease and there will be a stockpile. It will be a revolving stockpile virtually being held in trust. I can see that at the end of it all, with escalating fertiliser prices, the Government may make a handsome profit. I make that qualification. I note also that the Minister has said the question of stockpile ownership will be looked at again no later than one year before mining at Christmas Island ceases. That is seven years off.

I visited Christmas Island in 1974 as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation which investigated endangered species on the Island, particularly the Abbott's booby bird, the Christmas Island frigatebird, a species of turtle and a type of pigeon. There was a range of species specific to that island. I never actually saw an Abbott's booby bird but I am assured there are 2,000 nesting pairs on the island. Christmas Island is a beautiful island and an ugly island. The part mined is totally devastated; it presents a moonscape. There is some vegitation trying to take hold but, particularly in the areas mined in the early days with horses and carts and shovels and buckets, there is virtually no phosphate left and there are simply limestone pinnacles. It presents a rather unique but ugly landscape.

Honourable members might be interested in some of the pearls of wisdom we gained while on the island with respect to the Abbott's booby bird. The bird nests on Christmas Island and nowhere else. It nests in emergent trees, trees above the existing tree cover. When we suggested to an engineer there that this species would be endangered if all the trees were lopped, his reply was that the birds would have to land somewhere. The Malaysians who work the deposits on the island also have a hard-hearted approach to the birds. There are rather large basaltic cliffs on the island; the birds hover in the updrafts and they are quite easy to knock on the head. Apparently they make good eating. As an old chook farmer, I suggested that we put some chickens on the island for eating purposes but they assured me that they far preferred to eat the native birds. I will give honourable members another pearl of wisdom that arose: As we had not seen an Abbott's booby bird, we asked what their habits were. We were told that they came to the island for a few months, nested and when the young birds could fly they took off. We were assured that they took off at an angle of about 45 degrees, went up to a height of 30,000 feet and were not seen for another nine months. When we pointed out their need for oxygen masks at that altitude, we were greeted with an attitude of some dismay. I am sure they do not go quite to 30,000 feet. Apart from that, they are truly unique.

I am pleased to see that the commission of inquiry into the viability of the Christmas Island phosphate industry-the Sweetland report-and the Minister's statement have both expressed concern with regard to endangered species on the island. The Minister has set out for honourable members the management structure that has prevailed and that which will prevail in the future. The Opposition believes that the new arrangements are sensible enough but it will insist that the new organisation owned and controlled by the Australian Government takes decisive steps to look after the people on the island in a less paternal way than has occurred in the past. The Sweetland report on the viability of the island's phosphate deposits brought these matters into full focus. Briefly, the report stated that Christmas Island is viable and there are at least eight years of rock on the island, even given the payment of workers at Australian Federal minimum award wage rates. We have allowed the British Phosphate Commissioners to discriminate against the workers for all the years of rock extraction in what is an Australian territory, in what is a multiracial society. The Sweetland report states that the British Phosphate Commissioners did not adapt to the passing of colonialism. Page 3 of the report states:

The institutional framework within which Christmas Island operates is out-moded, discredited, and in many ways repugnant. Many of the Island's problems can be traced to this fact. The British Phosphate Commissioners (BPC) is an organisation which has not adapted quickly enough or willingly enough to the passing of the colonial era. Its shareholders, the governments of Britain, New Zealand and Australia have not required it to adapt to these changes. Responsibility ulti- mately rests with those governments and their servants. The structure of the Government Administration on the Island, and much of the law that is in force, is more appropriate to a colonial possession than it is to a remote multi-racial mining community on Australian territory.

The report goes on to talk about the problems which have arisen because of parallel partnership between Australia and New Zealand. In his statement the Minister for Administrative Services said that the New Zealand Government has withdrawn from those arrangements and now seeks only to be involved in a commercial way. I think one needs to acknowledge the bargaining and the negotiations that must have gone on to secure that arrangement.

The second major point that the Sweetland report makes is that Christmas Island will have a competitive edge now and in the future and that demand for superphosphate is ensured. The recommendations in that report put forward measures that put beyond doubt the continued economic viability of the island while phosphate rock remains. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the 16 recommendations of the Sweetland report.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows-
RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Christmas Island phosphate mining operations should be continued with the objective of extracting at minimum cost all mineable reserves of A grade material together with the maximum volume of B grade material that the Wash-Screen Plant will treat. Sufficient mineable reserves are available to ensure a life of eight years from the present time at the current rate of production. It is axiomatic that this operation be conducted in an environment of comparative wage justice.

2. The annual shipping target should be 1.4 million tonnes of rock to the specification required by Australian and New Zealand manufacturers, and 150,000 tonnes of bagged dust, or of rock to be crushed for bagged dust production, in Malayasia.
3. The Australian Government should seek from the New Zealand Government an indication of New Zealand's willingness to continue to participate as a full partner in the Christmas Island operation.

4. In consultation with the New Zealand Government, the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission (CIPC) should be reconstituted with a Board of five Commissioners. Two Commissioners with mining industry background should be appointed by the Australian and New Zealand Governments. Two should be nominated by the Australian and New Zealand fertiliser industry and the fifth should be nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

5. The Australian Government should seek the agreement of the governments of the United Kingdom and New Zealand to terminate the appointment of the BPC as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission.

6. The reconstituted Christmas Island Phosphate Commission should create two divisions-Mining, and Distribution and Marketing-with a General Manager in charge of each division reporting directly to the Board. The General Manager Mining should be located on Christmas Island with a minimum staff based in Melbourne, to attend to corporate, purchasing and technical matters. The General Manager Distribution and Marketing should be based in Melbourne, and this Division should take over from the BPC those functions for which the CIPC has responsibility as principal under the Christmas Island Agreements No. 87, 1949, and No. 69, 1958; the Agreement between the CIPC and the BPC in relation to the Purchase and Distribution of Phosphate 1968; and the Phosphate Supply Agreement between the BPC, as managing agent for the CIPC, and the fertiliser manufacturers in Australia.
7. Full consideration should be given by the Commission (CIPC) to proposals for the expenditure of capital on projects directed towards cost reductions, particularly those involving labour savings.

8. Christmas Island f.o.b. prices should include a provision for contribution to reserves during periods when world phosphate prices are high, which could be drawn upon when Christmas Island costs are greater than prices of phosphate rock from alternative sources.

9. The CIPC Distribution and Marketing Division should actively pursue markets in South East Asia for by-products of the A grade rock, and the B and C grade rock which have been developed from research projects. The possibility of calcining C grade rock at a location in Malaysia should be thoroughly investigated, possibily in conjunction with ICI Malaysia and Chemical Company of Malaysia (CCM).

10. Shipping operations should be planned, if possible, with the objective of minimising the 'ballast running' of vessels in the trade, and minimising the programming of vessels to load during the heavy weather seasons.

11. (a) The manning of the Island operation should be reviewed as soon as possible. The review should be undertaken in consultation with the unions and it should, if necessary, be done with the assistance of experienced management consultants. Its objective should be to maximise efficiency of production.

(b) The CIPC should select from among the Island workforce employees those who are most likely to benefit from professional training. It should provide that training with a view to filling senior supervisory positions from among members of the Malay and Chinese communities on the Island, and remove any further discrimination between their remunerations and benefits and those of staff of European descent.
(c) Unless the circumstances or requirements are exceptional, the following order of preference should apply in further recruitment to the Island's labour force:
(i) former Island workers and their children now resident on the mainland;
(ii) other Australian citizens;
(iii) citizens of Malaysia.
12. (a) A capital provision should be made to upgrade domestic accommodation in the older sections of the settlement, both for single men and families.
(b) As the labour force is reduced and single accommodation becomes surplus to requirements, these units should be modified and made available for married couples.
13. The Christmas Island Industrial Relations Ordinance should be repealed as soon as possible, and the full provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act extended to cover Christmas Island.

14. (a) Residents of Christmas Island should qualify for citizenship in exactly the same manner as foreign nationals who take up permanent residence on the Australian mainland. The provisions of the Citizenship Act 1948 as amended should be extended by ordinance to include Christmas Island. The citizenship provisions of the Christmas Island Act 1958-1973 should be repealed.

(b) The Migration Act should be extended by ordinance to include Christmas Island so that further movements of people to the Island from foreign countries can be regulated in the same manner as occurs on the mainland.

(c) Island residents who would not yet have qualified for Australian citizenship under the provisions of the Citizenship Act as extended to Christmas Island, and whose positions become redundant as a consequence of any restructuring of the phosphate mining operation, should be accepted as eligible for permanent residence on the mainland, subject to health and character checks.
15. (a) The cost of maintaining the Island Administration should be met by the Australian Government.

(b) The objective of the Island Administration should be redefined to ensure the earliest possible removal of the administrative anomalies that distinguish Christmas Island from the Australian mainland. Christmas Island's social and political institutions should become progressively closer in form to those that characterise isolated mining communities on the mainland, and progressively less like those of a colonial possession. To this end, Article 8 (1) of the Christmas Island Act 1958-1973 should be amended to provide that Commonwealth Acts shall include Christmas Island in their coverage unless specific provision to the contrary is made. At present, no Commonwealth Act applies on Christmas Island unless appropriate provision is specifically made. Evidence was given by representatives of the Department of Home Affairs that in the extension to Christmas Island of existing legislation a large backlog of drafting has arisen. Steps should be taken to eliminate this.

(c) The Advisory Council should be set up as quickly as possible, and the Administrator should invite it to sound community opinion and advise him on what form of political and community representation consistent with those that exist on the mainland would best accord with the wishes of the Island's inhabitants. Parliamentary representation should be included among the possibilities to be considered.

(d) As soon as an acceptable form of political representation has been established, the office of Administrator should be abolished and responsibility for liaison with the Department of Home Affairs should be assumed by a 'Department of Home Affairs Liaison Officer'. The residence of the Administrator should be made available to residents of the Island for a purpose of their choosing.

(e) Early consideration should be given to the appointment of a small number of Justices of the Peace with limited judicial function, or alternatively to the appointment of one or two Special Magistrates with limited judicial function, from the different ethnic communities on the Island.

16. The newly constituted CIPC should expand its program of reafforestation on the Island, making greater use of back-filling in mined areas. Bird populations should be monitored as accurately as possible so that any signs of significant decline can be detected and appropriate action taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I ask the Minister whether he will report regularly to the House on the progress of the new organisation, when it is set up, which is owned by the Australian Government, particularly with respect to the continuing economics of the phosphate extraction, whether there are any changes in the level of reserves, the conditions in the work force, the future of workers when mining ceases and the question of endangered species. The Opposition notes that, within the statement, there were hints in these areas, particularly with respect to the Abbott's booby bird. A report is now before the Government. I think that all these matters need to be reported to the House. I hope that the Minister will undertake to do that.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 34, General Business, being called on forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Transport for his failure to fulfil his Ministerial duties by failing to provide essential information and support to the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares and further by repeatedly misleading the Parliament and the public in relation to the purposes and conduct of the inquiry.

The principle of ministerial responsibility, trust and accurate accountability to the parliament is fundamental to the proper functioning of the Westminster system of government and fundamental to the operation of our parliamentary system. A Minister of State's commission from the Queen's representatives not only carries with it power, prestige and a set of onerous duties but also places upon the Minister a heavy responsibility for efficient performance, propriety in conduct and honesty in reporting to the parliament on the conduct of his duties.

From copies of correspondence attached to the report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, from statements made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to the Parliament and from public reports it is abundantly clear that the Minister for Transport repeatedly misled the inquiry team as to the intent and purpose of its task. He denied the inquiry assistance and information essential to the proper conduct of its affairs. It was his responsibility to ensure that such was provided. He deprived the inquiry of adequate time in which to carry out the responsibilities with which he had charged it. He repudiated firm undertakings as to the life of the inquiry and the provision of data resources. He had given these undertakings to members of the inquiry on their appointment and at subsequent meetings.

Further, the Minister blatantly and despicably misrepresented statements made by members of the committee as to the undertakings he gave them. He adopted a partisan approach in favour of the major beneficiary of the two-airline agreement, Ansett Airlines of Australia. He failed in his relationship with the inquiry to ensure that the interests of air travellers and the owners of Trans-Australia Airlines were properly protected. He embarked also on a campaign of character assassination of the committee members once he found out that they were not prepared to carry out his will, once he found that they were determined to act in an honest and professional manner. In these circumstances, the Minister does not deserve the confidence of the House.

To appreciate fully the insincerity of this Minister, his incompetence, his partiality towards Ansett Airlines of Australia and his abject failure to perform his duties responsibly and in an honourable fashion it is necessary to relate the sequence of events associated with the inquiry. One has only to recall the lackey-like behaviour of this Minister and the pretence he carried on when, as Minister for Health, he destroyed Medibank.

In the case of the fares inquiry a similar pretence was perpetrated by the Minister because the inquiry, in the course of its investigations and its duties and in seeking relevant information from Ansett Airlines, began to get too close to the bone. It was likely to expose the rip-off of air travellers under this Government's high air fare policy. Let me make it clear that this Government and this Minister owe their political survival to the proprietors of Ansett Airlines of Australia, Mr Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles. The Government is effectively a captive of the proprietors of Ansett Airlines. When the inquiry sought to explore the handsome financial benefits derived by Ansett Airlines at the expense of air travellers under the terms of its licence to print money-the two-airline agreement-the proprietors called for a brake on the committee's activities. The Government, through the bumbling, compliant Minister for Transport, readily obliged because the Minister was well aware that so far as the Government is concerned Ansett's financial interests took preference over the interests of air travellers.

To understand the behaviour of the Minister in this matter, I should like to mention the events leading up to the establishment of the inquiry. In the face of growing public criticism of the Government's high air fare policy and the two-airline agreement that the Government decided that action needed to be taken to blunt the criticism of those policies. Following the gigantic stock exchange battle of 1979 when Mr Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles gained control of Ansett, discussions were commenced with them on a new two-airline agreement. In that stock exchange battle the Government had given its mute endorsement to the new ownership. In December 1979, the Minister said that it was in the interests of all Australians that major changes were to be made to the two-airline agreement.

I inform the House that the first preference of Sir Peter Abeles for the two-airline agreement was that Trans-Australia Airlines should be sold to commercial interests. We all know that inevitably that would lead to a private monopoly in the provision of air services in this country. The second preference of Ansett Airlines of Australia was that TAA financial structure should be changed and that TAA should be required to produce a 10 per cent profit on revenue after tax compared with a 6 per cent profit on revenue before tax and interest recommended by the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a handout for the Murdoch mob.

—It is a money making machine for the supporters of the Government. The people being ripped off are the air travellers of this country. The inquiry was established then by the Minister to defuse air fares as an issue and to head off the moves in Western Australia for the nomination of a Senate candidate under the heading of 'cheaper air fares for Western Australia'. The Minister sought to head off the possibility of the nomination of that candidate at the coming election. When the inquiry was established the Minister then faced the dilemma that his masters at Ansett Airlines who wanted faster and larger fare increases and greater profits had to be balanced with the interests of those of the public who wanter lower air fares and better public accountability by airlines. Subsequent events have shown that Ansett won again.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite his statement on 20 March that details of the fare inquiry would be announced the following week, it was not until nine weeks later that the Minister was able to tell the Parliament who would be members of the inquiry. He indicated at the beginning that there was not going to be much to the inquiry because he said: 'I do not think the inquiry is any great panacea for travellers round Australia. I do not think it will resolve the issue by obtaining cheaper air fares'. He underestimated the capacity of the committee. When the Minister met the committee on 3 June last he made it abundantly clear to its members that no time limit was stipulated on the activities of the inquiry. He gave his personal assurance to the members of the committee that the co-operation of all major parties had been vouchsafed. On 9 June the inquiry opened in Sydney. It was not until 28 June that submissions were invited and they closed in August. The Budget Papers last August showed that some $379,000 was allocated for the inquiry. Importantly-this is the point the Minister cannot get around-the notes on the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services state:
. . . the Government has not set a date by which the Committee is to report and should the completion date not be achieved, it will be necessary to review the estimates . . .

Those words expose the falsehoods of the Minister in recent days in relation to this matter. They expose the maliciousness of the Minister in attempting to impugn the integrity of the chairman of the committee, Mr Holcroft, by claiming that the committee had an intent to terminate on 31 January 1981 and by implying that Mr Holcroft is a liar. The Minister for Administrative Services has confirmed the notes on the Department's estimates of August last year and the Minister for Transport has confirmed to me in writing, through the committee, the accuracy of the information provided by the Department of Administrative Services, that is, that the inquiry was expected to conclude in mid-July 1981 and that it was the responsibility of the inquiry to determine its own program of public hearings. He clearly and precisely confirmed that information. We have learned subsequently that Western Australian back bench members of the Government-let those who deny it stand up and be identified-have since confirmed that the Minister told the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in their presence that the committee was due to report in mid-July of this year. Thus the Minister's attack on Mr Holcroft's integrity was cowardly and a debasement of his office.

I turn to the denial of support to the committee by this Minister. In chopping short the activities of the inquiry, the Minister was fully aware that the people of several States would not have access to the committee's hearings and that Western Australia would not have the benefit of the resumed hearings that had been promised. Mr Holcroft has told the Parliament of the personal assurances given by the Minister, assurances which have since been repudiated. The Minister's Department did not place a submission and did not provide the co-operation that the Minister had promised. It was not until 13 days after the committee had been ordered to conclude that the Department of Transport lodged its submission with the inquiry. The Minister, falsely, has offered the pressure of work by his Department in the preparation of the new two-airline agreement as an excuse for the delay of nine months from when the inquiry was announced and the Department of Transport, with this Minister as its head and some 11,000 employees, put together a submission to its own inquiry. The delay was part of the cover-up. The Government did not want the information revealed. Last night the Government's back bench committee was told again by an officer of the Department of Transport that that Department had been advised by the Minister's office that there was no rush to put in a submission. Again, the Minister has been exposed as to the way that he suppressed the activities of this committee and tried to mislead and misrepresent its activities. Additionally, Mr Wheeden of the Department of Transport told the inquiry last year that no published information was available on airline cost components other than the work done by the Bureau of Transport Economics.

But this Minister, who professed that there was a public inquiry and who wanted to see the facts, ensured that the BTE did not submit a submission, despite the evidence of his own officer that it had the only public information available on that subject. That information was absolutely critical to the conduct of the inquiry. Again, the Minister sought to blame somebody else: First Mr Holcroft and then the BTE. What has happened to the BTE since? The Director has resigned. In his devotion to the proprietors of Ansett, the Minister instructed the committee not to examine the two-airline agreement with the ridiculous assertion that the two-airline agreement is not relevant to an examination of the air fare structure. The air fare structure is a product of the two-airline agreement. It is inseparable from the agreement. The Holcroft committee recognised this fact. On 3 March, Mr Holcroft exposed the real reason that the Minister did not want the two-airline agreement examined when he said:
I don't think the Department of Transport--
That is, the Minister:
or Sir Peter Abeles saw it that way and you would have to believe that they filibustered on us a bit. There were delaying tactics all the way through to stop us getting information.

Added to the committee's difficulties in obtaining relevant information was the Minister's connivance in having the committee turned out of its premises part way through the inquiry. But the supreme insult to the committee came when it had to be advised by Sir Peter Abeles that there was to be a change in government policy. The advice was given not through the Minister but by his real master, Sir Peter Abeles, who advised that a new two-airline agreement was being signed. The Minister's difficulty with the committee then was that, having set up an inquiry into air fares to carry through a pretence of Government concern with public criticism of the air fare policies, he had to head off plans that would expose the real profits being made by Ansett and the real benefits being given to that company under the guise of the two-airline agreement. The dishonourable course taken by the Minister was to favour Ansett again and to curtail the activities of the committee, even if it meant betraying his responsibilities as a Minister.

The Holcroft committee, despite the denial of information and support to it by the Government, has done the Parliament a great service. It has exposed the pretence carried on by this Minister, it has revealed the excessive profits being made by Ansett Airlines at the air travellers' expense and it has highlighted to all Australians the power of the proprieters of Ansett over this Government. Honourable members will recall that on the last night of the last parliamentary session this Minister introduced the Australian National Airlines Commission Amendment Bill-a phoney Bill. That Bill embodied the requests made in January of last year by Sir Peter Abeles to this Minister that Trans-Australia Airlines' financial structure be changed and that TAA's profit objective be changed. The major beneficiary of the extra profit that would flow from that change to airline arrangements-increased fares would have to flow through to provide the additional profit-would be Ansett Airlines. It would be the major beneficiary of the real purpose of the amendment to TAA's legislation. Ansett and TAA have to charge the same fares under the two-airline agreement, so that when TAA's fares go up, Ansett's have to follow. If the Government forces TAA to increase its fares through this legislation, Ansett will be the major beneficiary of the windfall gain. Ansett is already making excessive profits. Mr Holcroft has shown that in his report.

The legislation I have referred to would bring super profits to Ansett at the expense of the public of this country. Sir Peter and Rupert Murdoch have got their way so far. But this Government and this Minister, who has repudiated his undertaking to a public body, owe their positions to the Ansett empire. The services rendered have now to be paid for. The first payment is the curtailment of the fare inquiry and the continued suppression of information on Ansett's financial performance. Ansett has again escaped from having to provide detailed and substantive financial information on its performance. Throughout the life of the two-airline agreement under previous conservative governments and this Government, Ansett Airlines has never had to produce the detailed information that is necessary to a proper examination of what is going on in that company and in the airline industry of this country. The second payment is to be the new, more restrictive, 10-year two-airline agreement with its automatic fare increase. Another request which was made in writing-it sits on the Minister's file-by Sir Peter Abeles to this Minister as part of the payup, was provision for an automatic fare increase, and that is proposed in the legislation affecting TAA.

The third payment-to tidy it all up-is to be the amendment to TAA's legislation, so that fare levels will have to go up. Towering over this scandalous affair and this disreputable Minister is the shadow of Ansett's proprietors. Partners with this Government in a disgraceful deal, they are ripping off the Australian travelling public and deluding this Parliament and the people of this country as to the true conduct of airline affairs and the profits being made by Ansett Airlines in this country. The Opposition's views, and the views I have expressed in respect of the inquiry, are shared by many of the major media journals published in this country.

Let me refer to some august journals which are not necessarily sympathetic to the causes of the Australian Labor Party. I refer to the Australian Financial Review of 27 February and the Sydney Morning Herald also of 27 February. The report in the Australian Financial Review refers to the Holcroft inquiry as being nobbled and warns any other businessman asked by this Government to participate in a public inquiry to beware. When this Government sets up inquiries it wants dummies and yes-men who will carry out the bidding of subservient Ministers whose first responsibility is to the Murdoch and Ansett empires. The editorial in the Australian Financial Review states:

The nobbling of the Holcroft inquiry is therefore a serious matter. The committee's report has performed an important public service by drawing attention to the unsatisfactory conditions in which it has had to work and the way in which the beneficiaries of Government largesse have been allowed to evade any public accountability.
The editorial also states:

For the behaviour of the Government towards the committee, and the behaviour of a number of parties which should have assisted the committee, has been nothing short of scandalous. The Government effectively precluded the committee from thorough examination of a number of central issues and forced it to report with such haste that the report is inevitably deficient in many respects.

Whilst it is deficient in many respects, the substance of its recommendations bear worthy consideration and the committee has exposed much of the largesse that is being handed out to Ansett by this Government under the two-airline agreement. Ansett will receive more if the new two-airline agreement happens to be ratified by both Houses. An editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald made the point that any public citizen invited to participate in a government inquiry should beware. It states:
Why should such citizens, who suffer from the delusion that the Government genuinely needs their services, put up with the contemptuous treatment that they ultimately receive.

This Minister is hiding behind the privilege of this Parliament. He is not outside making these statements publicly. But in here during Question Time he is nice and quiet. He is defaming, denigrating and abusing the character of three honourable men who have done all that was asked of them and who have responsibly carried out their public duties. As these three men have said: 'We are three honourable businessmen who want to tell the truth all the time about what we are doing'. This Minister is hiding behind the cowardly cloak of parliamentary privilege. He has not told the Parliament or the public the truth and has suppressed a public inquiry. He has treated air travellers, the public and the Parliament with absolute contempt. He has repudiated the trust placed in him and he has repudiated his own undertakings. He has misled the Parliament and the people as to his role in the conduct and actions of the inquiry. He has been exposed by a courageous and upright committee. He is now embarking upon a campaign to denigrate the members of that committee. This Minister has breached the trust placed in him as a Minister of State. In doing so he has destroyed any entitlement he had to the confidence of this House. He has been responsible for the squandering of some $378,000 of taxpayers' money and in these circumstances he does not deserve the confidence of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak until after I have heard whatever might be the defence of the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This censure motion attempts to censure the Minister for Transport on two counts: Firstly, the failure to provide essential information and support for the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares and, secondly, allegedly misleading the Parliament in relation to the purpose and conduct of that inquiry. I absolutely refute these wild assertions, as indeed I refute a number of other wild assertions made by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) in his personal attack upon me. The honourable member for Shortland stated that discussions commenced on the new two-airline agreement after the Abeles-Murdoch ownership of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd in December 1979. That is absolutely not true. Discussions on the new two-airline agreement were commenced in July 1978 by the then Minister for Transport after the domestic air transport policy review. Those discussions took place as a result of recommendations contained in the report of that review. The discussions I undertook were renewed with the change of ownership in the airline.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to put into proper sequence the events leading up to a decision by the Government not to give the extension of time sought by the Holcroft inquiry which was formally transmitted to me by letter on 14 November. A meeting held by the Government with Western Australian back benchers happened to take place on 26 November, which was 12 days after the transmission of the Holcroft inquiry request.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you calling them liars?
—Mr Speaker, I am not calling people liars. I do not use that term.

—Order! The motion is a censure motion on the Minister. The mover of the motion was heard in silence. The Minister against whom the motion is directed ought also to be heard in silence without any interjections.

—That letter was transmitted to me on 14 November advising that the committee sought an extension of time to complete its inquiry. It was not until 27 November that the Government resolved to seek the report by 31 January this year. It was as a result of discussions that took place within the Government, with back benchers and others that the Government decided to give to the Holcroft inquiry the answer that it did. I want also to refute the allegation that the Director of the Bureau of Transport Economics resigned because of this incident. Dr Gannon's appointment was for a limited tenure. That tenure expired and he decided to return to the university. That was another very wild assertion made by the honourable member for Shortland.
—I did not say that.

—Let the honourable member read Hansard and let him take my reply as being a matter of fact. The Holcroft inquiry had my complete endorsement and support. Soon after I became the Minister for Transport I was convinced that there was a need for an inquiry into the way in which air fares were set on individual routes in the national network by the use of an air fare formula. As a result of submissions from Western Australian members of parliament and organisations I felt it was essential to establish whether inequities existed in the air fare structure to the disadvantage of long distance travellers. I am on record as having made known my concern on a number of occasions in this Parliament. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a number of references from Hansard which indicate my concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The references read as follows-
19 February 1980-Hansard page 13-Question

. . . Western Australian members of the Parliament. They sought a public inquiry or an independent inquiry into the air fare structure in Australia. Currently an inquiry is taking place at the departmental level. I did give an undertaking that when the Prime Minister returned I would discuss the matter with him. We have had a discussion on the issue and I will be preparing a paper. The Government will be considering the nature of any future inquiry in due course.
20 March 1980-Hansard page 1006-Question
It is against that background that the Government has decided to undertake an inquiry into the airfare structure throughout Australia, and certainly on the major domestic routes.
A fares inquiry undoubtedly will have some bearing on the issues he has raised in this question. In regard to another part of the question.
15 April 1980-Hansard page 1694-Question

It was against that background that the Government decided to establish a public inquiry into the air fare structure in Australia. I hope to be in a position in the course of the next week to make an announcement on the terms of reference and the personnel to undertake that inquiry.
20 May 1980-Hansard page 2887-Question

. . . 91 per cent of Western Australians voted very strongly in favour of an independent inquiry into air fares throughout Australia. Neither the honourable member for Tangney nor the 91 per cent of people in Western Australia who share his view will be disappointed, because the Government has decided upon the terms of reference and also has decided who will conduct that independent inquiry. I will be making an announcement on this matter to the Parliament before it rises at the end of this week. In the meantime, I assure the honourable member that the Government has been most concerned to ensure that an independent inquiry is conducted. The result of that inquiry will be given to the Government in due course.
21 May 1980-Hansard page 2965-Question
DOMESTIC AIR FARES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport to the continued advocacy by West Australian members for the establishment of an independent inquiry into the structure of domestic air fares in Australia and ask, further to the question that was asked yesterday by the honourable member for Tangney, when the Minister will be able to inform the House of the terms of reference for such an inquiry and the personnel selected to undertake it?

—I have some good news for the honourable member for Tangney and the honourable member for Perth. Following my recent announcement that the Government had decided to establish an independent inquiry into the domestic air fares structure, I can now release further details. The chairman of this public inquiry will be Mr W. J. Holcroft, who has had a long association with the transport industry and with various government advisory bodies. Amongst other tasks, he has been chairman of the Transport Industries Advisory Council and the Manufacturing Industry Council. He will be assisted by Dr Harold Bell and Professor Warren Hogan. Dr Bell has had a distinguished career as an economist in the insurance industry and has also been associated with the transport industry. In particular, his role as a member of the Transport Industries Advisory Council, I am sure, will place him in good stead to understand the factors involved in the inquiry. He is also a Commissioner of the Australian National Railways. Professor Hogan of Sydney is of course a very well known Professor of Economics at Sydney University and a distinguished economist. He has also served on a number of important government advisory bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that the collective experience of these gentlemen will enable the inquiry to address itself adequately to what will be a very demanding task. I do not know whether I should bore the House with a recital of the terms of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman might ask to have them incorporated in Hansard.

—Yes, but I will try to summarise the principal points, for the benefit of those who might not read Hansard. The terms of reference provide for the examination of air fares on the trunk and regional routes operated by the two major domestic airlines, namely Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. The inquiry will also look at the way in which fares are set on the individual routes of the national network by the use of an air fare formula.
—Did you write this yourself?
—I did, but I did not type it.

—I rise on a point of order. This is a very important issue that is worthy of special time being devoted to it, following the making of a proper statement. It is an abuse of Question Time to arrange a whitewash such as the Minister is trying to indulge in now. I ask that the Minister make a statement to the House on the subject and allow debate upon it.

—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Shortland well knows that. I would have thought, out of courtesy to the Minister and out of deference to the importance of the inquiry, that honourable members on the Opposition benches would remain silent and that honourable members on the Government side also would remain silent.

—I rise on a point of order. Equal noise is coming from the other side of the chamber, but your constant reference is to the Opposition. Please be reasonable and name the other side, not just this side.

—The honourable member for Shortland obviously did not hear me reprimand honourable members on the Government side immediately after reprimanding honourable members on the Opposition side. The Minister will now be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The existing and alternative pricing policies and the degree of cross-subsidisation will also be examined. In this manner the question of equity between the long and the short haul fares will be addressed. As the House will be aware, this issue has been a matter of particular concern for Western Australian members of Parliament. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the terms of reference of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
INDEPENDENT PUBLIC INQUIRY INTODOMESTIC AIR FARES TERMS OF REFERENCE

1. The inquiry is to examine air fares on the trunk routes and regional routes operated by the two major domestic airlines, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, with special reference to the way in which fares are set on individual routes in the national network by use of an air fare formula.
2. In respect of these routes the inquiry should report, and make recommendations as appropriate, on
(i) costs, revenues and load factors
(ii) existing and alternative pricing policies
(iii) the degree of cross-subsidisation.
3. The inquiry shall have regard to (i) the public interest
(ii) government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition
(iii) the effect of competition on fares
(iv) the Report of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee
(v) the desirability of a nationally consistent approach to setting first, economy and standard class fares
(vi) factors which affect operating costs on particular routes
(vii) the assignment of corporate overheads
(viii) operations of other airlines over routes referred to in (1)
(ix) other relevant factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government agreed to set up such an inquiry. I wish to read from a media release which I made on the issue. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry will examine air fares on the trunk routes and regional routes operated by the two major domestic airlines, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia.

The inquiry will also look at the way fares are set on individual routes in the national network by use of an air fare formula. Existing and alternative pricing policies and the degree of cross subsidisation will also be examined. Its investigations will be concentrated on the air fare formula used to determine Australia's domestic trunk route fares and whether this formula produces cost related fares.

The Government appointed three outstanding people of the highest calibre to undertake this inquiry, namely, Mr Warwick Holcroft, Professor Hogan and Dr Harold Bell. It was a logical progression from the 1978 domestic air transport policy review which initially identified substantial cross-subsidisation in the air fares system. That review also recommended the continuance of a two-airline system operating over the major trunk routes. It also recommended a new agreement to deregulate freight and to provide for a greater measure of competition within the system. The Government adopted the domestic air transport policy review recommendations and sought the rewriting of a new agreement along the lines recommended. As Minister for Transport, I have negotiated a new agreement on behalf of the Government.

The Holcroft inquiry undoubtedly builds on one area of DATPR. It is untrue to say that I have not supported the inquiry. Indeed, I have been one of its strongest advocates. There is not the slightest doubt that the Department under my control provided the inquiry with as much information and material as it was able to do. I offered the complete co-operation of my Department, and I am convinced that it did fulfil its obligations and responsibilities. My officers refute the allegation made by the honourable gentleman that last night officers told a gathering of back benchers that my office conveyed to the Department that there was no hurry to provide information. The departmental report was delivered to the inquiry on 10 December. Admittedly, this was later than we all would have desired. However, I am informed that considerable material was made available to the inquiry prior to the report.

So far as TAA is concerned, I assured the committee that TAA would co-operate with the inquiry. That TAA's submission to the Inquiry was so extensive bears out its co-operation. With respect to the Bureau of Transport Economics, Mr Holcroft's letter of 1 December was the first expression of dissatisfaction in that he noted that the BTE had not lodged its submission. I would like to make two points in respect of that comment. Firstly, the BTE had never made a formal commitment to provide a submission to the inquiry. The executive members of the BTE in fact decided in September not to proceed with a submission. Secondly, the BTE, like the Department of Transport, had extensive discussions with the inquiry and its staff. Indeed, I would also like to mention that two BTE officers were seconded to the inquiry research staff.

However, it was never the Government's intention for the inquiry to be a full-scale review of the regulation of domestic civil aviation. In all my statements on behalf of the Government I have made that point clear. The Government reaffirmed its commitment to a two-airline policy and repeated its position clearly prior to the election. In a speech at the opening of the Skywest Air Services Pty Ltd administrative building in Perth on 28 July I stated:

Implementation of these domestic air transport policy review recommendations has had to await the outcome of extensive negotiations on a new airlines agreement. Discussions with the major airlines on issues related to the agreement are completed. I therefore hope to be in a position to make an announcement on domestic air transport policy shortly.

Subsequently some further issues were raised and the legal drafting of the document took some time to finalise. On two occasions I stressed to the Holcroft committee that the real purpose of the inquiry was to inquire into the ways in which air fares are set on individual routes and the national network by the use of an air fare formula. At no time have I misled the Parliament or anyone else on the Government's intentions. The Holcroft inquiry chose to interpret the terms of reference in its own manner, and that was its prerogative.

In regard to the date on which it was to report, I was never explicit about the duration of the inquiry in my discussions with members of the inquiry. Let me repeat: It was originally expected that the inquiry would report by January 1981. There were indications, as time went on, that additional time would, in the committee's view, be required. It was quite clear that Mr Holcroft understood that the original expectation was for the inquiry to finalise its report by January 1981, and that is borne out by his letter dated 14 November.

I would also like to mention that it is quite clear from the evidence given at Estimates committees and from departmental understandings that it was originally expected that the reporting date would be January 1981. Indeed, a letter from the Acting Prime Minister on 9 December confirms this position, and I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Prime Minister Canberra 9 December 1980 My dear Minister, I refer to your letter of 27 November 1980 relating to the Holcroft Inquiry request for an extension of time for the completion of its report.

I would emphasise the importance of the inquiry completing its report by the end of January 1981. In your letter of 27 November 1980 to Mr Holcroft you informed him of the substantial and pressing reasons for completion of the report by this date.
The Government would be most concerned if the target date were not met.

Furthermore, you will recall that it was originally envisaged that six months would provide sufficient time for completion of the Inquiry report; by the end of January 1981 eight months will have elapsed since the establishment of the Inquiry.
I trust you will ensure that the Inquiry complies with Cabinet's decision on this matter.
Yours sincerely,
DOUG ANTHONY
(Malcolm Fraser) The Hon. Ralph J. Hunt, M.P.,
Minister for Transport,
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just read from the second last paragraph of this letter which is dated 9 December 1980. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, you will recall that it was originally envisaged that six months would provide sufficient time for completion of the Inquiry report; by the end of January 1981 eight months will have elapsed since the establishment of the Inquiry.

The letter is there for all to see. I also refer to the statement made by the honourable member for Shortland in this Parliament on 11 September 1980. On page 1176 of Hansard he is reported as saying:
Predictably the inquiry, sham that it is, is not expected to report before February 1981 at the earliest-well after the coming election.

The honourable gentleman did not expect the committee to report before February 1981. Yet he has brought forward this matter today for discussion. Let the honourable gentleman answer that in his own way.

As time progressed it became apparent to the committee that more time would be needed. Ultimately Mr Holcroft and his committee met me on 13 November, when the position was explained. As I said earlier, this was confirmed in the letter dated 14 November. I assured Mr Holcroft that I would put the request before the Government. The Government considered the request, but because of its desire to receive the inquiry's report before legislation to approve the new airlines agreement was introduced into the Parliament this session I conveyed to the inquiry by letter dated 27 November the Government's wish that the inquiry report at the end of January. The rest is history.
I refer to another contentious section of the transmittal letter, in which Mr Holcroft says:

It is also appropriate to record that the members of the inquiry felt in some degree misplaced when learning on 9 September that they had been proceeding with an inquiry requiring them to have regard, inter alia, to 'Government domestic aviation policy . . . in ignorance of the fact that the Government was meanwhile negotiating a new ten-year two airlines agreement.

On no fewer than five occasions I informed this House that I was negotiating a new airlines agreement on behalf of the Government with TAA and Ansett. I am at a loss to know why the inquiry members were so surprised. It was never the Government's intention to break off negotiations in respect of the two-airline agreement while the Holcroft inquiry was being undertaken. As far as the Government was concerned, the two-airline policy had been reaffirmed and was the cornerstone of our domestic aviation policy which should have been taken into account in the course of the inquiry.

Let me conclude by saying that the Holcroft committee is to be commended on the report it has produced. It is a most valuable report and will be of immense value to the Government, the Parliament and the public. On behalf of the Government, I thank the committee members for their tireless efforts and for meeting the Government's reporting requirements. Secondly, at no time have I undertaken any action, either in regard to the Holcroft inquiry or the negotiations for the new airlines agreement, that did not have the authority of Cabinet or the Government. (Extension of time granted). I thank the House. I would like to say one final word about the Australian Labor Party and its shadow Minister for Transport. To my knowledge, the Australian Labor Party in recent times has refrained from uttering any coherent domestic aviation policy. Does it still adhere to the nationalisation of the aviation industry with one government-owned airline? To describe the Opposition's policy as ad hoc would be to pay it a supreme compliment. All that the honourable member for Shortland does is yap and yap behind my heels like a pomeranian pup. The Australian Labor Party has not put forward a coherent domestic aviation policy since the 1940s, when it attempted to nationalise or socialise the industry.

I refute the serious allegations made against me. In no way do I criticise the attempt of those involved on the Holcroft inquiry to come to grips with a very complex and important issue relating to the setting of air fares. The inquiry complements the domestic air transport policy review and will be of value in assisting the Government in determining future fare setting arrangements. The Government will give urgent consideration to its 36 recommendations and will give proper regard and consideration to the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable gentleman should wait until the end of the debate to make any personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take great delight in seconding the motion. I do so having heard the pathetic defence of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), a defence which told us absolutely nothing. All he did was continue his tirade of abuse against the members of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. He continued to mislead the House about its reporting schedule. He continued to distort the purposes of the inquiry and its terms of reference. Significantly, he told us that, if he went, he would take a few of his colleagues with him. He said it was the Cabinet that was responsible and he was just the mug out front. We might have guessed that. In the transport industry the stakes are enormous and who would leave it to poor old ineffectual Ralph Hunt to destroy the results of years of careful nurturing by the political heavies of this Government? Then there was the other problem of how to carve up the bribes from Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. That could not be left to Ralph Hunt and the National Country Party alone--
— Order! The honourable member shall refer to the Minister by his title.

—The carve-up of the bribes from ATI could not be left to the Minister for Transport. His party, the National Country Party, could not have it all. After all, the Liberals have done their bit in the past and continue to do so at present. So, at a time when the two-airline agreement was up for grabs, both parties saw a great opportunity to extract the price of their compliance. That is why the Government had publicly to commit itself before the last general election to the then secret agreement. You will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that a Bill relating to the deal was brought in during the dying hours of the last Parliament. Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abels were able to reciprocate due to the fact that the Bill was introduced into the Parliament before the election. They had time to reciprocate and the coffers of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party were topped up in grateful acknowledgment of the obedience of their political slaves. That all had to be done before the election.

SPEECH.PARA: All would have been well had it not been for the fact that Holcroft, Hogan and Bell were still on the loose. Everybody had forgotten that. They were honourable men and they had been given a job to do and were setting about their task of doing it. Apart from that, the Western Australian Liberals were getting jumpy. They knew that they could not survive the next election if they continued to support the two-airline agreement and the raw deal it had meant for Western Australian travellers over many years. They could not continue to support the high air fares policy of this Government and not be exposed as the charlatans I suspect they are. That is when the Government panicked and when the whole deal looked like coming unstuck. That is when, in November last year, a compromise was reached. A meeting took place between the Minister for Transport, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Liberals from Western Australia. That compromise and that meeting have been attested to not only by the Minister but also in recent days by the Western Australian Liberals who attended that meeting. It is strange to see how they remain gutlessly mute during this debate. They said that they would review their attitude to the two-airline agreement only if the Government tabled the Holcroft report before debating the legislation to ratify the two-airline agreement.

But wait; there was still another problem. It all had to be done before the middle of this year in order that the legislation could go through before those unreliable Australian Democrats took their place in the Senate. That is when the directive went out to Holcroft. That is when the Prime Minister ordered the Minister for Transport to direct the Holcroft committee to have its report in by 31 January. No amount of dissembling by the Minister for Transport can disguise the fact that he led the committee to believe that it had until mid-1981 to report. Mr Holcroft confirmed this fact to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) again this morning. The Minister for Transport can continue to disparage Mr Holcroft and his colleagues. He can continue to dredge up semi-relevant documents to confound us, but the simple unanswered testimony remains. From the 3 June meeting in the Minister's office, Holcroft and his colleagues believed-there is no question about this-that they had until the middle of this year to complete their report.

The very great shame, the eternal shame, is that this Minister has not had the courage, or apparently the capacity, to tell the truth and to reveal the details of this whole messy business. He does not seem to realise that the game is up. He may well survive as Minister for Transport today but as a Minister he is finished. Through his incompetence he has imperilled the most cherished jewel in the political fund-raising of conservative parties in this country. He has exposed and put at risk the special relationship, the intricate corruption, that has underpinned the dealings between this Government, the Liberals and the National Country Party, and Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. He will not be forgiven for that. In a sense, we are indebted to him for his incompetence because it is his incompetence which has revealed more of the details of this special relationship, this corruption, than we knew of already. We are even more indebted to the Holcroft committee for the way in which it revealed the situation and the way in which it has rammed it home to the people of Australia. It is as a result of that committee's report that this Minister has had to resort to the tactic which is usually adopted by people on that side of the House, people of his party and the Liberal Party, when they prevaricate, dissemble, and defame-in brief, to say anything other than the truth.

What has the Holcroft committee revealed which is so damaging and so unanswerable? What is it that this Minister will not face up to? What is it that this Minister has to continue to prevaricate about? What is it that has led this Minister to continue to defame and to misrepresent three honourable and honest men? First, the report in total is a colossal indictment of this Minister's trustworthiness and his reliability. Secondly, it reveals his utter ignorance of the issues for which he has ministerial responsibility. Let me deal with a few of these.

He said it was not the Committee's job to consider the two-airline agreement. From that we can only conclude that he has not even read the terms of reference. Honourable members will realise that the terms of reference were not written by him in the first instance; they were written by a few Western Australian Liberals who were able to convince him, or bully him, into setting up this inquiry in the first instance. I refer to a couple of the terms of reference. The second term of reference, referring to trunk routes, states:
In respect of these routes the Inquiry should report, and make recommendations as appropriate, on:
amongst other things:
(ii) existing and alternative pricing policies including special discount arrangements
Further, the third term of reference states:
The Inquiry shall have regard to:
(ii) government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition,
(iii) the effect of competition on fares,

I really ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the Minister how on earth-or anywhere else for that matter-can the committee begin to consider those matters without first considering the matter of the two-airline agreement. The two-airline agreement is the antithesis of competition. It has prevented competition in this industry for as long as it has existed. Yet at the same time as the Minister said that it was not the job of the committee to consider the two-airline agreement, the Government asked the Committee to consider the objective of increasing competition. It also asked the committee to consider the effect of competition on fares. It is an inescapable fact that one cannot consider the matter of competition, ways of extending competition and the effect of competition on fares, without at the same time considering the effect of the two-airline agreement on the whole matter of competition and fares.

If that is not enough to convince us that the Minister is prevaricating and dissembling on this matter, we need only to look at his statement of 26 November, when he announced the truncation of the inquiry and the fact that the committee had to report by 31 January. In one paragraph he stated:

The Government intends to table the Holcroft report before proceeding to introduce legislation to ratify a new agreement with the airlines. Therefore Parliament will have the benefit of that report before debating the legislation.

That lets the cat out of the bag. If the Holcroft report has nothing to do with the two-airline agreement, why would we want to have it before debating the legislation? It is quite clear, of course, that that paragraph had to go into the Minister's Press statement because it was the basis on which he was able to buy off the opposition, at least temporarily, of the Western Australian Liberals. They were able to insist that the Holcroft committee's report had to be available to them and the Parliament before they would guarantee to vote for the two-airline agreement and the legislation which was to ratify it. But, in doing so, the Minister has given the game away. He has known at all times that the report of the Holcroft committee is entirely germane to the whole question of the two-airline policy. What he is now attempting to do in abusing the committee for not understanding that is a total insult to the intelligence of those three honourable men.

The point is that after the committee had been appointed and while it was doing its work the agreement was secretly concluded without the knowledge of the Parliament or the public. It was secretly concluded before the election in order to satisfy Ansett in relation to the undertakings which the Government had given to it in return for its political donations. It also had to be concluded secretly at that time to strengthen Ansett's hand before the inquiry. Ansett had not wanted the inquiry in the first place. It always considered it to be irrelevant. The signing of the new two-airline agreement provided immunity for Ansett in relation to the meddlesome interference of the committee. When the committee sought to get Ansett before it to answer questions Ansett was able to say smugly that the questions were irrelevant because they had already been dealt with by the two-airline agreement which had been secretly concluded between the Government and Ansett Transport Industries. It also meant that the committee was prevented from examining some of the very sensitive areas.

To name just one, I refer to the fact that a number of submissions before the committee, including my own, raised the question of the use of the excess capacity of the planes of Qantas Airways Ltd travelling across the continent. Of course, the use of that excess capacity would mean lower air fares for people travelling to and from Western Australia. Now, as a result of the new two-airline agreement, Ansett has an effective veto to prevent the use of that excess capacity of Qantas or any other international carrier. The committee was not able to make recommendations or to consider that very important question which would have resolved the problem of air fares to Western Australia if it had been implemented. It had already been recommended to the Government by a former non-public inquiry. The simple manoeuvre of allowing Qantas to use its excess capacity would have cut by half the fares between Perth and Sydney or Melbourne. Yet this committee, which had the express task of looking at air fares, particularly the problems on the longer routes, was prevented from looking at that simple manoeuvre. The Minister also misled the committee about the co-operation of the Department of Transport, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett. I refer to the letter of transmission from the committee. It states:

In your initial meeting with us in June 1980, you emphasised that you had been assured by both airlines that the inquiry could expect to receive their full and willing co-operation and that the same could be expected from your own Department. In the event TAA honoured its undertaking. The contribution from Ansett, however, proved far from spontaneous and the delay in settling the basis of agreement to supply information hampered the Inquiry's operation.

So much for Ansett's co-operation and the assurance of the Minister in relation to that co-operation! The Department of Transport did not make its submission until six weeks before the committee's report was due; that is, six months after the co-operation had been promised by the Minister. In the event, the Bureau of Transport Economics did not submit one at all. In answer to the Leader of the Opposition on 3 March the Minister said that the Bureau of Transport Economics did not wish to make a submission. Who is running the Minister's Department? He promised the Department's co-operation. He should have insisted on a submission from the Bureau of Transport Economics as well as from the Department. The Minister says this matter is trivial. He says that the inquiry should have been able to proceed without that information. Yet the airline industry is the most regulated, secretive and arrogant industry in Australia. It has always operated as a cosy and exclusive club. Of course the committee could not proceed without the information which only the Department and the airlines had. By the simple manoeuvre of refusing to honour his assurance the Minister was able to frustrate and, in the end, scuttle this very important inquiry. The real reason for not wanting to disclose all the information the Department had was that the Department and the Minister realised that they had utterly failed to honour their public trust in failing to protect the interests of the travelling public and has failed to ensure that they got a fair deal from this duopolistic-virtually monopolistic-industry. This industry has felt free to exort the travelling public for years. This Department and this Minister were not going to see that little arrangement exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion of censure of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) was launched earlier today by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris). During his address we heard words such as disreputable, disgraceful, shameful, dummies, yes-man, defaming, denigrating and contemptible. Those of us who have shared this Parliament with the honourable member for Shortland for a number of years will know he has always made up for lack of argument with colourful words. Today he tried to make up not only for lack of argument but also for lack of stature in the Parliament with colourful words of abuse. All I can say about the effort of the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) to make a contribution to this debate is that if he is not careful he will very quickly follow the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) and be downgraded. Worse still, he will follow the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Innes) and be sent to the back benches.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition was reading an old Hansard for the whole of the honourable member's speech and the alternative leader of the Labor Party was yawning his head off, so there is not much of a future for the honourable member for Fremantle. Let us look at the words of the censure motion. The first part states:

. . . this House censures the Minister for Transport for his failure to fulfil his Ministerial duties by failing to provide essential information and support to the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares . . .

I thought the Minister answered that allegation perfectly well in his speech and I will not bother to repeat the information he gave. I think that the second part of the censure motion is more germane to this debate. It states:
. . . and further by repeatedly misleading the Parliament and the public in relation to the purposes and conduct of the Inquiry.
What were the purposes and conduct of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares? I think the purposes are well set out in the terms of reference, which commence by stating:
The Inquiry is to examine air fares . . .
There is nothing ambiguous about that. I would have thought that the three members of the committee of inquiry would have had no difficulty understanding that. The terms of reference continue:

. . . on the trunk routes and regional routes operated by the two major domestic airlines . . . with special reference to the way in which fares are set on individual routes in the national network by use of an air fare formula.

That is perfectly plain. The second paragraph relates to the first and refers only to air fares. There is no mention of anything else. The Labor Party turns its attention very much to what comes out of the third paragraph, which states:
The Inquiry shall have regard to:
(i) the public interest,
(ii) government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition,
(iii) the effect of competition on fares-
This is the nub of the matter-
(iv) the report of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee.

I would have thought that the secretariat, if not the committee of inquiry itself, and certainly the honourable member for Shortland-certainly not the honourable member for Fremantle; he would not know enough about it-would have understood that the reference to the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee was a direct reference to government policy. As a result of that committee's report the Government restated its intention to continue the two-airline policy. That point leads me directly to what the Opposition is claiming as the Minister's misleading the Parliament as to purpose. The Opposition bases its charge on that point alone and I am staggered that it has not properly thought through what the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee recommended and what was publicly stated, when I was Minister for Transport, following the tabling of its report.

The history of the matter is that subsequent to March 1978, when that report was tabled, there was a series of Press statements, speeches, articles and questions relating to the two-airline policy. On 20 December 1979 the Minister issued a Press release on the subject. On 22 January 1980 an article appeared in the Bulletin. On 5 March 1980 a question was asked on the subject. On 17 March 1980 a Press release was issued. On 27 March 1980, during the second reading debate on the Airline Equipment Loan Guarantee Bill another statement was made. On 14 and 15 May 1980 further questions were answered and on 18 September 1980 another speech was made.
