For the Holcroft committee to suggest that it did not know that the Government had a firm policy in respect of the continuance of the two-airline policy is quite extraordinary. The most charitable conclusion one can reach is that there has been a failure on the part of the secretariat to do its homework and a failure by the committee of inquiry itself to attend to the terms of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, blame the public servants again.
—The honourable member for Wills has come into the debate. He has been breaking his neck to get in an interjection. Let me recognise it. It is probably the first that the man has made.
—How about answering it.

—The fact is that if the committee of inquiry read the terms of reference properly it failed in its duty to understand what those terms meant. This means that the Labor Party, in accusing the Minister of misleading the Parliament, has not understood the question at all. Let me turn now to the next matter of controversy, the date of completion. It is hard to follow why this should have been an issue in this debate. Even the honourable member for Shortland knew that the report was to be completed by January or February 1981 because as, reported in the Hansard on September 11 1980, and as the Minister pointed out this morning, the honourable member said:

SPEECH.PARA: Predictably the inquiry, sham that it is, is not expected to report before February 1981 at the earliest, well after the coming election.

He recognised quite clearly that the report was to be concluded. He is not too bright and if he recognised it surely the members of the committee ought to have known about it themselves. There is no doubt that the committee did know; that is unquestioned. The first paragraph of Mr Holcroft's letter to the Minister of 14 November states:
In recent discussions I referred to the fact that the inquiry is unlikely to complete its task by the original reporting date indicated, January 1981.

So it is quite clear that the committee was aware of the completion date. It had conversations with the Minister also about it and the Minister expressed some sympathy for their problem. He took that problem to the Government but the Government, for broader reasons that I will come to, decided that the report ought to be completed on the initial date so that it could be considered in the debate on the two-airline policy. Another question emerges at this point. Apparently-this is a serious matter-all the correspondence relating to the exchange between Mr Holcroft and the Minister on this matter, with the exception of this letter, was included in the appendix to the report. I refer to the letter in which it was recognised by Mr Holcroft that the original reporting date was to be January 1981. That raises a very serious question that the committee itself ought to answer. On that point its integrity is somewhat under challenge. Nobody has greater respect for the members of that committee than I do. Nobody has worked more closely with its chairman. I ask the chairman of that committee publicly to state why the letter had not been included in the report. I thought it appropriate that it should have been. It was not until the Minister himself tabled the letter that the fact was brought out that the chairman had known of the completion date for the inquiry. The last question to be answered is why the Minister confirmed that he wanted the report concluded on time. When Mr Holcroft wrote seeking the extension, the Minister promptly referred it to the Government. Thus it was the Government, not the Minister, which decided that the report should be available for the debate on the new two-airline agreement when it commenced in Parliament. That is quite appropriate. One can imagine the Opposition yowling its head off were that report not to be available when the Government brought the two-airline agreement before the Parliament. Just imagine the furore that the Opposition would have created, with the Holcroft inquiry proceeding and the Opposition not having the benefit of that report during the debate. That is the complete opposite of what the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has said. It was quite appropriate that it should be here so that Parliament could consider both aspects of the aviation policy-the continuance of the two-airline policy which followed the domestic air transport review and the question of air fares which flowed out of the Holcroft inquiry.

One thing that has been common to aviation debates in this place for a long time is the blinkered view that the Opposition always takes of Ansett Airlines. Every Labor speech that has been made in this Parliament during the 20 years for which I have been here has attacked Ansett Airlines. Sir Reginald Ansett used to cop it in speech after speech from the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones). It was a tiresome business. The honourable member for Newcastle always threatened that when Labor got into government it would dismantle Ansett, send it broke or do something to it. Of course, the honourable member failed in his objective. Ansett is carrying on as strongly as ever. Not only Sir Reginald Ansett has been attacked. It has been transferred to the new proprietors, in the person of Sir Peter Abeles. The speech of the honourable member for Shortland was a bitter attack upon Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Rupert Murdoch. The same sort of difficulty is experienced by the new management in dealing with the Labor Party which has a blinkered view of free enterprise. It is scared stiff that private enterprise might succeed; that the people of Australia will see that socialism cannot provide the answers; that free enterprise can provide both the answers and the jobs.

In the five years during which the honourable member for Shortland has been leading for the Opposition in aviation debates in this Parliament he has failed to produce a comprehensive and cohesive platform for aviation. I refer to the Australian Labor Party's platform, constitution and rules. We ought to have the benefit of that document's being tabled so we can see how much aviation is mentioned in it. Under the reference to transport the only relevant word is the word 'air'. It refers to 'road, air and water'. That is the totality of Labor's policy on aviation. It comes here bereft of policies and attacks a Minister who has done a genuine job, whose integrity and honesty since he has been in Parliament have never been in doubt. The best that Labor can do is move a censure motion of such a poor nature as this. I move:
That the question be now put.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (CIVIL LIABILITY) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Commonwealth Government has, over the years, pursued policies that are aimed at protecting the Australian coastline. In keeping with that history, I am now introducing a package of legislation entitled 'Protection of the Sea'. The package represents a major advance in marine pollution prevention and combat in Australia. These matters have been the subject of detailed discussion with the States in the Marine and Ports Council and also with industry. Australia has been participating for more than 30 years in international organisations that develop international conventions on maritime matters. Australia has a good record in implementing these international agreements after they come into force. Australia as an island continent has a long coastline that, in places, is environmentally extremely sensitive and I believe it is now opportune to introduce legislation to augment the existing law.

The 'Protection of the Sea' legislation package contains the following Bills: Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill, Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill, Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill, Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill, Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill and Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill.

The Understandings on Offshore Matters reached at the Premiers Conference in June 1979 provide for Commonwealth legislation on certain matters relating to ship-sourced marine pollution. The six Bills accord with the Understandings. The Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill will implement the provisions of the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969 and the 1976 Protocol to that Convention. The Convention requires ships carrying more than 2,000 tons of oil in bulk as cargo to maintain insurance to cover liability for pollution damage. The Convention and the Bill provide for ship owners to limit their liability to an amount determined by the size of the ship. The maximum level of compensation available under the provisions of the Convention is in excess of $A14.9m but this amount relates to tankers with a register tonnage of more than 105,000 tons. No tankers of that size trade to Australia. The maximum liability for an incident involving the largest tanker in the Australian fleet would approximate $A7.8m. The Bill preserves the operation of State and Territory laws that give effect to Convention requirements.

I think it is appropriate to outline the other measures that are envisaged by the 'Protection of the Sea' legislation package so that honourable members will be aware of the interrelationship of the various Bills. The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill will implement the provisions of the 1969 International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties. The Bill will also implement the provisions of the 1973 Protocol to that Convention. Where pollution or a threat of a pollution incident exists the Bill empowers the Minister to take any appropriate action on the high seas or in territorial waters in regard to Australian or foreign ships. I, as Minister, will be required to have regard to Convention constraints which are incorporated in the Bill in using this power. The Bill preserves the operation of State and Territory legislation.

Since 1970, Part VIIA of the Navigation Act 1912 has included provisions based on the Civil Liability and Intervention Conventions. The Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill will repeal Part VIIA of the Navigation Act so that the Bills I have just outlined can give full effect to the provisions of the respective Conventions. Part VIIA of the Navigation Act currently contains intervention powers which are broader than the powers conferred by the Convention or Protocol. Australia has always asserted that customary international law provides a nation with powers to protect its territory and coastal sea. The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill will continue to apply these provisions in Australian pollution legislation.

The Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill will repeal and replace the Pollution of the Sea by Oil Act 1960. That Act gives effect to the provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil. The new Bill picks up the provisions of the 1960 Act and, in addition, will implement the requirements of the two 1971 Amendments to the Convention. The first amendment will provide increased protection to the Great Barrier Reef by prohibiting the operational discharge of oil within or near the reef by redefining the Convention term 'nearest land'. The new arrangement will ensure that oil is not discharged within 50 miles of the outer edge of the Great Barrier Reef. The second 1971 amendment to the 1954 Convention imposed limits on the size and location of cargo tanks in tankers. The new Bill applies these provisions to Australian ships.

The Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill repeals Part VIIA of the Navigation Act 1912, as I mentioned earlier. It also inserts a new Division 12 in Part IV of the Navigation Act. The new Division imposes requirements on tanker owners and masters in relation to survey, certification and production of certificates. These provisions are included in the Navigation Act to maintain the various survey and construction requirements in one piece of legislation. In addition, I, as Minister, will have power to direct foreign tankers to take certain action while the tanker is within the Australian jurisdiction. These powers will be exercised only insofar as it is necessary to do so to protect the environment.

The remaining Bills in the package are the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill and the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill. These Bills respectively repeal and replace the Pollution of the Sea by Oil (Shipping Levy) Act 1972 and the Pollution of the Sea by Oil (Shipping Levy Collection) Act 1972. The new Bills maintain all the provisions of the existing Acts, but change the titles of the legislation to maintain uniformity with the remainder of the legislation package.

The Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill includes a new provision to ensure that the minimum amount of levy able to be collected will be maintained at an economic level. In addition, the definition of oil in the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill has been extended to include a wider range of hydrocarbon pollutants. That establishes the relationship of this Bill to the other Bills in the package. I commend the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill to honourable members.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hodgman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967. The Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967 established an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of the encouragement of travel to and within Australia by people from other countries. The act was assented to on 23 May 1967. The principal Act has been amended on three occasions to date; namely, in December 1973 by the Statute Law Revision Act 1973; in October 1974 by the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1974; and in June 1978 by the Administrative Changes (Consequential Provisions) Act of 1978. The 1974 amendments allowed the Australian Tourist Commission to engage in domestic tourism promotion and extended the membership of the Commission from seven to nine. The amendments to the Act which I now propose have three main purposes; namely, to increase the total number of commissioners from nine to 10; to increase the number of State and Territory representatives on the Commission from two to three; and to bring the financial provisions of the Act into line with legislation covering comparable statutory authorities.
Increase in number of commissioners

In discussing the proposed amendments I turn firstly to the need to increase the membership of the Commission to enable Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory representation on the Australian Tourist Commission on the same basis as the States. At its meeting in August 1979 the Tourist Ministers Council, a body comprising the Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers having responsibility for tourism matters, agreed that the Northern Territory should be accorded membership of the ATC through incorporation into an existing rotational system of representation. This decision was made in the light of progress in the Constitutional development of the Territory. In its March 1980 report on Tourism in the Australian Capital Territory, the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory recommended:

The Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967 be amended to allow the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory to be represented on the Australian Tourist Commission on the same basis as the States.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Right Honourable Sir Phillip Lynch, and the former Minister for the Capital Territory, the Honourable R. J. Ellicott, raised the question of Commission membership by the Australian Capital Territory at the April 1980 meeting of the Tourist Ministers Council. The Council agreed to the proposal subject to the number of State and Territory representatives being increased from two to three. The Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory are important tourist destinations with tourism making a significant contribution to the economies of these areas. Some two million people visited the Australian Capital Territory last year. It is logical, therefore, that each Territory should be able to take its turn along with the States in providing membership of the national body concerned with the promotion of tourism.
State and Territory representatives

Against this background and in recognition of the wishes of the Tourist Ministers Council, the amending legislation provides for the increase in total membership of the Commission from nine to 10, thereby allowing three members to be persons nominated by the States and Territories. Consequent upon the increase in total membership of the Commission, the Bill provides for the increase in the number of members required for a quorum from five to six. Needless to say the Bill preserves the position of existing commissioners.
Financial and other provisions

Amendments to financial and other provisions of the principal Act, aim to bring the Act into line with legislation covering comparable statutory authorities and incorporate further consequential amendments as necessary to accommodate these changes. Clause 4-removes reference to the redundant Superannuation Act 1922. Clauses 5 and 6 bring the provisions of the Act into line with recommendations of the Bowen Committee relating to removal of members and disclosure of interests by members. Clause 8 brings the financial provisions of the Act into line with legislation covering comparable statutory authorities. Clause 9 repeals section 28 of the principal Act, which relates to the application to the Officers' Rights Declaration Act, which will become redundant on the proclamation of the Public Service Amendment Act 1978. Clause 10 repeals reference to section 29 of the principal Act, concerning reports, which will become redundant on the twenty-eighth day after the day on which the Act receives royal assent. Provisions concerning reports are embodied in Part V-Finance of the amendment Act 1981. Clause 11 takes account of formal amendments to the principal Act as scheduled. Clause 12 clarifies the commission's powers to function pending the enactment and proclamation of the amending legislation.

I am sure that the Territories will wish to see the way cleared as soon as possible for the new system of representation, under which they will in due course enjoy representation on the same basis as the States. It was with this in mind that the Government accorded a high priority to this legislation. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Newman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The continuing policy of the Government is to strengthen the parliamentary system and to enable Parliament adequately to review the activities of government administration. In recent years the Government has taken a number of major steps in this area. These include the establishment of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure to allow for closer examination of the effectiveness and economy of public expenditure in the delivery of Government policy, and the expansion of the Public Accounts Committee's charter to bring within its purview the accounts of statutory authorities and other government bodies. The Bill now before honourable members provides a similar expansion to the role of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

The current Public Works Committee Act 1969, provides as a general rule that a public work to be undertaken within Australia or an external Territory for a Commonwealth department and estimated to cost more than $2m, shall not be commenced unless it has been considered by the Committee. The major thrust of this Bill is to bring the works of statutory authorities, instrumentalities and other bodies as well as overseas works, under the purview of the Public Works Committee.

Some authorities and types of works will continue to be exempt from the Act because of their special nature. The works of the Northern Territory Government and the Administration of Norfolk Island are exempted because of the relationship between the administrations and the Commonwealth, while Commonwealth works in these territories will continue to be subject to Public Works Committee review-these arrangements are parallel to provisions in the Public Accounts Committee Act. Similarly the works of bodies established jointly by the Commonwealth with the States or other countries are exempted, as are overseas aid works because of their bilateral nature.

The works of the tertiary education institutions in the Australian Capital Territory are already subject to careful examination by the Tertiary Education Commission. These works are therefore exempted to avoid duplication. The National Capital Development Commission and the Parliament House Construction Authority are also exempted because of their specific legislation and functions.

It is recognised by the Government that certain authorities which trade, or which provide services and compete with the private sector, require considerable autonomy and flexibility. In some cases their investment proposals and financial and consortium arrangements should not reasonably be subject to an external review. The Bill therefore enables regulations to be made to exempt such authorities from the Act. It should be noted that provision is made for specific works of authorities which are not subject to the Act to be declared examinable by the Committee.

The Bill contains a number of other amendments to improve the workings of the Committee. The Committee is being given the discretionary power to conduct inquiries in private, and in respect of urban land development works the Committee may report without an inquiry. Repetitive type works may also be exempted from review following agreement with the Committee. With regard to the Committee's inquiries into overseas works, the Government is mindful of the legal and constitutional difficulties if the Committee were to conduct inquiries and take evidence in overseas countries. The Bill therefore limits the Committee's inquiries into these works to the consideration of plans, models and statements placed before it, and to the taking of evidence from people already in Australia.

The Government has decided to allow a period of 12 months to elapse after the Bill's date of assent before the works of authorities become subject to the Act. This is in recognition of the need to allow for the alterations to lead times and work loads involved in allowing for Public Works Committee review. The Public Works Committee had requested that the Act be changed to enable the Committee to make random investigations of works costing less than $2m. The Government has rejected this request for two main reasons: Firstly, the responsibilities of the Committee have already been considerably widened by this Bill; and secondly, there would be severe administrative difficulties for Commonwealth departments and authorities.

It is understood that the Committee was particularly concerned with cases where major works costing over $2m have been phased in over several years with small projects, that is below $2m. These projects have either escaped Committee scrutiny, or if referred to the Committee, have been referred at a stage where proper Committee investigation has been pre-empted by the work already done. The Government expects works totalling over $2m to be subject to parliamentary scrutiny, and will do all it can to ensure that all works required to be examined by the Committee in accordance with the Public Works Committee Act will be so examined. I have assured the Committee that should it wish to examine any work below $2m the Government would treat any request sympathetically, and would facilitate Committee investigation of any such work.

The Committee has also sought authority to examine works proposals of the National Capital Development Commission. Clause 6B of the Bill enables the Government to prescribe certain works of the NCDC as public works for purposes of the Public Works Committee Act, and thus open for scrutiny by the Committee. However, it is anticipated that the bulk of works by NCDC will be exempted from examination by the Committee. The Government can assure the House and the Committee that should the Committee wish to examine any specific work of the NCDC, the Government would treat any request sympathetically and would facilitate Committee investigation of any such work. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill, the Bounty (Non-adjustable Wrenches) Bill 1981 and the Coal Excise Amendment Bill 1981 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each Bill at the conclusion of debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? As there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me say something about the timing of the debate on these three Bills because it is indicative of the way this House is being mismanaged at the present time. These three Bills were listed for debate last night. I was ready to open the debate on them. The Government Whip had asked me courteously how long I thought I would take with them. I was given every indication that the debate would be brought on at that time. Indeed, just as I was about to be called to speak on the legislation, without any warning being given to me and without the normal courtesies at all, the Minister in the chamber at the time moved that the House adjourn.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to refer to the timing of the debate, to the organisation of the House, and to record my objection to the way in which the House is being run and to the discourtesies which are being shown to the Opposition. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I know that the excuse will be given that the change was due to certain moves to suspend Standing Orders in order to bring on a debate relating to a censure motion of a Minister which had been due to come on for some time. The fact is that that censure motion eventually was brought on this morning. With the benefit of hindsight the Government surely recognised that the censure motion would be brought on eventually. If it had told the Opposition that the motion were to be brought on before the end of the week we would not have lost all the time we lost yesterday seeking to suspend Standing Orders so as to bring on that debate and we would not have had the sorts of discourtesies that we had in relation to debate on the legislation now before us. To add insult to injury I would at this stage merely mention that having moved the adjournment of the House 20 minutes or so early last night, the Government then gagged debate on the adjournment. I take this opportunity to object to that as well. No notice was given that it only wanted--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member has made his point. He should now address himself to the Bills.

—It is very much related to the timing of the debate of these Bills. I am glad that the point has been made to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I hope that the point has been made to others who are organising this House that if they treat the Opposition in this way then the time of this House will be wasted in divisions instead of being used in debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We eventually get around to these three Bills. On the one hand they are about what I call social democracy or democratic socialism-I do not care which of those two phrases is used-and they are also about industry policy. I want to say a little about each. I raise the subject of democratic socialism under the heading of these three Bills because the three measures are an example of the Fraser Government, in spite of its rhetoric, intervening in the market-place on behalf of the community. In spite of all the words that are spoken about free enterprise and the Government not intervening in the private sector, at least two of these three Bills add up to a sensible example of a government deciding that subsidies are required and that intervention is necessary. As a democratic socialist I applaud this. On behalf of the Opposition, I support the example of intervention in the market-place displayed in this piece of democratic socialism.

Just as we believe that there must be macro-economic management of the economy to minimise unemployment and inflation, and just as we believe that there must be action by government to provide those services on which the private sector defaults to such a large extent, such as moderate cost housing, health care and more satisfactory urban transportation, so too we believe as democratic socialists in democratic socialist measures such as this one-intervention to subsidise some area of production where otherwise jobs would be lost. True liberals indulge in rhetoric against this sort of approach. They hold that all possible economic decisions should be left to the freely competitive market. While we have a government of the political complexion of the present coalition government there is always a danger that its actions might live up to its words. The whole of the Australian motor vehicle manufacturing industry at the present time is in danger because the Industries Assistance Commission has issued a draft report making recommendations which follow the liberals' free market philosophies. While we have a non-Labour government in this country those IAC recommendations could be adopted with enormously adverse results for our country.

I do not want to give the impression that there is not a place for the market. Of course there is. It renders highly useful service. But in economics there are no absolutes, and we should not allow the rhetoric which suggests that there are absolutes. The only sensible policy towards the market is one of open-minded pragmatism. Where it works, the market should be allowed to work; where it does not work, there has to be intervention. I am very glad to note that the Government has forgotten its rhetoric, adopted a piece of democratic socialism, and intervened in the market as it has in two of the three Bills that are before the House.

The first of the Bills I will discuss is the Bounty (Non-adjustable Wrenches) Bill, which provides for temporarty assistance to be given to the industry producing non-adjustable wrenches or spanners in Australia. The local spanner industry essentially comprises Siddons Industries Ltd, an Australian company which manufactures spanners under the Sidchrome name at Heidelberg in Victoria. Siddons suffered a decline in market share from 25 per cent to 16 per cent between 1976-77 and 1979-80. The Temporary Assistance Authority recommended in August last year that a bounty of 11c per unit be paid to preserve the local industry. We in the Opposition consider that it would be lamentable if the capacity in Australia to produce such implements were lost. Up to 400 jobs depend on this industry, and the continued production of wrenches has some defence industry relevance. So there we have an intervention in the market-place which is of a democratic socialist nature and which, of course, we in the Labor Opposition can therefore support wholeheartedly.

The next Bill is the Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill, which extends the application of the bounty scheme for this industry until the end of 1981. It will then be replaced by new industry until the end of 1981. It will then be replaced by new bounty arrangements determined within the overall assistance measures being adopted for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. We in the Labor Opposition have supported the provision of this bounty in the past, and its benefits have been reflected in the strong growth of this section of the industry in recent years. Cotton mills in Australia are substantially located in decentralised areas and provide important employment opportunities in regional centres. Mr Deputy Speaker, you represent regional areas of Queensland and you will understand the great need for employment in regional towns like Maryborough. I am not sufficiently acquainted with your area to know whether you have any textile, clothing or footwear plants in your part of the world, but you will know, as I know, that there are many other regional centres of this nation where so many jobs are very dependent on this industry. There is great need for it to be supported, and in my case I am particularly pleased that that support comes in the form of a bounty to encourage scale economies and, we hope, re-industrialisation improving the productivity of an industry so that it becomes more competitive with imports. Accordingly, once again, this is a good democratic socialist piece of legislation, providing for intervention in the market-place. I readily support the Bill and so do my colleagues on this side of the House.

The Coal Excise Amendment Bill 1981 is in a slightly different category. It is essentially a machinery measure which extends from seven to 28 days the allowable period for making an entry in respect of excise duties imposed on coal. The previous period allowed has proven too short and is administratively difficult to comply with. We have no objection to the Bill. In fact, the Coal Excise Act goes back to 1949, when there was a Labor Government in this country. The purpose of the Act was to ensure that funds were received to pay for long service leave benefits granted to certain employees in the coal mining industry and for the Coal Research Trust Account. We understand from the research we have done that the collection of funds for these very valuable purposes was difficult because the Act laid down only seven days for that purpose. So, we are glad that in this third piece of legislation machinery is now being instituted which will enable those funds to be collected in 28 days instead of seven days. The Opposition has no objection to the third Bill.

I mentioned in my introduction that these three pieces of legislation were to do not only with democratic socialism, or social democracy, but also with industry policy. Just as I have talked about the former, I would now like to talk about the latter of which bounty Bills in particular are so much an essential part. Discussion of bounty assistance measures provides us with an opportunity to consider the overall effectiveness of bounties and other industry assistance measures. At the present time there is a growing concern in the community that, as a consequence of structural change pressures in the Australian economy, the manufacturing industries of this country will decline in importance. This is a real threat. Leading Government advisers such as the Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, are on public record as advocating a reduction in activity levels in a number of areas of manufacturing in order to facilitate development of mines, quarrries and capital-intensive mineral processing plants. John Stone is on record as suggesting that one of the offsetting features of policy against what will happen in the so-called resource based boom, is that there will be more imports into this country, which of course will be an enormous threat to our existing manufacturing industry, which manufactures products in competition with imports and seeks to get out into the export market and win new revenue through exports and new job opportunities for this country.

I say in passing that I find it a very sad feature of government in this country at the present time that a lot of the major speeches on economic policy in particular are being made by senior public servants. I think we should do more than just pay lip service to the Westminster system. We should see to it that the policy which is being mooted and discussed in the community is being discussed by Government Ministers or Opposition shadow Ministers, not by public servants who have to serve both sides and who ostensibly, under present procedures, would serve both sides of politics. That is not happening. Some of the more prominent pronouncements are coming from people such as the Secretary of the Treasury, John Stone, instead of from his Minister.

I believe there are occasions when heads of departments must read speeches on behalf of Ministers when the Ministers are unable to speak when they have been invited to do so. But I think it is totally wrong that policy options are being flown, as kites are flown, by heads of departments who should serve whichever party is in government. It is almost as though the ideologues in the Treasury and in the Government's ranks-following on from what John Stone of the Treasury has said-want to ensure that the worst possible effects of the expansion of our resource based industries actually occur. They seem utterly unconcerned about the tens of thousands of jobs that are at stake. They are quite unable to show where replacement jobs are to be found, particularly when the problems of regional and skill imbalances are taken into account.

It is imperative that these destructive attitudes be rejected. There is absolutely no need for a sharp reduction in activity levels in Australian manufacturing industries. The resources, labour and capital in those industries are generally not transferable to the mining and quarrying industries. Moreover, the employment likely to be generated in the current decade by the expansion of resource industries will not be sufficient to provide jobs for even half of the expanding work force. Up to a million extra jobs will be needed in the coming decade just to keep up with the work force growth. We have up in the Gallery young people who will be coming into the work force in the years to come. We have at the moment a net figure of about 120,000 people coming into the work force each year. Even though the bulge in the birth rate will mean that from the mid-1980s onwards the figure may reduce to a net 80,000 or 70,000 a year, honourable members on both sides of this Parliament will still face an enormous challenge in ensuring that the number of jobs required to meet that net increase in the work force is found in this country. We should go beyond that and find the extra number of jobs required to reduce the present horrific figure of half a million people unemployed in this country.

We will not find those jobs entirely out of the quarrying or entirely out of the resource based industries. The best research shows that that will not happen. That brings us back to manufacturing industry policy and to tertiary industry policies as well. It brings us back to the sorts of policies that are involved in the Bills before us, through which we have bounties as one means of encouraging the expansion of manufacturing industries in order to create those jobs. I repeat, the resource based industries will provide directly only about 10 per cent of the jobs we need and will provide indirectly another 30 per cent at the very most. This means that at least 60 per cent of employment growth must be generated by other means. So manufacturing industries must not be dismantled. In fact, we must build up our manufacturing capacity because a lot of new jobs in the tertiary sector are related to that manufacturing capacity. I believe that we need to find new areas of manufacturing industry growth and not just ensure that existing manufacturing capacity is not dismantled.

The present Government's policies are not addressed to this need. The manufacturing industries of Australia have been hammered by the restrictive monetary and fiscal policies which are so central to the Government's economic and social attitudes. The production index of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd has shown almost no growth over the past 12 months. Indeed, to be accurate-the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), who is interested in this debate would know this-the figure is 1.9 per cent, indicating almost no growth. We must all have as an objective a far greater growth rate than that if we are to create the number of jobs necessary to keep pace with the increase in the work force and, indeed, to make a dent in the present disgraceful level of unemployment in this country.

In most industries capacity utilisation is extraordinarily low-typically about 70 per cent-the only exceptions being a narrow range of industries supplying materials and equipment for their resource projects. But of equal importance is the fact that pathetic efforts have been made to encourage new industries in this country. The Government has placed virtually its whole emphasis on the resource based industries, namely, the mining, quarrying and aluminium industries. A comparable effort has not been made in the technology based industries-for example, in electronics, communications, bio-industries, new materials and aerospace. These rapidly growing industries in the world market have not been adequately promoted within Australia.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) has been busily lauding the merits of the Government's offset manufacturing policies. Lately the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) has been trumpeting the benefits of new industries based on high technology. But what are the facts? They are certainly not as one would imagine them to be, judging from some of the public relations outbursts from those two Ministers. The offset policy is presently miniscule. Offsets generated represent as little as one-fifth of one per cent of manufacturing industry turnover. The Government's disastrous failure to define appropriate defence producement requirements for Australia has meant that the largest project, the tactical fighter replacement, has been subject to one delay after another. Indeed, if we had such offset policies we might not need this bounty Bill in relation to wrenches.

There might then be sufficient work and sufficient demand for the product of the Siddons factory referred to and others instead of our having to pay out from revenue this amount. I am simply suggesting that that is a possibility so that I keep my remarks within the scope of this Bill. I see that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, think-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is using a very broad brush, but he is doing it skilfully. He may proceed.

—Thank you for the compliment, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think you understand that this legislation represents an essential part of industry policy generally and gives me an opportunity to talk about other aspects of industry policy. The experience with the industrial research and development incentives program has similarly been one of mismanagement by the Government. In the recent 1979-80 annual report of the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board, the chairman states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Board's task was again made somewhat difficult by the limitations placed at various times during the year on project grant commitments. Similarly additional funding required to acquit industry entitlements under the commencement grant scheme was not received until mid-June which meant that a substantial number of applications had to be held in abeyance pending the availability of these funds.

In the offsets policy and in the research and development policy we see the real nature of this Government's commitment to Australian industry. It is one of mismanagement, of not taking advantage of all the opportunities that present themselves-indeed, one of penny pinching of the most disruptive kind. Needless to say, the experience has been similar in the various export incentives schemes under which, typically, payments have been delayed for many months. In the meantime, Australia's industrial potential is declining. I mentioned earlier that the rates of factory usage had fallen to between 60 and 70 per cent. In other words, our existing factories have an enormous capacity which we should utilize before we start to build new ones to promote growth in order to create new jobs which, in turn will absorb the net increase in the work force and reduce the present terrible levels of unemployment in this country. I repeat that instead of being regenerated, the industry of this country is declining. Whereas the electronics and communications industries have been areas of strong demand growth, Australian employment in these industries has fallen by 45 per cent since the beginning of the decade.

I will not listen to anybody from the other side of the House suggest, as perhaps some of them will try to suggest, that this decline came mainly during the Labor Government's period in office. That period was part of an international economic downturn. The sorts of things happening in the country at that time were happening in other parts of the world. Since then there has been re-industrialisation in many other countries. There has been a growth in the number of people employed. In this country, in spite of an energy equation which is in our favour, we have not, because of a lack of proper government policies, been living up to our potential. A lid has been kept on our economy. We have had virtually no growth. The figure recorded for the last financial year was 1.9 per cent. That is a disgrace. It means that many more people are unemployed now than need be. New opportunities have now arisen which should be taken advantage of. They are not being taken advantage of because of the policy of stagnation in this country at present.

Electronics component production has virtually ceased. This is just one example of the neglect of the technology-based industries. It is high time the Government recognised that the resources industries are not a panacea for all our ills. They will not provide enough jobs for all our needs. They will not provide satisfying and varied employment opportunities for our growing and increasingly better educated work force. They will not alone guarantee a secure and balanced future for this country. Australia's development strategy must include a reinvigoration of manufacturing industry. Leadership must be provided by the national Government, as it is in most other advanced countries, and not left to the effects of so-called market forces. Development strategies depend so much on government policy, the co-ordination of investment and the development of technological advantages that markets simply do not work. We are not talking about following comparative advantages but determining for ourselves what are our comparative advantages and what they should be.

The national Government can provide this leadership by devising a plan for the development of industry. This planning approach should then be backed by selective industry assistance policies which combine research, export, investment and production subsidies in an appropriate mix. Two of the three Bills before us contain some subsidies but they are interim ones until others take over. Bounties are probably the most efficient form of subsidy but I repeat that the Bills before us are interim measures. Bounties have minimal price effects and are readily adjusted. Direct government involvement may also be necessary in some instances, particularly where an industry is internationally dominated by a few firms, such as the computer and aerospace industries. In circumstances such as these, complete reliance on private sector entrepreneurship is not sufficient. We need government departments such as the Department of Science and Technology and the old Department of Productivity to stimulate such entrepreneurship. I give credit to some of the innovations that have taken place in that field in recent months. The Australian people will not get the sort of leadership, not the necessary amount of it, from the Fraser Government. So many of its members are still paying lip service to a market-only approach. We need more stimulus and partnership between the public sector, the government and the private sector for the sorts of objectives I have outlined to be achieved.

The bounty measures we are considering, like virtually all the Government's industry policies, aim not at new development but at protecting industries which have been long established. We need both. In these Bills we can fairly observe that this Government's approach to industry is one of living on our historical inheritance, either benefits handed from former entrepreneurs or the benefits of what can be dug from the ground, instead of getting out into the new world and seeking new jobs built on new areas of activity. What we badly need now is a series of new initiatives which develop Australia's potential for participating in higher technology industry. The continued neglect of this need by the present Government is deserving of the strongest condemnation. However, I repeat that a little is better than nothing. The two bounty Bills are supported by the Opposition because they at least preserve some of the jobs in areas where they should be preserved. However, in themselves they are insufficient. We need a whole new approach to creating jobs in manufacturing industry instead of the laissez fairism we are suffering in this country at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House sympathise with the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) in his difficulty in being obliged to speak for half an hour about three Bills, the Bounty (Polyester-Cotton Yarn) Amendment Bill, the Bounty (Non-adjustable Wrenches) Bill and the Coal Excise Amendment Bill, which he supports. He sought synthetically to discover elements of the Government's policy in this area with which he is in disagreement. There were elements of what he said with which I agree. Bounties are certainly the most efficient and proper manner in which support should be given to Australian industries. If we rely on tariffs or other hidden benefits the taxpayer is not clearly aware of what sort of support is being given to individual industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that many people in the cities complain bitterly about the level of bounties and subsidies to people in rural industries because the costs of these bounties and subsidies are so clearly evident. If we could ensure that all support for the manufacturing industries in the cities were clearly available in the form of bounties rather than being hidden in tariffs so that one cannot state exactly what the real cost is, I believe that the debate which divides the city and the country in many areas could be eliminated. One could see quite clearly what were the costs of the support given to manufacturing and other city industries and many country industries. I recognise, of course, that there are many manufacturing industries in rural areas. That is true of my electorate.

I am surprised that the honourable member for Adelaide is so sensitive about his commitment to socialism that he felt obliged to explain and justify it. He regarded these three Bills as democratic socialism because they involve an intervention in the market-place. The nonsense that the honourable member for Adelaide raised is worthy of investigation. I wonder whether he would regard the erection of borders as being intervention in the market-place. These Bills are concerned with the borders of a nation. They deal with the relationship of this nation with other nations. That does not, I imagine, represent to the honourable member intervention in the market-place. If it does, it is surprising. When the honourable member's Government was in office-I know that he was not a Minister and so I suppose he cannot be blamed-its level of activity in this area was to bring about the destruction of 125,000 jobs in Australian manufacturing industry by an across-the-board, not thought out, irrational 25 per cent cut in tariffs. This had a devastating effect on Australian manufacturing industry. If that is democratic socialism at work, I do not think the Australian people want much of it. I submit that perhaps the wrong definition has been given by the honourable member for Adelaide in a desperate attempt to justify his curious philosophic position. Having supported the wiping out of tariffs as a member of the Labor Government with the consequent loss of 125,000 jobs, he now commends the present Government for being democratic socialists by doing exactly the opposite.

I raise now the realities of these Bills. Certainly, as the honourable member for Adelaide has said, the Coal Excise Amendment Bill simply makes it easier in an administrative sense to implement the requirement that collections should be made of information on the production of coal. Making the period 28 days rather than seven days is simply a sensible proposition.

The bounty on non-adjustable wrenches is, as the honourable member for Adelaide has said, simply a temporary one. He said that in a critical sense, as if it was somehow unpleasant or unreasonable. What he did not go on to say is that an assessment of the need for the continuance of the bounty assistance beyond 12 months will be undertaken by the Industries Assistance Commission as part of its overall examination of cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools manufacture on which it is to report to the Government by 30 June. I cannot see that it is a matter for criticism that, pending a detailed investigation and a report being made to the Government, this temporary assistance should be given. I cannot understand why the honourable member for Adelaide should find that to be an issue on which he should be critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not find that to be an issue.

—Then I wonder why the honourable member went to the trouble of saying that this was only a temporary measure, as if that indicated that the Government had no enthusiasm for, no interest in, adopting an overall approach. To the contrary, an overall study is clearly under way and a report is due by June of this year. I would have thought that it would have been fairer of him to have adopted a more bal- anced approach on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the bounty for polyester-cotton yarn, the same situation applies. In fact, this is an interim measure. From 1 January 1982 new bounty arrangements for polyester-cotton yarns will come into effect. They are part of the Government's proposed program for assistance to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries beyond 1981. This is not an ad hoc measure. It is an interim one while long term proposals are being introduced. It was unreasonable and unfair of the honourable member for Adelaide, in his desperate search for things on which to criticise the Government about three Bills which he supports, to have raised these matters in this way.

I think it worth while to mention, however, that there are some problems about this kind of legislation. Many people take the view that it is in the best interests of Australia as a whole not to have artificial support for industries which are in competition with industries overseas. I stress that this does not involve intervention within the market place of corporations in Australia. It concerns the relationship with other countries. It seems to me that if one seeks to protect Australian industries one will naturally be increasing in one way or another the costs to Australian taxpayers. A bounty is a simple method because it is the taxpayers alone who carry the burden. It is not carried forward into a cost of living figure, as would a tariff. That is why I believe that the way in which the Government is going about it is by far the most sensible one. I am glad to see that the honourable member for Adelaide agrees.

However, many people take the view that the cost to the taxpayer can never be justified by the number of jobs that are created or saved in this way. All that I would like to emphasise is that, despite the comments of the honourable member for Adelaide, in the last five years there has been an increase of 400,000 in the number of people at work in Australia. In the main they have been males. The allegations of honourable members opposite that the bulk of this employment has been in part time female work is arrant nonsense and they know it. This 400,000 increase in the number at work in Australia comes as a surprise to the people who listen to the rhetoric of honourable members opposite and to the criticism that manufacturing industry has not expanded,that it has done nothing. When one puts into reverse a loss of something like 125,000 jobs in manufacturing industry under a Labor Government, in a period of some 18 months, as a result of that Government's determined tariff policies, a fair case is made out for saying that Australian manufacturing has progressed far better under this Government. Certainly it has far greater prospects. This can be seen from the dramatic recovery in the export levels of manufacturing industry since the Government came to office. It has been largely as a result of the increasing competitiveness of Australian industry as against that of overseas industry. This emerges largely from the fact that we have managed to hold our inflation rate far below that of other countries. That is why I was intrigued to hear the honourable member for Adelaide say that the reason Labor had problems when in government was that it was part of an economic downturn which affected the whole world at the time. Let me remind him of what has been happening around the world in the last couple of years. If that has not been an economic downturn, I wonder what it has been. In fact, Australia has managed to be largely insulated from the economic problems facing the rest of the world. That has been possible because of the sound economic management that the honourable member for Adelaide so denigrates.

It seems to me to be curious that he is prepared to diminish at all times the real achievements of this Government in increasing the numbers of people who are employed, in manufacturing industries in particular, and in bringing to an end the downturn in employment which took place under Labor-not because of special overseas factors which are not now affecting Australia but simply because Labor's economic management allowed runaway inflation, which put our costs far above those obtaining in the rest of the world. Because this Government has held the inflation rate down, relative to that of other countries, costs have enabled manufacturing industry to play a much more competitive part in the trading world. As a result, we have achieved a big increase in employment.

But why do we have to put up with these bounties? Why do we have to protect ourselves against other nations of the world? It is disappointing to note that this is not a perfect world. Many Australian industries which could compete very successfully, particularly those in the rural sector, are not given the opportunity to do so by the major trading groups, such as the European Common Market, in particular, because of the offensive and restrictive trade policies adopted by those nations. Instead of allowing the sort of access that Australia and New Zealand, in particular, used to have to Great Britain before it joined the Common Market, products from that group are now being dumped around the world-I might say by the use of the same sort of bounty and subsidy arrangements that we have in this Bill. It may well be that this Bill could be regarded as some sort of retaliation for the unfriendly trading practices which now are commonplace throughout the world, particularly in the European Common Market.

I want to stress especially the impact that this kind of bounty, when applied to agricultural products in Europe, has on Australia. Cheese and other dairy products which used to flow from Australia to the Common Market have been effectively blocked by unfair bounty payments in the Common Market. That practice is now spreading heavily into the meat industry, and I must declare that I have an interest in that area. Meat industry support, through subsidies and bounties, in the European Common Market has been so great that instead of being a massive importer the Common Market will probably this year become the world's biggest exporter of meat. The meat industry there has been artificially subsidised by the taxpayer. This should underline for Australia the dangers and the excesses of the sort of measure that we are employing now. However, we are not using it to excess, rather to protect the position that obtains. It is disconcerting to find that we are required to bring in this kind of legislation because of the unreasnable way in which bounties and subsidies, as well as prohibitions and limitations specifically on imports by developed countries such as the European Economic Community are putting us in such a disadvantageous position. I emphasise, for example that a figure of some 570,000 tones of carcass weight equivalent last year the Common Market was the world's second largest exporter of meat, after Australia, having been previously one of the major importers. This was made possible only because of the huge subsidies to which I have referred

An added burden to Australia is that these subsidies mean that the Common Market then dumps subsidised meat products in many meat markets to which we used to export. I refer, for instance, to the Middle East. It is disconcerting to note that quite recently the European Economic Community Commission proposed making a further increase of 9 per cent for the coming financial year in the support given to these bounty and subsidy prices.

That will mean much higher production and make things worse for the rest of the world. There is no doubt in my mind that the general principle of bounties, tariffs and restraints of this kind is not sound unless we live in a perfect world. Regrettably, we do not live in such a perfect world.

I now refer to the coal levy because, although it is only very nominal, it does relate to an industry which has another levy, that is the coal export levy. The other day in this House I described what is, in my view, the best way to overcome the relative disadvantage the coal industry suffers because of the discriminatory application of the concept of a levy for coal exports. It seems to me that if it is good enough to hit the coal industry with an export levy it should be good enough to hit every other raw material export with an export levy. It seems to me that such a levy would massively encourage the upgrading and processing of Australian raw materials in Australia. It seems that there is a real need for this encouragement, especially when one considers the pellet plants lying idle in the north-west of Western Australia. Rather than approach this problem the way the Australian Labor Party has approached it by talking about a resources tax or a super-profits tax, which in fact would simply result in a disincentive for people to invest, if a levy similar to that applied in the coal industry were applied to all raw material exports a massive incentive would be provided for all raw material producers to upgrade their products in Australia before exporting. This may be, in the terms of the honourable member for Adelaide, an intervention in the market-place. Once again I would say that in effect this is an intervention at the border of one's nation just as I suggest that two of the three measures the House is discussing represent an intervention at the border but not within our own market-place.

Certainly I hope the Government will give strong consideration to extending the levy on the coal industry to all other raw material producers. I hope that this will serve not only to diminish the use of Australia as a quarry-which some companies have been doing in the sense that they have not upgraded their produce in Australia before exporting it-but also that there would be merit in adopting this approach in some areas of primary industry. There should be, for example, an export levy placed on live animals, but there is no levy on meat being exported. Such a levy would encourage the maintenance of a thriving meat processing industry to the benefit of all Australians, particularly primary producers. Once again I declare my interest in that industry. The same can be said for the wool industry. It is absurd that we export greasy wool when we have a great capacity to produce wool tops. It seems to me that the tradition of Bradford has tended to dominate us far too much in our decision to maintain our exports of wool in greasy form. It may well be that we will have some difficulty dealing with customers overseas because of this, but we do have a capacity to negotiate in regard to these raw materials and the increased revenues that could come from such levies could allow a reduction of the burden which, as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has quite rightly pointed out, has been carried by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers in recent years. There is no doubt that they have contributed far more to increased revenue in Australia than any other group of taxpayers.

The coal levy is a very nominal matter but, nonetheless, it raises an interesting issue in that it relies on the appropriate railway authorities for the issuing of weighbridge certificates. In New South Wales at the moment it is fairly difficult to get effective weighbridge certificates if the shunters will not move the coal. I am particularly disturbed to see that the New South Wales Government has been prepared to accept the existence of industrial disruption which does not cost the people involved any money. It allows this kind of industrial disruption which holds up exports, which is damaging to our balance of payments and which costs jobs in the coal industry, without the New South Wales Government's taking any strong action against the people causing the disruption. The same thing applies to the coal loaders, for example, at Port Kembla. There is a continuing dispute which has cost members of the Transport Workers Union who truck the coal from my electorate something like 62 per cent of their earnings over the last three months. There seems to be a great need for the governments involved-as the Federal Government is involved, through this excise legislation-particularly at the State level, to take a far more responsible view of the services they provide to the users of those services. I hope that the New South Wales Government will accept its responsibility to provide a proper service to the coal industry, particularly through the railways and the coal loading facilities. I support these three Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) suggested in the course of his speech that policies I supported during the years of the Whitlam Government were responsible for a loss of jobs. I deny that those policies were the cause. I said in the course of my speech that it was international economic factors which were responsible and that, indeed, the picture here was the same as elsewhere. I want to illustrate this very briefly by using some figures which the honourable member used and distorted. He used August 1975 to August 1980 figures and said that employment had increased by 400,000 people. He used that figure today; he has used it previously. This is a distorted picture because the Labor Government policies were still in force until February 1976. When one takes that into consideration, and realises that the Hayden Budget was responsible for what happened between August 1975 and February 1976 when there was a growth of 80,000 jobs in this country, one realises that the honourable member's figures are a distortion of the growth pattern over those five years. Finally, he suggested that my policies during the Whitlam years were worse than his Government's policies since then. I need say no more than that from February 1973 to February 1976 employment growth in this country was 246,000, that is over three times the growth of that during the time of his Government from February 1976 to February 1979. During that period the growth was a mere, paltry 71,900 jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Currency Amendment Bill now before the House is not contentious and I do not intend to detain the House for very long. The Bill gives authorisation to the Government to mint a $10 silver coin to commemorate the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane in 1982. This coin is to be 92.5 per cent silver, otherwise known as sterling silver. It will be minted in the second half of this year and issued at a price which will be determined nearer to the time of distribution. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said in his second reading speech, it will be issued at a price substantially above its face value. The other main aspect of this Bill is to provide that any future issue of new coins will be capable of being implemented by way of regulation rather than by having to amend the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to make a few general comments in relation to collector or commemorative coins. The distribution of such coins clearly is something which is very popular in the community. It is an attractive way to hold precious metal. If one looks at the distribution of the gold coins which were minted last year one will find that there has been great community demand for them. As I understand it, the Government has already sold 50,000 of the special proof gold $200 coins at a price of $300 and 207,000 of the $200 uncirculated or bullion-type gold coins at a price of $240 a coin. There was an unmet demand from some 70,000 people for the collector coin which sold at $310. Quite clearly, this is something which has attracted considerable interest in the community and has been an interesting exercise on the part of the Government. In view of this demand for gold coins at substantial prices we can therefore expect that the issue of a silver coin also will be very popular, particularly because it will be offered at a lower price. As I mentioned, that price will not be known until nearer the issuance stage.

It should also be noted in passing that the distribution of these coins has been a very profitable exercise for the Government. In the second reading speech made last year by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) when amending the Act to allow the gold coins to be minted, he said that the collector coin which sold for $310 would show a profit of some 33 per cent. On that basis, with 50,000 of them having been sold, one can roughly calculate a profit of some $5m. With respect to the bullion-type coin, of which 207,000 have been sold, the Treasurer said that the profit would be relatively small. He did not elaborate further. Assuming that the profit is at least 10 per cent, then a profit of about $5m, and perhaps more, will result from the sale of those 207,000 gold coins. Altogether in this exercise we are looking at a profit in excess of $10m, which is an interesting exercise in public sector activity.

I notice that, according to a recent article in one of our weekend papers, the Government has incurred a considerable cost in the distribution of these coins, and this may have dinted the profit expectations of the Government. I understand that the Ward's organisation was the distribution agent and that it charged some $7.50 delivery for each coin. Presumably, that was well in excess of what the Government thought delivery costs would be because it expected the deliveries to be made by Australia Post at an unspecified cost but, one assumes, well below the eventual cost of $7.50 a coin. Even taking into account the distribution costs, it is clear that the Government has made a considerable profit from the minting of these gold coins. It is also interesting to note that the gold coins were minted when gold prices were near record levels. As I am sure most honourable members are aware, gold prices have fallen considerably since then, and persons who purchased the gold coins from a speculative viewpoint may be rather disappointed about what has happened since. Of course, I suppose eventually gold prices will rise again. I mentioned earlier the provision that in future new coins will be minted by changing the regulations rather than by amending the Act. This seems to us to be a worthwhile amendment. I think that the Parliament has more important matters to debate than the issuing of new coins of this kind. Therefore, the Opposition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the support of the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) for this legislation. It is true, as the honourable member for Gellibrand said, that there was a strong demand for these coins which resulted in a handy profit to the Government. It probably brought a smile to the lips of those people who managed to thieve one parcel of coins, which I understand went astray. Obviously with the drop in the price of gold the thieves have not done as well as they thought they would initially.
—Oh, they got rid of them quickly.

—As the honourable member says, they might have got rid of them fairly quickly. Some aspects of this legislation are worth mentioning. Many honourable members hope that the Royal Australian Mint has a greater capacity to cope with the anticipated demand for this silver coin than it showed in its handling of the first gold coin issue, when there was widespread unhappiness throughout the community. Those people who had applied for coins were unhappy to find that not only was there a massive delay in the meeting of their orders or, if they were unsuccessful, in the return of their money, but also that a curious set of rules was introduced after the event which meant that many people who had applied for gold coins were not supplied with the proof coin as requested.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that we should adopt a far more business-like approach. I regret to say that the Mint did not cover itself with glory in the manner in which it handled that issue, and I think that it would be wrong for us to pretend anything else. I hope that that unfortunate experience will be usefully noted so that the same thing does not happen when the silver coins are issued. I also suggest that if any other government instrumentalities are involved in what could be described as a merchandising venture of this type which involves the receiving of cheques, that some better system be adopted than simply cashing the cheques, holding the money to the disadvantage of the people involved for up to five months and then sending the cheques back with no interest payment whatsoever. That was not a decent way to deal with the people who applied for these coins and I believe that the Mint acted badly. I hope that measures will be taken to ensure that people are not deprived of what in some instances were quite large sums of money on which interest could well have been earned had the money been invested. It is quite wrong for the Mint to have handled this matter in this way and I must express my disappointment.

The other matter that I think should be discussed is whether it is a good measure to allow future coins to be issued as a result of regulation rather than an Act of parliament. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), rightly, in my mind, said that he thought it would be a sensible development because the Parliament has more to do with its time than just pass Bills of this nature. It is interesting to note the suggestion that if this were done 100 years ago it would have brought about a bloody revolution. Anyone tampering with the coins or with the content of the coins certainly would have caused a fuss.

One matter that the honourable member for Gellibrand did not raise and which I think is perhaps even more significant than the question of whether new coins can be made by regulation, is that clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill provide for the composition of existing coins to be varied by regulation and for the denominations of the composition of new coins to be prescribed by regulation. This is an interesting measure because it certainly enables the government of the day to play around with the content of the coins if there are major changes, say, in the value of the metals involved or in the value of the currency. Some Government members did express concern about this and they have raised the matter with the Treasurer (Mr Howard). Undertakings have been given that under this Government proper notice will be given to the Parliament of any such regulations which can often slip through unless clear notice is given. I am glad to see that the Opposition supports this Bill which, of course, has the strong support of the Government's back bench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the House long, but I take this opportunity to make some remarks on the distribution and availability of what are deemed to be collector coins from the Royal Australian Mint and the lack of access of the general public compared with commercial operations to this distribution. This lack of availability did not come to my notice until recently. Last year a series of questions directed to the distribution point at the Mint elicited different information on each occasion on the availability of proof coins. I am not talking about the gold coin at this stage, but the normal annual proof coin distributions. On the first occasion, which was some time in February last year, advice was given that postal applications could be made until some time in August. Subsequently it was indicated that postal applications had in fact closed at the end of February. It was also indicated that coins were available from the Mint on certain dates.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making is that the general availability and methods by which collector coins are made available are not widely known. Certainly, in seeking information there seems to be some confusion at the Mint itself. There may not be, but the information which was supplied to inquiries I am aware of was inaccurate and it ultimately prevented the inquirer from ordering or obtaining coins. At the time of the initial inquiries, which was early in the year, coins were in fact available from professional dealers at double the price the Mint would normally charge, which would indicate that dealers have first access to supplies of proof coins.
