There may be reasons for that but I think it is something which the public should be aware of and I think that a statement from the responsible Minister, indicating the means by which people can apply for and obtain coins, would not be inappropriate.

I also want to refer to the availability of direct sale coins. There is only one production point for these coins. Last year, on the first day of issue of proof coins, some 1,600 people queued up in Canberra for the supply of these coins which are at this stage fashionable items to collect. That means that some 14 million Australians who do not live in Canberra either had to spend considerable sums of money to travel to Canberra or had to apply by post some seven months earlier for such coins. I do not think that is a reasonable method of distribution of items which are designed by the Government for commercial sale for profit. There is no question that that is the reason why this type of collector item is produced.

I think that everyone is aware that the production and distribution of the gold coin was a fiasco. I do not think that anyone anticipated the problems which arose. I think this House ought to be aware of those problems, that it should learn the lessons and ensure that these problems do not arise again. For instance, when orders were called, they were called in a certain fashion. I could name a collector organisation in Melbourne-but I will not-which decided that some of its members were going to purchase coins. It applied through the secretary for a number of coins. A decision was taken that multiples of the coins were not to be provided with the result that although some nine applications were made, I think only one coin arrived. I presume they raffled it. No advance advice was available to people, as far as I am able to ascertain, that multiple applications would not be met and therefore it was advisable for individuals to apply separately. If they did that they would at least have had some chance of obtaining the coins which they sought.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) mentioned the long delay in the holding of money for the purchase of these coins where some $300 was involved in each case. The holding of that money for over three months meant the loss of fairly substantial amounts in interest to the people concerned. I am not going on a vendetta or anything of that nature against the Mint but I think it is essential that people are able to obtain information of the means by which the coins are available and that members of the general public have an opportunity which is at least equal to that given to those who live in Canberra or to the dealers who are able to cream off a very substantial profit because of the lack of opportunity to members of the public to obtain coins through what I indicate are unsatisfactory sales methods.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr McVeigh) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Dairying Research Amendment Bill. I wish to raise a few issues relevant to the dairy industry. At present the Australian dairy industry is under the microscope. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is looking into the affairs of the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Australian dairy industry. Of course, any discussions which take place in the industry create a degree of interest which normally would not exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again this House has before it legislation which seeks to amend the Dairy Research Act 1972. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has mentioned that three of the proposed amendments have been sought by the Dairying Research Committee and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. These proposed amendments are designed to bring the dairy research legislation into line with changing circumstances. The major change in the legislation is that the Dairying Research Committee is to be renamed the Australian dairying research committee. The Minister for Primary Industry commented that this name change will give the research committee a national identity in international research circles. Apparently the Government has now decided that this legislation should embody a national outlook for the industry. This approach possibly highlights more than anything else how, when it comes to dealing with dairy industry matters, honourable members on the Government benches are inclined to cry after the milk has been spilt. There is ample evidence to show that, in the last five years, the industry, particulary in the manufacturing milk sector, has moved from a national industry to an industry based in Victoria. Today States such as Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia are producing only export products in minute tonnages in short periods of the year. Basically they are city liquid milk producers.

All this research being conducted within the dairy industry, which is aimed at increased productivity, sales and manufacturing techniques, will be of little consequence unless this Government gives a positive indication of what is required of the industry. Much of the research is being conducted into producing new products but there is grave concern as to whether it would be wise to invest in long term planning until the industry is confident of its future.

I would take this opportunity to canvass the issue of Federal and State responsibilities in the area of research in the dairy industry. The facts of life over the last decade clearly point to the manufacturing industry contracting to the State of Victoria. This change has come about by market forces, coupled with natural climatic conditions, where the State of Victoria is ideally suited to dairying. When decisions which try to hold back the natural climatic and market forces of any industry are made by government, eventually there will be a price to pay.

Research has shown predictions for the production and export of dairy products in the 1981-82 season as amounting to only 13 per cent. This is well below the accepted level of production to guarantee products to the Australian market at all times of the year. Some 90 per cent of prescribed products-that is, products which come under the jurisdiction of the Australian Dairy Corporation-other than city liquid milk, will be produced by Victoria. The Dairy Corporation's record of management is being scrutinised at present by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. It is high time that some research was initiated by this Government to consider seriously whether there is a need to scrutinise the future of the ADC. A question that should be asked is whether there is a need to have a dairy corporation at Federal level with a charter that is no longer suited to the production patterns which have developed.

Even though Victoria produces 90 per cent of prescribed dairy products-that is, butter, butter oil, skim milk powder, buttermilk powder mixture, casein and wholemilk powder-a decreasing amount of these products will be exported in 1981-82. The majority of these products will be sold interstate on the Australian market. In order to illustrate this point we should look at the ADC's powers and functions. The Corporation is responsible to the Minister for Primary Industry for the performance of the following functions described in the Act: To promote the export from Australia of dairy produce; to control the export from Australia of dairy produce; to control the sale and distribution of dairy produce after its export from Australia; to promote trade and commerce in dairy produce amongst the States, between the States and Territories and within the Territories; to improve production and encourage the consumption of dairy produce in the Territories; and such other functions in connection with dairy produce as are provided by the regulations.

It is clearly seen from this charter that the Australian Dairy Corporation has no powers to import dairy products to make up any shortfalls in production in Australia. If the Corporation, either through being unable to collate accurate production figures, or through mismanagement, both of which we have seen just recently, causes a shortfall in a particular product, private industry would have to import the required product. It becomes quite clear that, if Queensland or Western Australia finds that it is short of butter this coming winter, the companies that will import the product will be the Ballantyne Export Co. Pty Ltd or Lavery Distribution and Sales Pty which already have agreements with New Zealand. There is a false belief in the industry that the Corporation will import the product. The Corporation has no such powers. There is a false belief also that by having a Federal body there will be some protection from imports. I ask the Minister for Primary Industry, who is seated at the table, to make clear to the industry just what is the true position.

In June 1982, there will be a new free trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand. Just this week, I received a submission from the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation which has been sent to all honourable members of Parliament. It states:

The dairy industry's policy is that dairy products should be excluded from any phased reduction of trade barriers between Australia and New Zealand. Any relaxation of the formal and informal restrictions on trade would result in unfair and unreasonable disruption to the Australian dairy industry. The Australian dairy industry also contends that the current informal arrangements between the two industries should be formalized at government level. In other words, the present agreements between the industries on access for New Zealand butter and cheese should be confirmed on a government to government basis.

The Minister for Primary Industry should come clean with the dairy industry and state just what is the Government's policy and how it relates to the proposals of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation.

I wish to indicate what would be the scenario if the Fraser Government opts for open free trade. For every tonne of product imported from New Zealand or the European Economic Community into Queensland, Western Australia, New South Wales or South Australia, an equivalent tonne of Victorian product will have to be traded on the lower priced world market. That is the reality of the present situation. What is the alternative? The alternative is for the industry, with Federal Government support, to attempt to allow the Victorian Dairy Industry Authority to take over those charters which at present the Dairy Corporation carries out on behalf on the Victorian industry. Instead of the Victorian industry having to export products at lower prices, that industry finances the promotion and research for markets within Australia, under the Victorian dairy industry charter the industry could get its chop of those interstate markets and actively compete for its rightful markets. If necessary it could even market its product in New Zealand under the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Perhaps it could try a little of the free enterprise about which we hear so much from the Government benches.

I would like to take up the matter of whether we should be economic realists as far as industry is concerned. Some States, such as Western Australia, have great mineral deposits. As these deposits are developed they will earn great income from exports to world markets-markets which have a demand for energy which States such as Victoria and Tasmania cannot supply because of their lack of those mineral discoveries.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Latrobe Valley?

—The Latrobe Valley has brown coal, but at this stage it cannot be exported because it contains too much water, but brown coal is used in the manufacture of aluminium and other products which can be exported. At this stage States such as Queensland, Western Australia and even New South Wales have every advantage as far as exports are concerned. The southern States have their great advantage in terms of agriculture. It is from this source that a State such as Victoria must earn its income. It is the overall responsibility of the Federal Government to co-ordinate the economy so that the mineral exporting States give first preference to the dairy products of States such as Victoria and Tasmania. If the present situation whereby the dairy industry remains under the control of an outdated corporation is allowed to continue we will see States such as Queensland and Western Australia sharing their wealth with the New Zealand dairying industry. This would be an intolerable situation and an indictment of this tired Government's approach to economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not oppose the Bill. We welcome the fact that updating is taking place in the dairying industry at all times. There is a great need for research generally. There is a great need for research into the way in which this industry will go in the future. I urge the Government to act and to act fairly quickly because time is not something which is on the side of those in the dairying industry. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments to the Dairying Research Act. In 1958 legislation was first brought into this Parliament to set up a dairying research organisation in Australia. New legislation was introduced in 1972. In the light of experience and progress in the dairying industry, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is now seeking to amend the Act to allow for further progress insofar as research is concerned. A great change has occurred in our dairying industry. I do not suppose that one would find any primary industry in Australia which has faced more challenges and which is as difficult to handle as the dairying industry. If the Government were to adopt the suggestion of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), the States would be in severe competition with each other. On the one hand, the honourable member advocates co-operation between the States and the establishment of a national organisation, and on the other hand he suggests that Victoria should be given the opportunity to move into the markets in the other States and engage in straight-out competition.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to have reliable information available to us in our thinking on the dairying industry because of the challenges that exist in the industry and because of the fact that we can be subjected to imports from overseas. In fact, many tonnes of European cheeses have come into Australia over the years. The legislation of 1972 has certainly done a tremendous amount to stabilise the industry within Australia. The Commonwealth has been prepared to subsidise 50 per cent of the actual cost of research. I know that the State departments of agriculture have played a very big part in doing that research. It is important to remember that the research being encouraged relates not only to the farm but also to the factory and the education of the people involved in the factories. Farmers have to be advised of the results of this research. I believe that over the years, particularly in recent years, the Australian Dairy Research Committee has met its obligation to pass on its findings to the farmers. The Committee has been set up as a steering organisation to co-ordinate research in Australia and distribute the results in the right direction.

I was pleased recently to see the adoption of a four-year program for the marketing of our cheese. It is anticipated that by 1984 we could be marketing up to $40m worth of cheese a year. In 1979-80 almost $1.2m was spent on dairying research. In excess of $400,000 was spent on farm research and $524,000 was spent on manufacturing research. Many aspects of farm management are being developed today as a result of research. I am sure there are many dairymen in the States who have not had the opportunity to avail themselves of advice regarding the proper use of fertilisers. Many farmers today do not know whether they should be using superphosphate or nitrogenous fertilisers simply because they are not aware of the quality of their land and the climatic conditions under which they farm.

Many farmers are most anxious to know more about the relationship between the input of feed and the output of production of the cow. Of course, we can say that basically the production in Great Britain, Europe and America is so much greater than ours. However, their feeding conditions are so different to ours. They feed their cows hay and grain. Any Australian dairy farmer who feeds his stock grain and hay can get a great production per cow. But, as I said, the system of farming in Australia is different from that practised overseas. Farmers in Australia are dependent mainly upon pasture feeding. As such they can get fluctuations at certain times of the year. But that is the economical way to dairy farm within Australia, particularly in the southern areas, such as Victoria and Tasmania. These are the sorts of things that we have to research so that the farmer will know what his output will be if he feeds certain types of feed to his cattle.

The dairying industry is subject to challenge by substitutes, markets and the seasons. It is particularly concerned with the quality of its product. There has been a great increase in the quality of the product over the years. I believe that today Australian farmers are producing as fine a quality of milk as is being produced anywhere in the world. They have met their responsibilities, and are meeting their responsibilities, insofar as the demands of health departments are concerned. I do not wish to say a lot more about the Bill. However, I think it is important that I should say something as I am a representative of a dairying electorate.

I was delighted the other day to hear the Minister for Primary Industry tell producers of an underwriting scheme which will date from 1 July next. It is important that the Minister should keep such schemes under constant review. We know that there have been discussions between New Zealand and Australia concerning future ties in respect of primary production and other areas. I do not know whether it is possible to exclude the dairy industry from these discussions. I know that the Minister is well aware of the matters of concern to the industry and that he is consulting closely with the States and the industry. We have to examine the level of assistance that New Zealand farmers obtain from their government compared with the level that Australian farmers receive from their government. I believe that our farmers have met their responsibilities, given the assistance that has been made available the marketing schemes within Australia and the benefits which have resulted from research.

While, as a government, we continue to encourage production and to lower the cost of production then I am sure that we will never be afraid of importation of other dairy products. If we fail to do this then, as a government we do not have an argument to use. When we look at the dairying industry or any of the primary industries, as I said here the other day, we have to appreciate the capital investment, the hours of work by the farmer on the farm and the challenge of a 35 hour week. We know that in the dairy industry or in any other primary industry these are the things that will force up our costs at home. There will be consumer demand on State and Commonwealth governments for the importation of cheaper food if it is available. I have reason to believe that the Premier of New South Wales has already indicated to the State that we may have to look at the importation of primary products from New Zealand. This is what is approaching this country. We are not only talking because of price; we are talking because people are becoming afraid that our dairy industry within Australia may not be able to meet its own domestic requirements, whether it be for liquid milk or other manufactured products. We never want to see this time arrive in a country that is suitable for the dairying industry.

So it is that governments have to live up to their responsibilities, both Commonwealth and State, to see that the industry is assisted. We must take into account all those other social aspects about which I spoke before and the high investment cost for a person to be in the industry. This is an industry that has to survive here because of the livelihoods and the family units that are generally involved within it. I am very pleased to see today that the amending legislation provides for four direct representatives of the dairy industry on the committee. We do not have three people to represent the manufacturing side and one to represent the liquid milk side. One thing that I regret, after having been a Minister for agriculture in New South Wales for just a short period, is that governments before that day encouraged the dairy industry to be split and encouraged certain products to be actually paid for on a very variable basis.

This legislation is a recognition by the Government that the dairy industry throughout Australia is an industry in which the States have to work together. I believe that Victoria is tackling the problem now in a proper way. It is working around to establishing one price for a litre of milk. This is very important indeed. As a representative of New South Wales I say that if there is to be a challenge from New Zealand or from anywhere else I hope that all the States of Australia will get together to support basically the ones which rely upon the manufactured product and not the liquid milk supply. I am very pleased to support the amending legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I would like to thank the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) for allowing us to have a separate debate on the Dairying Research Amendment Bill. There are five agricultural Bills; they could all have been put into one cognate debate. The reason the Opposition requested that we have a separate debate on the dairy industry is that the dairy industry is under a great deal of stress at present. Many issues are coming up in the dairying industry. As this is a talking institution I think some of these things need to be aired. I thank my colleagues the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) for speaking and addressing themselves very much to these broader questions. I also need to thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for allowing the debate to range so widely because this is a very limited Bill. It just relates to changes of names and getting the dairy research fund in line with other agricultural research committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I was recently in the electorate of McMillan speaking to dairy farmers in Warragul, Trafalgar, Traralgon, Kooweerup and Sale-not that Sale is in the electorate of McMillan-and right through the Gippsland area. The dairy farmers in that area are very concerned about a host of issues that are affecting them. The dairying industry throughout the 1970s went through some rather dramatic changes. It is an industry which was over-producing in a way, or was being denied market access. The phasing out of the subsidies by the Australian Labor Party Government in a way forced the industry, in terms of its manufacturing sector, out of butter into cheese. I think that has all been to the good. We have now reached the stage where, because the industry has been reconstructed and production levels are now getting down to domestic consumption plus an exportable surplus, there are real doubts within the industry as to just how far this reconstruction will go. The concern is not due so much to the reconstruction measures themselves but rather to various social economic values within the industry, within the dairy farm, such as the conflict in some areas between different farming interests or the conflict between a need for industrial use of some land, particularly in the Latrobe valley. There are a whole range of factors. There are a lot of tensions and stresses in the industry. A lot of questions are being debated now within the industry.

If we look at the numbers of dairy farms it is quite obvious that they are still going down. It was said on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program National Farm Report yesterday that the latest figures show that the number of operating units within the Australian agricultural sector shows that there were some 3,256 fewer dairy farms in 1978-79 than three years earlier. If we had a few more updated figures than that I am quite sure we would see that the number of dairy farms have more than halved over the past 10 years. I am not saying that production levels have dropped by that much because they have not. A lot of the adjustment within the industry, of course, has been with respect to farm buildup. Now we are at this level of production and we are dealing with some degree of exportable surplus-at present there are good export markets for the products we are producing-one of the pressures on the farmers of course, is that they would like to get more land and take the opportunity of being able to guarantee the supply of dairy products to Australia and also to export to the better markets that seem to be opening up.

I do not know how any government or anyone will determine the exact degree of how much we should have as an exportable surplus. When we have an industry that is so clearly seasonal it is very hard indeed to predict just what level we should aim at. Although I believe that the Government should make some statement on what size it sees as desirable for the industry, I also acknowledge how difficult that will be. At present, as honourable members are aware, we have gone through one of the most damaging droughts. It is still on in many areas of the south-east corner of Australia right up the coast into Queensland. This is not predictable. It is no more predictable how long the drought will last than the drought itself was predictable. This has put a tremendous stress on the industry. A whole series of problems relating to this matter need to be discussed. This includes the price being paid to the farmers for their product, whether it be liquid milk or manufactured products.

There is real debate in the industry as to whether we could get more out of the market. The United Dairy Farmers of Victoria organisation maintains that it could get more out of the market for butter and for manufactured products. The dairy farmers of New South Wales and Queensland, given the pressure of the drought and the price of stock feed, believe that the price must go up for the domestic consumers, otherwise the farmers will be going out of business. I think we can see some evidence of the numbers going out of business, particularly those close to the big metropolitan area of Sydney, Newcastle and Wollongong where there are pressures by Pitt Street farmers, people going into hobby farms and studs. Good dairying land is going out. Without an increase in price it is quite clear that more and more land will go out of dairying. That is some of our better dairying land. Macarthur, the last electorate that I represented in this House, has very good dairying land particularly around Mittagong, Bowral and Moss Vale, the basalt country. This land is steadily being eroded and taken over by rural or other pursuits. That is a problem.

In Victoria people want access to more irrigation water, particularly in the Sale area which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) represents. I am sure that the Minister is well aware of those pressures. In Victoria there are pressures acting on the factories as the level of production has gone down and their seasonal production is coming in. Because of the mode of production by farmers the factories will get into more and more trouble. There is the question of trade with New Zealand. Already the honourable member for Lyne and the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) have raised these problems here this afternoon.

It seems to me that the proposition set out by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation will need to be taken into account very carefully by the Government. The level of protection and assistance given to the New Zealand dairy industry also needs to be taken into account. I believe that the New Zealanders apply a long term strategy with respect to their trade in dairy products because that trade is essential to their economic wellbeing. As long as both sides of the Tasman at governmental and industry level appreciate the problems inherent in the fact that Australia does not represent a long-term solution to New Zealand's problem in that regard, I think some kind of agreement can be worked out which both sides respect and acknowledge as being the best that can be arranged.

The problems raised by the honourable member for McMillan relate to Victoria, which is very much the pre-eminent dairying State. If we look at the full dimensions of the industry in that State, at the way in which the towns throughout the moister parts of Victoria are dependent on the dairying industry, at the absolute level of dairying in Victoria in terms of the overall level for Australia, we can almost say that the manufacturing dairying industry in Australia is concentrated in Victoria, the south-east of South Australia and Tasmania. Victorian farmer organisations put forward the case as they see it. They have a case which makes a heck of a lot of sense to them, as I am sure policy makers appreciate, but the Australian dairy industry still has to be regarded on a national basis.

The discussions I had with dairy farmers throughout the electorate of McMillan showed me that many producers believe that the days of the Australian Dairy Corporation may be numbered. Some of them are adopting a more extreme view and saying that even now we should be looking to phasing out that organisation. I would say that, overall, the Australian dairying industry does regard it as essential to have a national body. As long as we need to be engaged in export, as long as there is a need for promotion, as long as the various marketing arrangements are administered by a statutory authority with powers delegated by this Parliament, I think it will be essential to have a body such as the Australian Dairy Corporation. The States have powers in those areas, and we all freely acknowledge what the States could and could not do. However, I hope that before it reaches that stage wiser heads will prevail and some of the special problems Victoria faces will be recognised by all the other States and at the national level.

The organisations are always in some degree of dispute. I understand that at present the new underwriting arrangements are not being accepted particularly well by the organisations. Although I am not privy to the discussions, I know that at this time the Minister for Primary Industry is engaged in wide ranging discussions with the industry to have a form of underwriting accepted. I have said on other occasions that underwriting does not really represent much of a plus to the industry, given the present levels of production. Even so, I think that the industry still wants that guarantee of underwriting as part of the marketing arrangements and that that will continue for quite a while.

The matter of State competition was raised by the honourable member for Lyne, and one could comment on quite a few aspects of that. For example, the New South Wales producers want the price of liquid milk to be quite a bit higher than it is at present. They have had two small rises, but if the New South Wales producers were successful in obtaining these further price rises the Victorians quite sensibly would be able to divert milk into the New South Wales market. That is one of the fears. If we do not adopt a national approach, there will be nothing to stop Western Australia and Queensland importing butter if they wish. It is best that competition between the States does not get out of hand and that we adopt a national approach for some time yet.

As I said at the outset, determining the size of an industry and gaining some idea of how much exportable surplus is needed to take care of seasonal conditions is exceptionally hard. Say, for example, that the level of exports had to be 20 per cent more than the level of domestic consumption. If production were to drop below 120 per cent-say it dropped down to 90 per cent-we would be in a very difficult position indeed. If there were a seasonal upturn or if more people moved to the land and the level of production was 140 per cent instead of 120 per cent, we might face some of the problems we faced before. It is very difficult to determine. It is a testing task for government and for the organisations. It is an area which needs to be given quite a lot of thought at all levels in the industry.

Recently there has been quite a bit of disputation about whether we can meet our butter requirements this year. Arguments have been put forward by the Australian Dairy Corporation. I am not quite sure whether it is 100 per cent right or whether the case put by Mr Pyle, the President of the United Dairy Farmers of Victoria, is correct. However, it is quite obvious that we were very close to the margin, if we are not still short. I suppose one could say that there are two main reasons for this. Firstly, we are consuming more butter than was earlier anticipated. Secondly, errors in calculation were made in respect of the amount of product that would be available. I do not know exactly how one determines those things a year ahead when export quotas are being allocated. Again, one can appreciate both sides of the argument. I think it is very important that the Victorian farmers put forward their very strong view on this matter because they know darned well that they can produce and supply all the butter this country needs. If we were to consider importing butter without taking that into account and applying our minds to the problem Victoria has we would be very negligent indeed.

The last matter I wish to talk about is the problem of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, the Australian Dairy Corporation, and the inquiry under way in the Senate. I will not talk in specific terms about this matter because the Minister, in answer to a question, indicated quite clearly that he will not enter into any debate on this until the Senate has finished its inquiry. Nevertheless, it is quite clear that individuals within the Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries have been subjected to some scrutiny. I think that all members of this House would really like our large marketing corporation for primary products to be in a situation in which the industry, the producers and the Parliament know what is going on. We would like a situation in which these sorts of questions did not arise and such matters were put beyond debate. We have seen a range of organisations and marketing corporations, such as the Grain Elevators Board of New South Wales, the Australian Wheat Board and a whole range of statutory authorities at Federal and State levels, in which errors of judgment have been apparent. There have been quite a few cases of absolute negligence.

Although some political commentators outside this House say that they would like to see politicians out of the areas of agricultural policy and agricultural marketing, I believe that as long as the Commonwealth has the export powers and we are exporting our primary products, as long as the farmers invite the Parliament, the politicians or government-call it what you will-into their industries and need the public purse for underwriting, stabilisation or whatever, it is incumbent on all members of this House and the Senate to make sure that proper procedures of accountability prevail. It simply is not good enough to say that farmers should control all aspects of marketing. They simply cannot do everything themselves and so organisations are set up. When those organisations have powers which are delegated by parliaments, it is up to us to scrutinise them.

I hope that the allegations being made about ADI and Holland Milk Products Industries Inc. and the fact that we may have breached international agreements will be put behind us when the Senate report comes out. I am still critical of the fact that the one matter which the Minister has said is outstanding has taken so long. I hope this is not a reflection on the Australian Federal Police and that one day the Minister will be able to make a full statement on the matter to the House. This inquiry places yet more tension, more stress, on the industry, and I hope that the Minister will see and acknowledge that the sooner this is all cleaned up the better for the industry; otherwise, we will not get people with the competence we need to handle the dairy industry's affairs. It is absolutely essential that these matters are cleaned up so that the industry can get on with the job. Quite frankly, what has happened in the past within these organisations is not as important now as is looking to the future of the dairy industry and trying to decide where it should go from here. I have itemised a whole heap of stresses, as have the honourable member for MacMillan and the honourable member for Lyne, and I think they are the issues to which policy makers at the Federal and State levels should address themselves.

The industry is at a turning point in many ways. The concerns of the producers in the industry are very real. They are particularly intense in Victoria at present. I believe that we should be directing our minds to the positive aspects of the problems which dairy producers face rather than continuing an investigation month after month into a marketing organisation, the Australian Dairy Corporation, and into things that happened years ago. I think it is essential that that investigation go on but it is just as essential that we wind it up as quickly as we possibly can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Firstly, I thank the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for their contributions to the debate. They all made very reasoned and thoughtful speeches relating to the problems of the industry. The honourable member for McMillan asked whether the Australian Dairy Corporation has the power to import butter for sale on the Australian domestic market. I think he took the positive point of view and stated that it does not. That is correct. Any power on importation relates to individual companies. The role of the Australian Dairy Corporation in relation to any importing of dairy products is only a co-ordinating one. I can say only that I believe the various companies and organisations engaged in the industry are wise enough to recognise the need for the ADC to be used at any time in a co-ordinating way.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the whole question is hypothetical. As the honourable member for Werriwa rightly said, there were errors in the estimation of product. Of course, this was largely brought about by the seasonal conditions throughout Australia. As he pointed out, the eastern part of Australia suffered perhaps the worst drought it has had for a great number of years. This affected seriously the volume of production available that would have normally made up the estimates on which the ADC relied. The second factor is that there has been a very successful promotion of sales of butter and cheese. In particular, reports of increasing sales of butter are pleasing. It seems that people are at long last waking up to the fact that the claims made by some people about the use of butter and heart disease have been stretched beyond all imagination. Consumers are coming back to a very good product.

I thought the honourable member for McMillan was a little depressing in his prognostications about the future of the industry. Those in the industry know that the difficulties they have gone through in the past years far outweigh any that lie in front of them. I think we can be reasonably optimistic about the future of the industry rather than negative. I do not believe there is a need for the pessimism exhibited by the honourable member for McMillan about the future. There always have been and there always will be problems in the dairy industry as in other industries. I do not know that there will ever be a time when there will not be some problem facing the dairy farmer and other agricultural industries throughout this nation.

Let me deal in short compass with one or two of those problems. The first relates to underwriting. I am in discussion at the moment with the industry on a longer term underwriting proposal. For too long underwriting has been bound up in an ad hoc annual estimate of what the industry expects and what it ought to get. I want to get away from that and adopt a more mathematical approach that is more satisfying to the industry and which is more sensible. I believe we will get there given the co-operation that is being extended to me in the discussions at this point. I welcome the words of the honourable member for Werriwa in relation to the question of closer economic relations with New Zealand. It would seem that the Opposition and the Government are very close on this matter. Both are prepared to work towards closer economic relations but both realise that there are difficulties facing particular industries that will need to be worked out equitably before closer economic relations can be achieved.

Another matter that the honourable member for Werriwa raised related to the outstanding questions concerning Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. As I said in answer to a question in the House on Tuesday, I cannot determine the timetable for the completion of the report I am expecting. However, I share his view that the sooner it is in my hands and the sooner a statement can be made clarifying all the issues that have flowed out of this problem, the sooner the industry will be satisfied and the sooner I, as the Minister, will be satisfied. Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for allowing honourable members to range over issues far beyond the nature of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Nixon) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED VINE FRUITS STABILIZATION LEGISLATION REPEAL BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bil be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill 1981, the Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill 1981 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1981 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
-Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these four measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. They are consistent with the Government's policy of converting from stabilisation to underwriting with respect to our export horticultural industries in accordance with the principle that stabilisation does not expose industries to the full impact of overseas prices for our products whereas underwriting does. Economists have a cute term for this. They refer to market signals. By and large that is what it means. Stabilisation, particularly the scheme operating for apples, inherently required the Government to pay in more than the industry could ever have been expected to pay in. The horticultural industries have been subject to Industries Assistance Commision inquiries over the years. Their problems are well understood.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill actually repeals the stabilisation measures without putting up the underwriting scheme that will be introduced. One can say quite clearly at this stage that an underwriting scheme will be introduced. I understand that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and the Department are in discussion with the industry at present. The Bill before the House relates to the termination of the present dried vine fruits stabilisation scheme. The scheme applies to dried sultanas produced in 1978, 1979 and 1980 and provides for grower contributions to a stabilisation fund, if the average return received by growers in a season is above the established seasonal base price plus $10 a tonne. If the average return for the season is more than $10 a tonne below the base price, payments are to be made to growers out of the fund.

Growers contributed approximately $1.2m to the fund in respect of the 1978 season. It has become clear with the prices being received that further significant payments will also be the ultimate result of the 1979 and 1980 seasons' returns from the accounting if the scheme were permitted to run its full course. This would not be of any advantage to the industry. In fact, it would be a clear disadvantage. It would deny growers the use of substantial moneys which, under the legislation, would have to be collected from them in due course for these two seasons as grower contributions to the fund. Growers would than have to await the winding up of the fund at the end of the stabilisation term before these moneys could not have been made before 1982. The Government has accepted a request from the industry that legislation be introduced to terminate the scheme and to authorise the refunding to contributing growers of moneys presently in the Sultanas Stabilization Fund. Interest has been accruing to the $1.2m that growers have paid in and this also will be returned. It is hoped that such repayment will take place during this year.

The industry overall is essentially confined to the Murray Valley irrigation areas between Swan Hill in Victoria and Cadell in South Australia. About half of the industry's 3,800 growers are in the Sunraysia region. Farmers producing multipurpose grapes at present do not have suitable alternative crops available. Farm size is small. The industry is heavily dependent on labour-intensive technology which, in the main restricts farm size to what can be handled by a family unit without the need to employ a full-time hand. A number of grape varieties are dried but the dominant variety is sultanas and the industry is dependent on irrigation. The more labour-intensive flood furrow techniques predominate.

The Industries Assistance Commission, in a series of four reports, made strong recommendations with respect to the Riverland. It is a pity that governments, both Federal and State, have not addressed themselves properly to the recommendations in those reports, particularly in regard to reconstruction in that region. Growers there face quite a few long term problems. The volume of grapes available for drying in 1981 is expected to decline by about 28 per cent to 280 kilotonnes from the near record production of last year, but that estimate was made by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics before the current harvest began. I understand that there have been adverse weather conditions during the last few critical weeks of drying and that in some areas crops are down by 50 per cent. Thus, we do not yet really know how much less than last year's record crop this year's crop will be. Dried vine fruits production is notoriously difficult to predict because it also depends on the intake of multipurpose grapes by wineries and distilleries. On average this has increased by 4 per cent or 5 per cent annually over the last few years. However, last year the intake increased by 25 per cent, to 141 kilotonnes. As far as we know at present, for 1981 the dry weight equivalent of the forecast 280 kilotonnes-I am quite sure that that figure will now be lower-will be about 70 kilotonnes. That is less than last year's extremely high level. Gross value of production this year is expected to be between $80m and $90m; so it is a reasonably large industry that is concentrated in one area of Australia. Its prosperity or otherwise has a decided regional impact, and on three Federal electorates in particular.

About 41 kilotonnes of the total dried vine fruits pack is expected this year to be directed to export markets. However, if we assume an average crop-and as I have said already it will be a little below average-it will nevertheless be about 40 per cent down on that available for export last season. In this situation the unit return to Australian growers from exports is forecast to increase only sightly. Over the last year, as is shown by the very fact that we have a surplus in the 1978 fund, overseas prices have been near the price obtainable internally. This is not a typical situation. The indications are that world production of dried vine fruits will be a little lower also.

One matter that is concerning the industry is the entry of Greece to the European Economic Community but, again, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has reported that its impact upon dried vine fruits producers, or multipurpose grape producers, is not likely to be extreme. On the other hand, at any stage the EEC can change its mind on some of these matters and doubtless the industry is concerned about what could happen in that regard. By and large, this is a straightforward measure and one which the Opposition does not oppose.

The Bills which relate to the apple and pear industries are more complex and are concerned with both the phasing out of stabilisation over four years and the phasing in of underwriting during the same period-taking into account the fact that other measures apply to this industry. I am glad that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is now present in the chamber. When the matter was last debated the Opposition moved an amendment to have the stabilisation payment increased to $3 a box. The Government proposed to raise the amount by a whopping 20c from $2 to $2.20. Of course, the Opposition was accused of playing cynical politics, but some of the comments of Government supporters on that occasion are very interesting. For example, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who is now the Minister for the Capital Territory, at one stage advised the Opposition that it would not know the difference between a crofton and a geeveston fanny. I am still trying to find out what a geeveston fanny is.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good apple.

—I thank the honourable member. Also, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman), as is reported at page 1130 of Hansard of 19 September 1978, advised the House that he had not been locked in a toilet. The honourable member for Mr Murray (Mr Lloyd) then said: 'Let us get away from toilets for a minute and get back to the question of apples'. Having been thus enlightened, I think I should do likewise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Apple and Pear Stabilization Amendment Bill really concerns a winding down process and follows very closely the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. This industry has undergone quite a bit of reconstruction. Although I have not been able to obtain the exact figures, the expenditure for that purpose during the years 1973-1978 was very large. For each of the 1981-1985 export seasons separate guaranteed minimum return levels will be established by this Bill for apple and pear exports. The guaranteed minimum returns will be determined by calculating 95 per cent of the weighted average per box free-on-board return for all apple exports and for all pear exports over the figure for the immediately preceeding four export seasons. I understand that the industry would have preferred a level of 120 per cent rather than 95 per cent but the IAC recommended about 80 per cent. Still, by and large, the industry is satisfied with what the Government is doing in this matter.

At the close of each export season, there is to be a determination of the average per box f.o.b. export return for all apple exports in the season. The same is to be done in regard to pears. In the event that either of these average per box f.o.b. returns falls below the relevant guaranteed minimum return an underwriting payment is to be made. Such payment will be the difference between the guaranteed minimum return and the relevant average per box f.o.b. return. In the case of fruit exported at risk, underwriting payments will be made to the owner at the time of export. In the case of fruit sold before export, they will be paid to the owners of the fruit prior to that sale. I think I can work out what that means.

In addition to the underwriting arrangements for apples and pears, and the continuance of the stabilisation scheme for apples on a phasing out basis over the four years to 1984, the Commonwealth is to continue to provide supplementary assistance on a dollar for dollar basis with participating States over that period. The Commonwealth commitment is for a maximum of $3m over the period in respect of apples, and $800,000 in respect of pears.

The use of the assistance is to be flexible and is to be available to fund orchard reconstruction and related adjustment measures by growers particularly affected by the changed marketing support arrangements for at risk exports. It may also be used to provide additional at risk export price support assistance for apples, but not for pears. The Government has placed a ceiling of 750,000, and a maximum payout per box of $2.20, on Commonwealth funds used in 1981 to supplement export price support for apples. These maximums will be reduced by one-quarter in each of the three succeeding years, again following Industries Assistance Commission recommendations. The Commonwealth is currently discussing with the States proposals on the form and amount of supplementary assistance to be provided.

The Apple and Pear Stabilisation Scheme was introduced in 1971 and at that stage it covered only apples and pears exported at some degree of risk to the owner. Prior to 1976 it covered all exports sold at risk, but since then it has been limited to apples sold at risk to Europe and to pears sold at risk to Europe and North America. Support prices for each variety exported were set in 1971 and since then they have been indexed forward by changes in cash costs of production and no adjustments have been made to varietal support prices for changes in market returns for individual varieties. The level of assistance for apple and pear sales covered by the scheme has been, subject to certain limits, the difference between the support price for each variety and the corresponding varietal average free-on-board return for all export sales both at risk and forward. The limits in any one year have been a maximum support payout per box and a maximum total payout on all apples and pears.

Separate stabilisation funds have operated for each variety. When average varietal returns for all sales have exceeded the varietal support price, owners of fruit sold at risk have paid into that varietal fund on a sliding scale basis. If there has been insufficient money in a varietal fund for a required payout, the Commonwealth Government has made up the deficiency. Over the period, the Commonwealth has paid in quite an amount; I think it is about $22.4m. The maximum level of potential assistance available through the stabilisation scheme and supplementary assistance has exceeded the level of assistance paid out in most years. Between 1971 and 1979 about $50m was available to the industries for support but only about $31m was paid out. Of the $31m paid out, $30m was paid to the apple industry and $1m to the pear industry. Around two-thirds of the assistance paid to the apple industry was received by Tasmania and a quarter was received by Western Australia. The bulk of the assistance received by the pear industry was received by Victoria.

I have tried to point out the mechanism of the existing stabilisation scheme, which had the inherent characteristic of government payouts exceeding grower payins. Payouts from the apple and pear varietal stabilisation funds have totalled $22.4m since 1971. In part, that has been as a result of varietal support prices for apples being generally higher than average varietal returns for all export sales and in part as a result of exporters having inducement under the stabilisation scheme to avoid payins by shipping less fruit at risk when market prices are high or expected to be high. In the absence of the stabilisation scheme and supplementary assistance, growers would have found it more profitable to divert some fruit sold at risk to other markets, including processing, or to grow a new varietal mix removing those varieties which have depended on assistance in most years. I could speak at length about this but I do not have time to go through the whole mechanism of the scheme. All governments have tried to give a measure of support and stabilisation to the apple and pear industry at the same time as they have engaged in policies to have the industry reconstructed. These measures were started before the Labor Government of 1972-75. They continued during that period and have continued since, so there is no disagreement between the parties on this question.

By and large, the Opposition accepts and welcomes what the Government is doing. However, honourable members should note what I have said about the stabilisation scheme having the inherent characteristic of the Government paying in a lot more than the industry. The underwriting scheme we are now phasing in has the same potential for that if export prices drop. On a four-year calculation, over four seasons, the underwriting scheme will protect the industry, cushion it particularly well, against sudden drops on the export market. In this way, even though there is potential for the Government to pay in a lot of money, at least it will be paid in evenly and at all times it will cushion the industry. That seems to me to be a reasonably sensible measure. No one can calculate how much the Government may have to pay in, but as long as the industry continues to reconstruct in the ways it has been, and as long as this supplementary assistance is also directed into further reconstruction, in another five or eight years the amount the Government pays into this industry will be quite minimal and the industry will be fully reconstructed. I suppose the term 'reconstruction' in the apple and pear industry means that many trees have been pulled out.

The current year is an 'on' year in the biennial bearing cycle in the mainland States. This will result in more apples being made available for all outlets. One of the worries about the at risk and other markets with the new arrangements is that more apples might move onto the Sydney and Melbourne markets from Tasmania, but at this stage we cannot predict exactly what factors will prevail and what decisions growers will make. It is almost impossible to predict that. Total Australian production is a lot less than it used to be but, even so, it will be over 300 kilotonnes this year. Bearing tree numbers for apples are expected to remain at around 5.2 million trees. Increased availability of apples as it is the on year might result in about 185 kilotonnes coming on to the domestic fresh market. That is a rise of about 12 per cent. Shipments from Tasmania to mainland markets should fall below the level of last year as Tasmania is expected to experience an off year. Projections of past trends suggest that the total fresh apple consumption over the medium term could lie in the range of 160 to 180 kilotonnes a year. This implies a declining consumption per person.

Exports this year are expected to total about 45 kilotonnes, which is only slightly up because the off year in Tasmania will limit supplies of export quality fruit. The overseas supply situation is that the 1980 European apple crop again was above average, but it was slightly below the crop of the year before. Approximately 25 kilotonnes of Australian apples could be expected to go to the United Kingdom and European markets. This is the classic at risk market. However, the possibility of high European Economic Community stocks of stored fruit at the beginning of the 1981 importing season, increased competition from Chile, South Africa and New Zealand and increases in freight rates will mean lower returns than those achieved in 1980. United Kingdom and French problems arising out of the EEC Common Agricultural Policy could see fewer French apple sales in the United Kingdom and that may provide opportunities for southern hemisphere exports. Australia has a geographic advantage in Asian markets. New Zealand could be Australia's major competitor in the region. Shipments of Australian apples to this region in 1981 should be similar to those of 1980.

The implementation of this underwriting scheme, along with the phasing out of the stabilisation scheme which will operate for the 1981-84 seasons, will enable producers and marketers to adjust more gradually to changes on the export market. As I have just pointed out, the export market is notoriously difficult to predict but this set of measures will enable the returns to growers to be cushioned and evened out. Whilst providing some degree of security against sharp falls in export prices, an underwriting scheme is likely to result in the diversion of fruit from at risk markets. Diversion to the processing sector, particularly in the expected on years of 1981-83, could result in lower average real returns for apples because of the lowering of the price paid for processing apples. Placing more Tasmanian fruit on mainland markets may not seriously affect the fresh fruit prices if the Tasmanian on year coincides with an off year for the mainland.

In 1983 and later, if adjustment has not occurred, large quantities of Tasmanian fruit could be placed on mainland markets in on years, reducing prices paid to both Tasmanian and mainland growers. Development of new forward markets could enable previously at risk fruit to gain more remunerative prices. The longer term developments in grower incomes will thus depend on the actual diversions and adjustments made by growers, demand conditions and the effects that such changes will have on prices in the various markets. It is a rather complicated set of measures, particularly the mechanisms for paying in and paying out and for the phasing out of stabilisation, but, as I have said, the Government's moves square very closely with the IAC recommendations. I think the last report on the apple and pear industry was delivered last year. The Opposition puts forward no objections to the legislation. We welcome it and also look forward to the future of these great industries.

The only other matter which I should like to mention relates to some lobbying by the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association with respect to the number of people on the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. For a while the South Australian and Queensland producers who produce only for the domestic market have been annoyed by the fact that they do not have State representatives on the Corporation. The Minister has agreed that the four places on the Corporation will be expanded to six. I understand that he is not prepared to say that the two extra people should come from South Australia and Queensland but I think that by making this concession he has indicated his concern or agreement with the industry case that there is room for every State to be represented on the Corporation. If that is in his mind, the Opposition welcomes it. The Opposition commends these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) on a very thoughtful address. I am always pleased to participate in cognate debates of this kind. From the outset I would like to congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), who is sitting at the table, for the expert job that he has done in assisting in the reconstruction of a very vital industry particularly, if I may be a little parochial, in Tasmania. The apple industry means a lot to Tasmania. I believe that the apple is symbolic of Tasmania. I am not one of the supporters who believes that we should try to change the image of Tasmania. I am in complete support of the casino and of the casino in the north and other attractions that Tasmania may have but the Tasmanian people should never forget that Tasmania virtually has been put on the map by the apple.
—They have not forgotten how you represent them either.

—Of course, my good friend the honourable member for Wilmot draws attention to that fact. He is a very good representative of the apple growers in the north of the State, which is a very important part of the apple growing area of Tasmania. Tasmania is known throughout the world as the apple isle. Apples and the export of apples, not only to the mainland of Australia but also overseas, have been a very important part of the economy of Tasmania. In the past I may have been, to a degree, critical of some of the functions of the Industries Assistance Commission. I have often thought that members of the IAC were a pack of armchair theorists but I am starting to change my mind. The Minister for Primary Industry is smiling and I am sure that he will not go crook at me for saying that. Sometimes people like to think that they know everything about everything but in fact they know very little; they read a book and they seem to think that they can do everything from a book. But that remark does not apply to the members of the IAC. I take back my previous comments about them. I was young, enthusiastic and I let my head go when making some remarks in those early days. The members of the IAC have done a dashed good job and they have been able to reconstruct the industry to a level which I believe will be in the interests of the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said on other occasions that it saddens me to see a reduction in production in the Huon Valley, the home of apples in Tasmania. Incidentally, it is in my electorate of Franklin. I, and many other Tasmanians such as the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr), the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom), the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who is from the north of the State, saw the demise of the apple and pear industry in the Huon Valley in particular. It saddened us to see such a reduction in production and the almost desperate decision in 1973 to create what is now the famous tree-pull scheme which enabled orchardists to stay on their own land and to meet their urgent financial commitments at that time. Of course, the scheme probably was brought in out of desperation. When the scheme was introduced in October 1975, 40 per cent of the total tree area was removed. Admittedly, some of the trees were old. It is not my intention to criticise governments but the orchardists at that time must have been wondering in which direction they should turn. They have now answered the call for efficiency in the packing shed and sometimes-this is well known-they have worked themselves to a standstill to sustain an industry that has been their life and their livelihoods. They combated spiralling costs of labour and materials coupled with high transportation costs. Of course, they had to put up with the elements-the varying climatic conditions-and the problems of transportation. But they have now won through and they should be applauded by every city dweller who goes into a shop, a greengrocer or a supermarket to buy an apple.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I had that dinner break. To a certain degree it has ruined my train of thought on that very important symbol of Tasmania-the apple. Every time a person buys an apple in a supermarket, a shop or elsewhere, he should think very carefully about the farmer who has produced it. People must realise that the continuation of the industry in Tasmania has meant a lot of heartaches and problems. The people who faced those changes stood up to them and have come back fighting. That is why the apple industry in Tasmania today is as good as it was some 10 or 12 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that apple exports fell sharply from a peak of about 150,000 tonnes in 1971 to about 88,000 tonnes in 1975. Freight rates increased dramatically during that period, and the Tasmanian people should be aware of how vital the apple industry now is to the economy of Tasmania. It employs about 2 per cent of the total population and contributes approximately 11 per cent of the Tasmanian gross value of agricultural production. About one-third of all apples grown in Australia are produced in Tasmania. Tasmania supplies two-thirds of the total Australian export trade. If I sound a little Tasmanian I do not make any apology for it. The most important single form of assistance given, and this is what the Bill is about, is through the Apple and Pear Stabilisation Scheme. This is the scheme restructured by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), who is at the table. I may have been a little critical five or six years ago, but I am not critical any more because the Minister had the interests of the apple industry at heart. He restructured it, with the assistance of others, to make it the viable industry that it is today. I repeat that the most important single form of assistance is the stabilisation scheme, and in the short time available to me tonight I would like to elaborate on that scheme.

I and a lot of other Tasmanians, including the honourable member for Braddon, realise that there would be a horrific situation if the apple industry in Tasmania came to a stop. The returns flow right through the economy into transportation, labour, and the money that comes to Tasmania as a result of exporting a fine variety of apples. The Tasmanian Labor Government is making stupid decisions, and I believe that it is being caught. It cannot make positive decisions and it cannot see that Tasmania is unique. It is pondering, starting to equivocate on certain things, and it is losing support and making the people of Tasmania hesitant. If the State Government does not heed the warning then it will lose government. I only hope that the Opposition down there wakes up and starts fighting a little harder for Tasmania and the people. If it does, then Tasmania once again will be a great State. It will be referred to with pride. It is the Apple Isle. It is the isle that produces the best apples in the world. It is the State that offers the most beautiful, scenic spots in the world, and I refer specifically to the Huon Valley.

I think that a lot of politicians should realise that the only way people can come to Tasmania is by air. It is most important for people to realise that we are dependent on air services. We have no ships, and we cannot drive cars across Bass Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —No bridge.
—There is no bridge. People should realise, if they want us as part of Australia, that we are in a difficult situation. We were the pioneers of Victoria. Mr Hamer is starting to talk about Tasmania.
—He hates Tasmania.
—What has this got to do with apples?
—I will deal now with the by-products of apples. They all hate Tasmania, for some unknown reason. Somebody asked me whether I had two heads.
—Order! I ask honourable members to remain silent. The honourable member for Franklin will get back to the core of the Bill.
—I come back to the stabilisation Bill. We should have an extension of it. We should realise that the by-products of apples are most important.
—Cider.
—Exactly-cider, apple cider, apple wine.
—Cider vinegar.
—Cider vinegar.
—Apple pies.

—Apple pies. It is not a joking matter, it is a serious matter. Unfortunately the people of Tasmania have allowed the symbol of Tasmania to slip away. We say: 'Come to Tasmania to see the casino. Come to Tasmania to see Port Arthur'. It is the Apple Isle, and people should realise that we depend on the apple. That is our symbol.
—What about Adam?

—Eve was tempted by Adam. I notice that the Minister has on his apple tie. He is proud to be a Tasmanian, and he should not refer to Adam and the apple. Apple cider, apple wine and apple pies could all be promoted. Every passenger who comes to Tasmania should see this very simple slogan: 'You may smile, you are now in the Apple Isle'. Some may smile at the slogan and say that it is stupid, but it is something very simple to attract people to Tasmania. They should be given an apple when they arrive and there should be an apple in their motel room. Promotion is terribly important, and it is the only way that a place can be sold. People are too negative. I am afraid that some of the Tasmanian people seem to think that the apple can be taken for granted. I hope honourable members agree that we should do more about promoting the apple. I am a firm believer in that. On Tuesday, 15 March 1977, when the Queen was visiting Tasmania, the Daily Telegraph carried an article under the heading 'It's apples for Queen in Tasmania' which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The pressure is right off the Queen on the happy apple isle. Tasmania has presented no problems, friendly crowds, no hints of demonstrations and the almost leisurely program of the tour.

It is apples all the time. In biblical times the apple was referred to as a symbol of purity, goodness and friendliness. I believe that with a few positive decisions, with a few politicians of fortitude who are prepared to stand up for Tasmania and not be influenced by some of the mainlanders, the apple could make Tasmania once again a great State. I quote from a 1931 document about Tasmania which states:

Fruitgrowing proves of paramount importance to Tasmania, not only on account of the large export trade, but also because the money received is distributed amongst many small holders and in consequence is circulated more than in the case of any industry. Tasmania is particularly adapted to the growing of fruit. That is, of course, for the production of temperature fruits such as apples, pears, plums, apricots, cherries, raspberries, etc. In fact, every fruit which is grown in England seems to thrive still better in Tasmania.

It is like our cricketers; we do better in Tasmania. Even today our young Boone is trying to get selection for the Australian team. The document says: 'It is apples for Tasmania'. We always refer to apples but we do not stand by them. As politicians who represent Tasmania, we should. My friends the honourable member for Denison, the honourable member for Braddon, the honourable member for Wilmot and I all stand by apples. We need to make certain that we promote them in this House. It is no use mucking around with it. We need to fight. Today the Sydney market is most important to the Tasmanian grower. New Zealand was at one time a very promising market and shipments were made occasionally to Rio de Janeiro and Cape Town. I am still referring to the 1931 article to let honourable members know that the industry did not start today. The apply industry started 90 years ago, and much hard effort has been put into it. The English export trade began in 1884 with a trial shipment to London of 100 cases. That was our first shipment, on the S.S. Warwick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this?

—I wrote it. It was not until 1887 that shipments were made to any extent. In that year 4,000 cases were taken by the Orient Steam Navigation Company. After that several Convent Garden firms directed their representatives to come to Tasmania as agents and they have stayed ever since. Tasmanian apples now find their way to all the important markets of the world. I would like to thank the Government Whip, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) for bringing in that lovely apple. I do not think that it is a Tasmanian one but it is not too bad. It is cold too. The industry started in those years has boomed.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody should realise that this assistance which is given through the Apple and Pear Stabilization Act and the underwriting of returns from all export market sales of apples and pears is of vital importance to the economy. We do not ask for anything. We do not want to subsidise some of the strikes that occur in the mainland. Everybody seems to criticise Tasmania. People say that we get too much from Victoria. We subsidise the motor industry-we subsidise all the industries. But when we get a little to assist an ailing apple industry, people say that too much is going to Tasmania. The great Premier of Victoria, Mr Hamer, criticises Tasmania; Tasmanians settled Victoria. The stabilisation legislation after making vital changes has enabled the industry to get back on to its feet. It is now starting to thrive. The people who objected to this scheme originally must now say that they were wrong and that the thoughtfulness and original planning of the Government has been to the advantage of the fruit growing industry in Tasmania.

I am pleased to relate that the industry now has a highly skilled and effective national organisation that has come to grips with the marketing problems that have beset it. Many experts, including those in government and industry, have come forward with recommendations for a continuing viable industry. Some have taken into consideration that fact that it should be restructured. Some have looked also at social considerations. I believe we have been able to pinpoint the problems. They have not been the problems of growers. The apple growers of Tasmania are the best in the world. They have been muddled by bureaucracy and by other people who seem to think that they know all about marketing. That ruined them to a degree but they have been able to come to grips with these problems and the industry is now a very viable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Red tape.

—It was because of red tape. I have said before that Tasmanian orchardists are among the finest in the world. They are able to compete in respect of quality. The only reason some of the mainland marketers get very upset about Tasmanian apples is that if we put our apples on the market we would outdo them because our apples are of better quality.
—The hard core apple.

—I do not know much about the hard core apple. Tasmanian orchardists are able to compete in terms of quality on any given market. The reason for so much controversy from other growers in Australia is their fear that Tasmanian apples may glut the mainland markets. It is a fear only of quality. The stabilisation scheme and the ability of growers to export Tasmanian apples at a fair and reasonable price, returning a fair and reasonable profit for these hard-working orchardists should be defended and assisted by the mainland growers. If this is not done, the Tasmanian orchardist will find it necessary to look for alternative markets.
