In fact, growers may be forced to glut the mainland market in Australia, and as a consequence nobody would win. There would be once more complete pandemonium in the industry. But given the right incentive and the right direction, the industry once again will prove to be a valuable asset to the economy of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Apples are regarded as a delicacy in many countries. People regard them as a fruit that not only tastes good but also assists in a healthy diet. Many markets in the world are crying out for good quality apples. People marketing apples from Australia should seek out even more markets than they do at present. They should seek out markets which have been disregarded in the past. In Taiwan apples sell at $1 each. They are regarded as a delicacy. The honourable member for Denison who was one of the best representatives in the Tasmanian Legislative Council that the Huon has ever known would lament the fact that thousands of apples have gone to waste when many people in the world are starving. A lot of people talk about poverty but unfortunately we can never direct some of these valuable food resources to those people in need.

It has been said on many occasions that if EZ Industries Ltd-a lot of people in Tasmania depend on the company-and the apple industry failed it would be the end of Hobart. Honourable members must realise that when I talk I may sometimes smile or make a joke but this industry is a very important one to Tasmania. The scheme and the principle of the Apple and Pear Stabilization Act are an extension of earlier schemes and are designed to cover apple exports. My friend, the honourable member for Werriwa explained the Bills we are debating in great detail. I hope the Minister for Primary Industry who is sitting at the table has learned a little about the situation in Tasmania. He has been a very good Minister. I wish the Tasmanian orchardists a very good year this year. The freight equalisation scheme has proven to be an important asset to the apple industry. I only hope that a scheme such as this can be extended to air fares so that we can get cheap air fares to Tasmania on a freight equalisation basis. The industry is important to Australia. It is most important to Tasmania.

I end my speech with a sincere wish that the orchardists in Tasmania and Australia have a very good season which will give them a fair return for their work. They are not interested in socialism or in other ways and means of producing apples. They are interested only in working hard, making a profit, trying to provide an income and a way of life for their families and work for the people whom they employ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to send my greetings to the people of Tasmania and wish them all the best for this year. I hope that they have a very good season with their apples. Now that we have got down to the core of the matter, perhaps we can proceed. By agreeing to underwrite the apple and pear export returns in each season at 95 per cent of the weighted average return for the four immediately preceding seasons, the Government shows commendable concern for the welfare of this section of primary industry. Honourable members on this side of the House also commend the Government for its decision to provide a phasing out period for the supplementary assistance arrangements to cushion the immediate detrimental effects of the change in the nature of financial support. As a result of restructuring within the industry and the changing patterns of marketing apples and pears, measures taken in recent years to maintain stability within the industry have led to some distortions in the pattern of returns to producers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fitting that having been treated to a very comical 20 minutes from the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) that perhaps we should at least get back to the subject matter of the Bills before the House. Honourable members will be aware that the stabilisation scheme and supplementary assistance have provided incentives that have directed sales towards at-risk markets with too little consideration given to changes in market preferences. The effects of this process have led to the formation of a structure in this industry that is out of line with market demands. It is not only out of line with market demands but also it is out of line with seasonal variables. This has slowed down the response of growers to market realities. Under a more apt system of assistance to the industry the growers might have been redirecting market activities to other markets or restructuring their own production by re-arranging their varietal mix. The Industries Assistance Commission report of 28 March entitled 'Apples and Pears' has this to say in its summary and conclusions on page III:

By diverting apples and pears to the less profitable 'at-risk' export sales, the Stabilisation Scheme and Supplementary Assistance have reduced incentives to develop new markets, and have discriminated against the processing sector in some years.

For some varieties, assistance has been used to subsidise exports at a considerable loss, whereas processors would in some years have been able to utilise the fruit at prices which would have required little if any support from government to bring farm gate returns up to the final payment they would have received 'at-risk' sales including various forms of assistance.

Because the Government's financial commitment to the stabilisation scheme and supplementary assistance scheme has remained unchanged since 1976 and, of course, was less in real terms, there has been no desirable reduction in the fluctuations in prices and incomes. Generally, like the Government itself, the scheme has outlived its usefulness. It is to be hoped that the process of rearranging assistance to the apple and pear industry by way of an underwriting arrangement should provide some stability for the industry to assist it to ride out the vagaries of export market fluctuations and seasonal variations.

We on this side of the House support the phasing out of the stabilisation scheme and support also the underwriting arrangements as proposed. The need for government action to protect important industry is indeed worthy of recognition by this Government. Free enterprise is not the undiluted system that the Government so monotonously pronounces it to be. That is probably the Government's ideal, but the reality is more likely to be something which is closer to the sorts of things which we, believing in a mixed economy, would propose. Public protestations, extolling a phoney adherence to the myth that this nation is or can be an undiluted example of private enterprise, bring no credit to this Government.

Government funded projects that are aimed at ensuring the viability of an important industry of this kind gain our support as they enable a large number of people to be maintained in stable employment, including people employed in service industries in areas such as the Goulburn Valley in Victoria, an area which would be deleteriously affected if such projects were not introduced. In an area such as Ballarat, which electorate I am proud to represent, there is a number of orchards growing primarily apples. It is not a large area. I might say, inter alia, that I have some expert knowledge of the excellence of the qualities of these apples. I do not claim that they are as plentiful as apples in Tasmania; but I must say that I thoroughly enjoy their quality. It would be sad if the livelihood of these orchardists were to be jeopardised by an inefficient system of income support. I think it must be recognised that, whilst we are primarily talking about export industry, we are talking also about the flow on to the domestic market.

Many jobs are maintained and family life supported by these orchards. The measures proposed in the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill should help to continue the maintenance of these jobs. We on this side of the House hope that this Government will be equally diligent in providing adequate programs of support for those other industries which are crucial to the maintenance of jobs and hence family living standards. We are aware, however, of the double standards of this Government, and so are the people of this country. For the army of the unemployed who will not benefit from measures such as those proposed to support the apple and pear industry, the Government has obviously very little sympathy. They are the victims of a policy of harsh judgments. Cutbacks in the Community Youth Support Scheme programs such as that which occurred in Ballarat are a cruel example of the partiality of this Government and its callous indifference towards the most vulnerable members of our society. As I said, we on this side of the House support the Bill. We hope that the Government will also develop positive policies that give similar sympathetic treatment to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four Bills that we are discussing tonight represent in my view a further example of this Government's commitment to agriculture and primary producers. I congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) on the introduction of these Bills so early in the new session. For a few moments I turn to the two Bills which, as far as my electorate of Mallee is concerned, have much more relevance. They are the Bills which relate to the dried fruit industry. The Dried Vine Fruits Stabilization Legislation Repeal Bill seeks to terminate the operation of the present dried fruit stabilisation scheme. As the Minister for Primary Industry said in his second reading speech, growers have contributed some $1.2m to the stabilisation fund in respect of the 1978 season. It has been assessed that further significant payments would also be the ultimate result of the 1979 and 1980 seasons accounting if the scheme were permitted to run its full course. Therefore, as a member representing some 80 per cent of the dried fruit industry of Australia, I believe this Bill will be of significant advantage to the industry. If it had not been introduced, growers would have been denied the use of substantial money which under the legislation would have had to be collected from them in due course for the two seasons I have mentioned as the grower contributions to the fund. If that had happened growers would then have had to wait for the winding up of the fund at the end of the stabilisation term before these moneys could be refunded to them. Such refunds could probably not have been made before well into 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government and the Minister have therefore accepted a request from the industry that legislation be introduced to terminate the scheme and to authorise the refund to contributing growers of the moneys presently in the sultana stabilisation fund. As the second reading speech states, the moneys contributed by the growers in respect of the 1978 season have been invested, the last maturity date of such investments being 1 October 1981. After consultation with the growers' organisation-the Australian Dried Fruit Corporation-the Government has therefore made provision in this Bill for the investments to continue until their maturity. In this way a considerable amount of interest will be earned and no risk will be incurred of loss of capital value through early redemption. After these investments have matured, all moneys standing to the credit of the fund are to be distributed among growers in proportion to each growers share of the total contributed by the growers. I think it is reasonable to state also that at the present time further discussions are proceeding with the industry and with the Australian Dried Fruit Corporation which are designed to conclude mutually acceptable provisions for an underwriting of the scheme commencing with the 1982 season.

In many ways, 1980 will be remembered by the Australian dried fruit growers as a vintage year. Both prices and production have been at record or near record levels. Total production was 98,000 tonnes which is a near record while export prices for sultanas have been between some $1,500 a tonne and $1,650 a tonne. Whilst it is not a reflection on the Government in power at the time, I just mention that in 1972, when I first represented the electorate of Mallee and this industry, export prices were some $260 a tonne. That fact gives honourable members some idea of the tremendous progress that has been made by the Australian dried fruit industry in promoting exports and, of course, making progress in relation to the expansion of export markets.

Last month I was able to visit the Robinvale packing shed, which is one of the larger sultana packing sheds in my electorate. I learned that to date approximately 90 per cent of the 1980 season pack has been sold at the opening prices that I have mentioned. The unsold stock of some 2,000 tonnes of raisins and 8,000 tonnes of sultanas will be carried into this year and realistically I believe it may be necessary to accept slightly lower prices for this fruit. Nevertheless, 1980 was a good year and, if real estate values are any guide, there is plenty of confidence in the future. At the present time, a 20 acre fruit block in the Sunraysia district is selling somewhere around $130,000. As I said, the prospects for 1981 are good and much is going to depend on the success or otherwise of the harvest that is almost completed and a continuation of good export prices. Based on early crop estimates, this year's crop is expected to produce some 65,000 tonnes. However, because of unfavourable climatic conditions, particularly unseasonable rain in the sultana growing areas, this estimate of yield is probably down to about 40,000 tonnes to 45,000 tonnes. However, it is still going to be a good year for the dried fruit growing areas.

On the domestic market, sales of dried vine fruit have responded well to a very successful promotional campaign and have shown renewed growth in per capita consumption in recent years. At the present level of consumption, approxi- mately 25,000 tonnes per annum will be sold on the domestic market and this accounts for some 30 per cent to 40 per cent of fruit. There are some problems on the horizon in relation to the Australian dried fruit industry. Perhaps the most significant problem will be Greece's entry into the European Economic Community. Australian exports of sultanas to the EEC in 1980 totalled in excess of 30,000 tonnes or almost one half of total exports. Although Greece has traditionally supplied 20,000 tonnes to 25,000 tonnes of sultanas to the EEC annually, the prospect of Greece becoming a full EEC member has been a concern for some time. However, it is generally believed that Australia's exports will not be severely affected because at the present time two-thirds of Greece's exports of sultanas amounting approximately to 40,000 tonnes to 45,000 tonnes per annum go to eastern European countries. Any major diversion of that tonnage to the EEC could cause considerable disruption to established, and therefore Australian, trade with the EEC.

The outlook for increased world production of sultanas, apart from the entry of Greece into the EEC, is that the system of production aid for dried fruit producers will apply to all EEC members and the prospect of increased production by Greece and other EEC countries should not be ignored. There is a possibility of increased dried fruit production in Mexico. However, production has already reached some 20,000 tonnes per annum in that country and, with the limited availability of water and the prohibition on the sinking of further wells in the dried fruit regions, I do not see this as a threat to the Australian dried fruit industry. Over the last three or four years the Australian dried fruit growers have achieved considerable success in regulating their production and in meeting the markets that are available. I believe that they can look forward with optimism to their future, particularly as this Bill has now been introduced and discussions are under way for an underwriting scheme.

Most of the discussion tonight has been in relation to the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Bill. Tonight I shall speak on this Bill in lieu of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who is attending an agricultural meeting in the country. Having listened to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), recognising the tremendous interest he has in the apple and pear growing industries, I would like to make the point that these industries are not able to share the same optimism for the future as most of Australia's other agricultural industries. Under this Bill export underwriting will be provided for export market support and assistance will be based on recent export market price experience. I believe that this Bill will go some way towards ensuring the future viability of people involved in the apple and pear industries.

This Bill will set a guaranteed price at 95 per cent of average returns in the preceding four seasons. This is in contrast to the stabilisation scheme, which provided assistance on the basis of notional average cost of production factors indexed annually for inflation. This scheme has led in many years to support levels and export production being out of line with market demand realities. Therefore, underwriting is designed to provide support to growers in the event of a sudden downturn in the returns from the export market for either apples or pears. It will not provide ongoing assistance in the event of a sustained trend to lower market prices. The scheme will cover all apple and pear exports, unlike the stabilisation scheme which covers only at risk exports and provides a disincentive to the development of more profitable sales outlets. There is to be one guaranteed minimum return for all apple varieties and another for all pear varieties-a departure from the separate varietal support rates established under the stabilisation scheme. This will facilitate the structuring of a varietal production mix more in line with consumer preferences.

I think it is fair to point out that there has been some criticism of the scheme that we are now implementing. The Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association requested that the guarantee be set at 100 per cent of the average returns in the preceding two seasons. I know that the Western Australian Minister for Agriculture wished to have the guaranteed level calculated only from returns realised in the forward sales market, for the calculation to be in respect of the preceding two seasons only and for the average return to be indexed in some way. However, the level of 95 per cent of average returns was arrived at by the Industries Assistance Commission after suggesting in its draft report an 80 per cent level plus an allowance for movements in the consumer price index. This concept of adjusting for CPI movements was rejected by the IAC at a final report stage and levels of underwriting were raised to 95 per cent to compensate for that. The period of four years for calculating the guaranteed level of returns was considered most appropriate as it provided a more representative sample of export years. Of course, it will not allow a particularly bad or good season to influence unduly the guaranteed return.

As the underwriting is to apply to all exports it is appropriate that the guaranteed price be calculated in respect of all exports and not just forward sale exports. If the guaranteed price were based on forward sale returns it would increase the support given to growers who continue to produce for at risk markets only. In any debate such as this where a large percentage of exports goes to the EEC, I think we must recognise that it is of major concern that the overprotective policies of the European Economic Community apply to imports, particularly, of canned fruit-in this case pears. As if a combined import duty, an added sugar duty of around 25 per cent on most products, were not enough, there is also an import licensing system for canned fruit, particularly pears, and latterly production aids or subsidies for EEC producers of this product. Continual access to the EEC markets is of great importance to this industry, particularly for canned pears, which have traditionally been supplied to the United Kingdom and West Germany in substantial quantities.

The subsidies which have been introduced for EEC canners are generous by any standards. In 1979 and 1980 the subsidies represented over half the selling price of canned pears. With this level of incentive it is inevitable that production by both efficient and inefficient canners within the EEC will increase and eventually exclude third country suppliers, such as Australia. Notwithstanding the higher transport costs involved, Australian suppliers would be able to offer high quality fruit products to the EEC consumers at lower prices if it were not for the increasing protection that is being allowed to local manufacturers. If these policies are not checked and greatly reduced, the payment of high subsidies to the EEC pear canners will have a long term potential threat for third country suppliers, such as Australia. Production could be stimulated to a point where it is in excess of EEC requirements. With other commodities, such as dairy products and sugar, the EEC production aid policy has led to surpluses which have been dumped on world markets. Such a development would have most unfortunate consequences for the Australian canned fruit industry.

The industry, although active at the trade level, recognises that the most effective relief can be obtained through government to government negotiations. It is most important, therefore, that the Australian Government continues to liaise and negotiate with the EEC and its member countries to ensure that access for Australian canned fruit is improved or, at the worst, maintained at present levels. Although the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation believes that Australia's access to the EEC markets is logical and fair, other considerations enter into international negotiations. It is therefore of great importance that the needs of the Australian fruit industry be kept in mind by our Government in its overall relations with the EEC.

In spite of the continuing decline in the exports of apples and pears, world exports seem to have some type of appeal to many within the industry. Its future, no doubt, is questionable and the amount of money spent each year in the entire export area of apples and pears should be matched with the overall value to the industry. The payout by the Commonwealth Government over the past 10 years of approximately $22.5m in the form of stabilisation has kept many growers in the export field, but the encouragement it has offered to restructure has often failed. Whilst I admire the tremendous support that the honourable member for Franklin has given to his industry tonight, I think it has to be recognised that in 1979 over 40 per cent of Tasmania's production was of varieties unattractive to mainland consumers. In addition, it cannot be overlooked that the Western Australian production consisted of over 85 per cent of one variety.

To briefly summarise, I think that the industry has realised the potential of Australian markets and the urgent need to correct the components currently impeding an expansion of sales in these areas. All in all, the Australian apple and pear industry no doubt is approaching a crossroads. Whilst the outlook is not a joyous one, I am quite sure it is challenging. The solutions are there for the industry to act upon. I believe there is no necessity for government intervention, but there is a need for government support. For that reason I am very pleased to support these Bills tonight.

Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill, the Flags Amendment Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981 as they are related measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the three Bills before the House-The Shipping Registration Bill 1981, the Flags Amendment Bill 1981 and the Navigation Amendment Bill 1981-is to abolish the requirement for British legislation to register Australian owned vessels, to establish the criteria for Australian registration, to set up a single Australian register and to establish the Australian Red Ensign as the colours of the Australian merchant fleet and the Australian national flag or the Australian Red Ensign as permissible colours for other Australian vessels. The Opposition does not oppose the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) mentioned in his second reading speech, the principal Bill of the package, the Shipping Registration Bill 1981, seeks to repeal Part I of the United Kingdom Merchant Shipping Act 1894 insofar as it applies to Australian law. That will abolish the present Australian registration system which registers Australian owned ships as British ships, hence enabling Australian nationality to be granted to Australian owned ships. The British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement of 1931 permitted Commonwealth countries to establish their own registers but retained the common status of British ship. That agreement was rescinded by all member countries in mutual agreement in 1978, yet Australia is the only independent member of the Commonwealth, apart from Britain, to continue to operate under the Merchant Shipping Act system. This legislation, which will cut our dependence on the British shipping legislation, is long overdue.

The principal Bill seeks to establish criteria for both compulsory and voluntary Australian registration. Compulsory registration is required for commercial vessels which are more than 50 per cent Australian owned and are of more than 12 metres in length. Voluntary registration is permitted to government vessels, fishing vessels, pleasure craft, Australian-owned vessels of less than 12 metres in length, vessels less than 12 metres in length solely operated by Australian nationals or residents and ships on demise charter to Australian based operators. A single Australian register is to be established with a central office and with branches as required. This will overcome the present peculiarity of having 20 ports of registry with no complete record in one place of all registered vessels.

As a consequence of this move there will be no ports of registry as such. However, due to the importance of the port of registry concept for legal and other purposes, the Bill provides for the adoption of a concept of 'home port' for each ship. The continued practice of marking the port on the ship's stern is thus maintained. The two subsidiary Bills, the Flags Amendment Bill and the Navigation Amendment Bill, are consequential to the principal Bill and together make provision for the Australian Red Ensign to be the colours of the merchant fleet. For all other Australian vessels the Australian national flag or the Australian Red Ensign is to be the national colour. The Australian national flag and the Australian Red Ensign are of identical design, except that the former is blue and the latter is red. The Navigation Amendment Bill also provides for the updating of penalties relating to offences under the Navigation Act. The Flags Amendment Bill removes any reference to the British Blue Ensign in describing the Australian national flag and, hence, in describing the Australian Red Ensign, in line with other provisions of the Bills which seek to establish Australian registration independent of British maritime law. The Opposition shares the concern of the Minister for Transport that Australia should develop its status as an independent nation. This legislation is an important step in that direction.

The Commission of Inquiry into the maritime industry undertaken by Commissioner Summers, which inquired into all matters relating to the development of the Australian maritime industry, including maritime legislation, was established by the last Labor Government in 1973. Such legislation had its roots in the late 1960s, with the entry of Australian flag vessels into overseas trade and the swell of Australian nationalism. The coalition Government at the time moved slowly on the question of maritime legislation geared specifically to Australian conditions and not tied to traditional British maritime law. It was in June 1972 that the Department of Transport issued a summary of changes proposed during discussions on the topic of the revision of the Navigation Act, the cornerstone of Australian maritime operations. It was then a singularly inflexible body of legislation, geared more to traditional British maritime needs than to the requirements of an independent Australian maritime industry.

One of the views put forward then was that the Australian national flag, not the Red Ensign, should be the proper national colours. This question assumed practical importance as Australian flag vessels were now plying the high seas, and under the Geneva Convention on the High Seas of 1958, to which Australia was and is a party, ships had the nationality of the country whose flag they were entitled to fly. The Australian Red Ensign, officially recognised by the Admiralty in 1934 and under section 406 of the Australian Navigation Act, is officially recognised as the proper colours of merchant navy ships registered in Australia. It is, however, described in the terms of the British Red Ensign, defaced by the stars shown on the Australian flag. I find it rather incongruous that we should describe the Australian flag as being a British flag defaced by the addition of the stars of the Southern Cross. I would rather have described it as the British flag embellished by the addition of the stars of the Southern Cross.

The Red Ensign was also authorised under British law as the proper colours of ships and boats belonging to British subjects resident in Australia and was thus considered to be of ambiguous legislative pedigree. It was thought that if Australia was to confer its nationality on ships plying the high seas, in line with developing independent Australian maritime status, it could not permit the Australian Red Ensign to be the national colours. The proposed Bill containing this view had not been drafted by December 1972, when the Labor Government was elected. The Summers inquiry was established, and in the fourth report of that Commission in June 1976 changes to maritime legislation affecting Australia were recommended, including a recommendation that the national flag, not the Red Ensign, should be the proper colours of Australian-registered vessels. This Government in its Shipping Registration Bill of 1981 proposed that this flag recommendation be adopted, with little prior consultation with the Australian maritime interests involved. The response from interested parties was so great and so negative that the proposal was allowed to rest to permit interested parties to put forward their views. The initial proposal was subsequently altered to enable the Australian merchant fleet to continue to fly the Australian Red Ensign as our national colours.

It should be noted that the Australian national flag and the Australian Red Ensign, or Red Duster as it is affectionately known, are identical but for the colour, the former being blue and the latter red. The Red Duster thus portrays not only our national unity but is also a special badge of honour for the Australian merchant fleet, bearing witness to a long and distinguished heritage of gallantry and service. The Government seemed to consider the Australian Red Ensign as an ambiguous flag, authorised under both British and Australian laws and described in relation to the British Blue Ensign. As I have said, their solution initially was to scrap the flag. It would seem to me to have been a far more appropriate step, both in establishing a national identity and out of sensitivity to those most affected by the legislation, to have consulted them adequately beforehand and then to have amended the ambiguities of the legislation rather than scrapping the flag to secure the legislative clarity. The Australian Red Ensign is Australian enough. One has only to ask any merchant seaman to discover that. It is the legislation around the flag that has been ambiguous. I suggest that it is far more important to national spirit to be allowed to wear a distinctive badge of courage and pride that has a long and honourable tradition and is close to the hearts of all merchant seamen and master mariners than to phase it out as legislatively ambiguous. As I have said, unfortunately at the initial stages that was the view taken by the Minister for Transport. It has subsequently been changed as a result of the wide reaction against it.

Historically, the British Red Ensign dates from the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. The privilege of flying it was bestowed upon the British merchant service in 1864 in recognition of its gallant role in time of war. The Australian merchant service has continued this honour of flying a special kind of national flag, a characteristic of merchant fleets in the British Commonwealth. The Royal Australian Navy has the deserved honour of flying the White Ensign, its own special kind of national flag. The Australian merchant navy, like the RAN, has a distinguished record in wartime service and one which is often forgotten, I think regrettably. Approximately 12 per cent of Australian merchant seamen who served on Australian ships from 1939 to 1945 were killed or lost at sea. The Merchant Navy War Service Association of Western Australia has prepared material in which it states that 364 seamen lost their lives. They were either killed in action, died subsequently from injuries, died in prison camps, or were lost at sea. In all, 16 Australian merchant navy ships were sunk.

The merchant service had a vital defence role. The war was only a matter of hours from its home ports. Merchant navy ships were used as troop carriers, hospital ships, and to maintain essential supplies. The HMS Bulolo, a merchant cruiser converted from a passenger and freight liner, convoyed merchant ships, hunted raiders, was the flag ship of several rear admirals in the invasion of North Africa, code named Operation Torch and was at the Anzio landings. At the end of the war in Europe HMS Bulolo was commissioned as headquarters ship for the South East Asia Command under Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten. It had a very distinguished war record. In a way, it seems rough justice that members of the Australian merchant fleet who served in war zones are still not accorded the right to a Service pension. Although during wartime they were always closely associated with the dangers facing the armed forces, they are still considered to be civilians and are denied recognition of their service in combat zones. Members of the merchant navy share equal honour on many of our war memorials and they generally qualify for full membership of the Returned Services League. Yet despite this and numerous citations for bravery and official government praise, they still do not qualify for the practical and real assistance of a Service pension.

Other deserving groups, such as members of allied partisan armies, have been generally recognised as worthy recipients of such an entitlement. Civilian journalists taken aboard merchant ships and working in close association with the armed forces can get a pension at 60 years of age under an act of grace, but Australian merchant seamen who served in combat zones during World War II cannot. I believe that this is a most unfair way to treat Australians in the merchant navy who have fought for our nation in time of war. It is a difficult decision of government to understand. On the one hand, it recognises the qualities of our merchant navy and the need for independence of our merchant fleet; on the other hand, it does not recognise the men who served to defend this country in a time of war. I come into contact with a number of merchant seamen in the course of my responsibilities. One man in my own electorate who has played a very prominent part in promoting the interests of merchant seamen and the role of our mercantile fleet is Bob Nelson. Mr Nelson has played a very valuable and effective role in respect of Service pension entitlements for merchant navy men who served in war zones during World War II. The Opposition hopes that the general direction of the proposed legislation, which favours a more independent Australian position in maritime legislation and a greater regard for the merchant fleet and its members, will be extended in a practical fashion. I refer not only to pensions for members of the merchant navy who saw war service but also to providing for an expanded merchant fleet in time of peace. Government support ought to be extended from the field of legislation to providing substantive support for an independent and adequate Australian merchant fleet.

Such a move also finds support in the reports which emanated from the Summers inquiry. Its seventh and final report recommends that the Commonwealth Government should extend financial support to both coastal and international Australian shipping ventures. It would be shallow indeed if the references by the Minister for Transport to Australian independence in maritime legislation were not developed into positive measures to build up an independent Australian maritime fleet. That would be a travesty of the word 'independence'. We have the Australian Red Ensign but relatively few ships, certainly in world terms, from which to fly it. Legislative independence must not be allowed to mask our continued commercial dependence on overseas shipping companies.

Since 1972-73, annual Australian participation in the carriage of its exports and imports has been dismal. In terms of bulk cargoes, Australian flag vessels have carried between 0.1 per cent and 3.1 per cent of our exports and between 0.3 per cent and 2 per cent of our imports. In terms of general cargoes, the respective figures are 3.3 per cent to 7.3 per cent of our exports and 6.1 per cent to 12 per cent of our imports. These are abysmally low figures. Most of the remaining cargo is carried in ships owned by British container shipping companies in the conference system or bulk ships and tankers belonging to multinational companies. Most bulk exports from Australia to Japan are transported in Japanese bulk carriers. Japanese flag vessels have carried between 39 per cent and 45 per cent of bulk cargoes which have left these shores since 1972-73. Since bulk exports account for between 80 per cent and 85 per cent, in volume, of all Australian overseas trade, the power of Japanese ship owners can be readily gauged.

The lack of an adequate Australian overseas fleet and, consequently, of control over the conditions of shipping Australian exports and imports places Australia in a weak commercial and strategic position, as a result of which all Australian suffer. Each year we lose hundreds of millions of dollars in freight and insurance payments to overseas ship owners. This has had a tremendous effect in keeping the Australian ship building and ship repair industries in a position in which they are starved of capital and unable to develop for want of markets and work. The resultant loss of jobs, both direct and indirect, is substantial. Jobs for seamen and for those who could build or repair such vessels are lost abroad. If this freight expenditure were retained in Australia the multiplier effects on Australian industry which I have mentioned, especially ship building and ship repairing, would be substantial.

Additionally, the conditions and cost of shipping Australian overseas trade rests in the hands of foreigners. This affects domestic freight pricing also. Australia is an island continent and most of our markets are a great distance from where our goods are produced. The costs of transport are of great significance in determining whether our goods will be internationally competitive; yet we have very little say in the prices charged for shipping those goods abroad. The conference system is largely outside our control. This means that pressure is exerted by producers and manufacturers, where and when they can do so, on the costs of Australian domestic freight systems. Often this means the Government providing what I term commercial welfare to local exporters in the form of freight subsidies via government instrumentalities, cost recovery on the cost of road freighting and the construction of export roads. Australia is a major trading nation which has about 6,000 vessel calls a year, carrying upwards of 200 million tonnes of cargo, yet it is not a maritime nation. Only a meagre amount of our overseas trade is carried in our ships. The cost of this to the Australian public, to the Australian community, to Australian industry and to Australian primary producers I have mentioned already, but there are a number of reasons for this detrimental imbalance. Some seek to explain it by way of economics, by the claim that our costs are too high, our wages are too high and so on. I rather think that it is better explained by Australia's colonial heritage, against which we are still struggling and which the Bills now before us help to remedy. Australia has never been a major maritime nation, due to its historical ties to Britain which as a strong maritime and colonising nation, had little interest in seeing a local maritime industry develop in Australia. We became a captive market. Even our shipping registration system was a captive of the British system. Our lack of a large, locally owned fleet led to the short term expediency of seeking the best freight conditions from overseas ship owners, rather than building up our own fleet. It has become the policy of conservative governments and it constituted a policy of neglect, one which Labor rejects. We support the extension of the Australian fleet, both internationally and on the Australian coast. The last Labor Government supported the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development 40-40-20 decision. This is often quoted as representing a fair international distribution of freight carriage. In essence, it states that Australia and other trading nations should carry 40 per cent of their trade; that 40 per cent should be carried by the importing nation, 40 per cent by the exporting nation and the remaining 20 per cent by cross-traders.

I believe that a similar policy could be developed in respect of repairs to overseas vessels. At present we perform only between one per cent and 2 per cent of those repairs. Clearly a 40 per cent share of sea carriage and ship repairs would have a far-reaching impact on the balance of payments, on our national income, on providing additional jobs and have other positive ramifications, including an expanded defence potential.

Under present conditions, little positive aid is given to the shipping industry. No assistance, apart from a subsidy on locally-built ships, is provided to coastal shipping and no Australian commercial ship of significant size has been built in the last few years. On the other hand, land transport is subsidised, so we have the anomaly of high energy consumptive inland freight carriage when 80 per cent of our population lives on the coast.

No financial assistance is provided to Australian overseas shipping, yet every country whose ships ply our shores receive significant financial support from their governments. The maritime unions, which are often used as a scapegoat to explain the sad state of our shipping industry, have made positive moves to obtain greater Australian participation in the carriage of our overseas trade. There have been welcome developments between industry and the unions towards obtaining a greater Australian participation, adopting a more balanced approach to the costs of operating vessels in overseas trade and to the levels of manning vessels in overseas trade. There is a better understanding on the part of both parties involved as to the responsibilities and problems of each side. I regard that as a welcome development for Australia, something that is supported on both sides of the chamber. I hope to see a greater development of it.

After an eight-year campaign, which is continuing, and partially due to pressure from the six sea-going unions to extend Australian participation in oil import carriage, a negotiated provisional settlement has been reached. The settlement involves the oil importing companies each putting one Australian tanker into the trade and this eventually will account for 15 per cent to 20 per cent of total oil import trade.

In that connection I mention, as the Minister has on previous occasions, that Ampol has introduced the Ampol Sarel, that H. C. Sleigh-Total-Amoco have introduced the William Dampier and that Mobil has decided to introduce a ship called the Pacific Star. I understand that discussions with BP, Shell and also Caltex are continuing.

There is one paramount reason why the development of an Australian overseas flag fleet of some magnitude is even more crucial than ever. That reason is the mineral boom following the global fuel crisis. The directions of Australia's hoped-for path out of the low growth period we have long been in is exporting energy related minerals such as coal, alumina, aluminium and liquefied natural gas. This will involve a vast expansion of our bulk exports of these commodities, potentially in Australian ships. If the present pattern of relying on overseas shipping companies as a short term expediency continues, we will see Japanese ships carrying our burgeoning mineral exports, as they carry most of them to Japan now. Our dependence on them will be great; the profits will be high; and they will be siphoned off abroad. If the fuel shortage favours Australia due to our abundant coal supplies for export, it certainly favours us in exporting them in ships propelled by that fuel and owned, repaired and even built by Australians. I suggest that not to carry coal exports and all our overseas trade increasingly in Australian coal-fired vessels would be a commercial disaster for the industry and for the people of this country, not to mention the waste of liquid energy that would occur if we ignore the potential that coal-fired vessels offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are leading the world in that.

—The Minister says that we are leading the world. I think there is a bipartisan view to that statement in that the use of coal-fired vessels is desirable in the national interest, and there should be accelerated development of it. An increase in Australian flag participation should be seen as an economically viable downstream venture deriving from Australia's global advantage in mineral and energy mining, processing and exporting. Consequently, it would be a national disgrace if the Government did not back up the spirit of its Shipping Registration Bill package, for national maritime independence, by giving greater and long term support to the development of an extensive and modern Australian shipping industry, both coastal and international. This should be part of a nationally planned transport policy, co-ordinated with a national energy policy of the same scope. This would support and foster by required policies the use of each mode for its most technically appropriate task. This package of Bills is an important step in developing the stronger administrative independence of the Australian shipping industry. In these circumstances, the Bills are not opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) on a very competent and efficient exposition of the Shipping Registration Bill, the Flags Amendment Bill and the Navigation Amendment Bill. It is extremely complicated legislation. I think that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who has had a very hard day, will derive some satisfaction from the fact that the very protracted, elongated negotiations that have been going on with the States and with other authorities for years are about to culminate, at least so far as the legislation in this chamber is concerned. I will not speak for very long tonight because, as the Opposition Whip, I wish to make sure that we leave time for a maiden speech by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) a little later in the night. That is the reason my remarks will be curtailed.
—They will be at half mast.

—They will be half mast; I will be dragging the anchor, as it were. In respect of the Shipping Registration Bills, it is most significant to note that Australia is the only remaining independent Commonwealth member, other than Britain, to continue to operate under laws of the United Kingdom. In other words, whilst that situation has prevailed up to this time, we are really confronted with an anachronism, or relic. In effect, this represents a significant occasion so far as navigation matters or shipping registration matters are concerned, because Australia has appeared to have come of age and to have taken on a sense of nationalism. I believe that that is a very good thing. We have been operating under the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 or legislation that is closely attuned to principles enunciated under that legislation. Of course, for many years that legislation applied right throughout the British Empire. If a country was a member of the Empire, it was virtually regarded as British and it flew the British flag. In 1931, the Statute of Westminster provided that nations would be free to repeal such arrangements provided they complied with the general principles that had been in operation up until that time. Therefore, this Bill facilitaties the registration of most ships so that ships can have Australian nationality. The honourable member for Shortland made some reference to nationalism in respect of the extent to which we use Australian ships for Australian trade purposes. The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Shipping Registration Bill is an important step forward in the development of Australia's status as an independent nation . . .
Of course, it does not really throw an effective switch to give us a very real involvement in trade.

If we look at some pertinent statistics on how much Australian involvement exists in the transportation by ship of our imports and exports, we are in for a very rude shock. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has provided figures which indicate that, in 1978-79, cargo loaded for export from Australia by Australian vessels was 3,962,000 tonnes out of a total of 165,094,000 tonnes. It is a mere 2.4 per cent of exports. I believe all Australians would be very concerned to learn about our inadequate involvement, about the small share that we are able to claim for ourselves. It is apparent that there is much to be done to redress that unsatisfactory situation. The import cargo carried by Australian vessels amounted to 338,000 tonnes out of a total of 21,884,000 tonnes. Again the figure is very small. Expressed as a percentage it is only 1.5 per cent of all imports.

Our balance of payments shows that the situation is very seriously affected by the figures I have just given. The net cost of transportation, or the net payments to other countries for transportation-which admittedly is for all transport, not just shipping; I do not want to confuse the House-was $939m in 1978-79 and in 1979-80 the figure had risen to $1,151m, an increase of 22.6 per cent on the previous year. So, we are going backwards rather than forwards. I think the Minister will take on board his obvious obligation to give Australia a better deal as an exporting, trading nation, and a share in our own shipping activities to a greater extent than we have been able to observe up till now.

In regard to the Flags Amendment Bill, I noted that mention was made in the second reading speech about the continued use of the Australian Red Ensign. I indicate my lack of enthusiasm for this concept. I cannot understand why we have to be as weak-kneed as this. The Minister said:
. . . it is proposed to declare the Australian Red Ensign the national colors for Australian merchant ships.

He then mentioned that in some circumstances other ships can fly either the Australian national flag or the Australian Red Ensign. This kind of option represents a shemozzle. I cannot see the need for compromise. I notice that the Deputy Clerk is looking at me very discerningly, if not critically. I know his nautical background. I know the prejudice that has grown up in a traditional way in the Navy and even in the merchant navy. The Deputy Clerk knows a great deal about that. I understand all that. But there comes a time when one needs to throw a switch and become a nation. The main point I want to make is that we ought to have one flag in this country. I do not want to belt it unduly. The Minister said:

. . . the British Admiralty has issued individual warrants to certain members of some 16 yacht clubs in Australia, authorising them to wear the British Blue Ensign, either underfaced or in a defaced form.

They can wear it in a bastardised form, if you like. It is incredible that members of these yacht clubs will be able to wear the British Blue Ensign. They are lucky to have their yachts in Australia. They probably derive from the exploitation of Australian workers and Australian resources. I think it should be good enough for them to fly the Australian flag. They should be required to fly it. I do not set aside the obligation I place on the Minister to tell the House why he has compromised on this important principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because tradition dies hard.
—Oh! He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The British Blue Ensign is similar to the Australian National Flag but without the stars. Approximately 400 Australian yacht owners have been issued with such warrants. This causes some difficulty as under the Geneva Convention on the High Seas 1958, to which Australia is a party, ships have the nationality of the country whose flag they are entitled to fly.
There is no justification for this. The Minister also made a point about the States. He said:
The Bill also preserves the use of the flag of a State or Territory in Australian waters and contains provisions in respect of flag rights for unregistered Australian ships.

I happen to be an Australian-not a New South Welshman, although I come from the great city of Sydney. I am very proud of the fact that the Australian Parliament is making Australian flags available to schools, benevolent organisations and the like. I am not anywhere near as enthusiastic about the fact that prisoners in various States perform the task of making State flags, and that concurrent with the distribution of the Australian flags is the prolific distribution of State flags. I cannot see why State flags should be allowed to be flown on ships sailing in Australian waters or on the high seas; Australian flags should be flown. I think the Minister ought to demonstrate some Australian spirit, instead of conniving, grovelling and crawling to miserable parochialism. I understand that democracy starts at the parochial level. I know that it has an expansive factor about it. One can be proud of one's city and one can be proud of one's State, but primarily one should be proud of one's country. We should not be as bastardised about these things as we are. I criticise this legislation from that point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon C.K.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to say a few words about the Shipping Registration Bill. I can already feel the Whip's knife in my back because my name was not on the list of speakers.
—Bourchier is not in here.

—I am talking about the Opposition Whip. I congratulate the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) for bringing forward this Bill. Such a Bill should have been brought into this Parliament some 30 or 40 years ago.
—That is the nicest thing that has been said about me all day.

—I did not say many nice things about the Minister this morning, but when credit is due I extend it. In this case, I extend my congratulations to the Minister for having introduced this Bill. I regret that an honourable member from this side of the House did not originate the Bill. Much work was done on this legislation between 1972 and 1975. Unfortunately, due to events that are now history, the legislation was not taken to the stage that it has reached today. The man who spoke most in this Parliament over the years about the establishment of a shipping register was the former honourable member for Werriwa, the Honourable Gough Whitlam. He spoke consistently and regularly on this matter. Whenever a shipping Bill or a maritime Bill of any type was introduced, the establishment of an Australian shipping register was always mentioned by him. Unfortunately, the Ministers of that era did nothing about it. It was very high on the list of priorities of the Whitlam Labor Government. If a particular event had not occurred, such legislation would have been through this Parliament by now. It is pleasing to see that the Liberal Government is slowly but surely getting rid of the shackles of the old Acts of the United Kingdom Government. It is good to see once again severance from the Merchant Shipping Act 1894. Australia is becoming a maritime nation in its own right with its own register. So much for that point. I think this is a good Bill. I think that it covers all the points that are required to be covered. I think it has the full support of the industry and the trade unions. I certainly support it.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to bring a few points to the Minister's attention about the exemption from registration of ships that are demise chartered. How long will this exemption apply? Some companies in Australia today charter ships and use them for a considerable time. The Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd had two ships on the coast for almost the whole of the life of the ships. I refer to the Iron Cavalier and the Iron Clipper. Ships of that type which operate for that duration should not be permitted to operate on the coast or in the overseas trade under Australian charter conditions without being required to register. I hope that the exemption will be extended only to ships on charter for a very short period.

I refer the Minister to clause 13, which refers to exemption from registration. Government ships, fishing vessels, pleasure craft and small craft are exempt from the requirement to be registered under Section 12. Of course, we know that government ships are men-of-war and I do not think they should be registered. However, we have to realise that fishing vessels are no longer the six-metre, seven-metre or eight-metre launches that used to operate in the estuaries and just off the coast. The fishing vessels of today are very large ships. There are mother ships, and other ships operating from them. Sooner or later ships of that nature will become established on the coast.

I am trying to keep my remarks as brief as possible. The same thing can be said of pleasure craft. I cannot see any justification for the exemption of pleasure craft. They should be included in the register. A fixed tonnage, length or whatever could be used as the yardstick. After all, there is provision in the Bill for the calculation of the size of a ship. There are umpteen different methods for calculating the size of a ship. I am not the least concerned about the formula that the Government will use. Some people I have spoken to disagree with the formula. I consider it of such minor consequence, and so do they, that I am not making an issue of it. Pleasure craft are becoming quite substantial in size and there are many of them on the coast. They are getting bigger every day. I think it is time that the Department of Transport considered preparing an amendment to the Act to include pleasure craft. Certain things have to be taken in consideration. For example people no longer exclusively sail their own pleasure craft. People are employed on them. Once that stage is reached there should not be any differentiation between what is a commercial ship and what is a pleasure craft. The owners of these pleasure craft, if they employ people, should have their vessels put on the register.

The other matter I raise concerns clause 5 of the legislation: 'Act to bind the Crown'. I think it is time that if a State or Commonwealth owned shipping line breaches the Act then it should be required to pay the penalty as privately operated shipping companies have to. I do not think there should be any exemption just because the shipping line is owned by a government. The Australian National Line is an authority set up by this Parliament. It is responsible to this Parliament and it is financed by this Parliament. Therefore, if it breaches the Act it should suffer the penalty. I know that it is only a case of taking the money out of the left hand pocket and putting it into the right hand pocket, but if it is good enough to penalise the other shipping lines then it should be good enough to penalise the Australian National Line for breaching the Act. I know that government operations are expected to observe the letter of the Act but unfortunately that is not always the case and breaches occur. Therefore I would like to see clause 5 of the Bill deleted as I do not think government owned ships should be given exemption. As honourable members know, I am a great supporter of the ANL. It would have been a much larger shipping line if I had had my way.

In my opinion the Government is putting great stress on this alleged mineral boom in Australia. The Government has no control over the expansion of the mineral industry. It is one of those things that happen. What concerns me is the fact that so little of the exports of Australia's resources have been carried in Australian bottoms. The oil tanker, the William Dampier-about an 80,000 tonner-is owned by an overseas company operating to the Middle East. Then there is the Ampol Sarel operating to Sumatra. There has always been an Australian ship on the Sumatra trade. I believe it is time the Government really expanded its fleet. If the trade union movement had given the Whitlam Government greater co-operation-the type of co-operation it is prepared to give to the oil industry today to bring tankers on to the coast-it would have had some 400,000 tonnes of tankers operating five or six years ago.

It is thanks to the previous Australian Labor Party Government that we have the four P class vessels operating in the carriage of iron ore. These include two 120,000 tonners and two 140,000 tonners. When the decision was taken to have those ships built we had an understanding with the Japanese steel industry that cargoes would be provided. Mr Bert Weymouth, when he was chairman of ANL, and the manager, Mr Robin, went to Japan and talked to the steel industry management. They got an assurance that cargoes would be available for those ships. The only reason they were not built in Japan-it was common sense to have them built there-was that the Japanese shipbuilding industry was so loaded with orders that it was impossible to get a delivery date from it. It was not the wish of ANL, the Department of Transport or the Government that those ships be built in Sweden and Germany. Even though the Japanese may have used that as an excuse for not giving cargo or agreeing to the charter of the ships, the reason they were not built in Japan was the fault of Japan. Its industry was so loaded with orders that it did not have the time to build them.

The percentage of coal exported from Australia in foreign ships is absolutely ridiculous. Yet that amount of coal is being exported and carried almost exclusively in overseas bottoms. I understand that only one Australian ship carries any of that coal, and that is one of the P class vessels that on every second trip picks up a load of coal from Hay Point. We should have used the opportunity when the price of ships and the charter of ships was at rock bottom to acquire sufficient ships to set up the nucleus of a substantial overseas trade, particularly in this area of the carriage of our mineral exports. This would also have helped in the importation of crude oil.

I hope that the Government has taken adequate measures to ensure that gas tankers will be provided to carry Australia's export of gas from the North West Shelf. If countries want to buy our gas, they should buy it at a fair and reasonable price. Having in mind the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development resolution-40 per cent of that gas to be carried by the supplying country, 40 per cent by the buyer and 20 per cent by cross traders-then at least 40 per cent of that gas should be carried in Australian bottoms. The cost of those ships is horrendous. Of course Australian maritime conditions are a bit higher than those in other countries but with all the facts taken into consideration such as the cost of the ship, depreciation, interest payments and all that is involved, put against the difference in wages, then the difference is infinitesimal. Now that the Government has taken the step of setting up an Australian register it should move into the field of ensuring that Australian resources are carried in Australian bottoms. Again I say that I support the legislation and commend it to the House because I believe it is a progressive move and one which is in the interests of the Australian maritime industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

That the following words be added to the Address: ', but note that the Government:
