SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I offer my congratulations to those new members of parliament who have made their maiden speeches during this Address-in-Reply debate. They have brought to this House the diversification of their various electorates, and I feel sure that their contributions have been of great interest to those of us who have been in this Parliament for some time. Some very expansive statements have been made during the debate. I wish to refer to some extraordinarily expansive statements made by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who indicated that 500,000 people in Australia were unemployed. That is not so. Statistics show that in January 1981, 374,800 people-216,000 males and 158,000 females-were looking for full time work, compared with 380,900 in January 1980 and 391,000 in January 1979. The honourable member has completely forgotten that there are 6,529 people in full employment in Australia. This is the greatest number of people ever in our work force.
—How many-6,000?
—People are loath to give credence to this fact. There are 6,529,500 people in full employment in Australia. Honourable members opposite know that figure only too well.
—How many?

—The figure has been noted. That is the most lively the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has been since coming to this Parliament. I am pleased that I have woken him up. The honourable member for Port Adelaide also indicated that in the recent McPherson by-election the National Country Party's campaign cost $200,000. If he took a couple of noughts off that figure he might be nearer the true figure. He indicated that the National Country Party receives $10 for every $1 received by the Australian Labor Party for election expenses. That is absolute rubbish. We know that the Labor Party is assisted by big business. There is no doubt about that. It gets funds from big business and from the trade union movement for election purposes. The honourable member for Wills, who is sitting at the table, cannot deny that.

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales and Queensland have had a devastating drought which has had a very serious effect on grain production, sheep and cattle numbers, and wool production. Although there has been scattered rain throughout New South Wales and southern Queensland, it has not been nearly enough to satisfy the farmers. At this time no water is flowing into the creeks or our great dams. These areas are going into the winter months without any surface water, and there is a very serious situation indeed. Wheat crops failed last year in this area which is the biggest wheat producing area in Australia. Farmers have had no income from wheat sales, and they have lost sheep and cattle; the numbers are down. We are experiencing tremendous problems at the moment in country killing works. I am chairman of the Gunnedah Shire killing works, which to date has been very successful. This killing works commenced operations on 15 July 1957 and has traded profitably right up to the present time, but with the shortage of stock for slaughter it is facing serious problems. That is the situation at practically every meatworks in New South Wales and, to a lesser extent, in Queensland. Of course, this problem has exacerbated greatly the unemployment situation. Honourable members have probably read in the newspapers about the closure of killing works at Moree, Guyra and Newcastle. This is creating great unemployment problems for the people in those areas, and the Government of New South Wales is being approached for funds to help those killing works continue.

It will take primary industry from two to three years to recover fully in these areas. Sheep farmers who usually get 120 bales of wool this year will be down to 45 bales or 46 bales of wool. The quality of the wool will not be the same, and this will seriously affect the export income of this country and country towns that support these wonderful agricultural areas. The banks will have to come to the party to assist the primary producers. If the primary producers are not successful in producing, there is a flow-on to the cities of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Brisbane, which rely on the prosperity of the people on the land. The Commonwealth Development Bank will have to be given funds so that it can come to the assistance of these people. The Primary Industry Bank of Australia also will have to come to the party. It is up to this Government to see that funds are made available in these areas so that these great industries can get back on their feet.

I was very disappointed to read that at the last Australian Water Resources Council meeting which was held recently, no mention was made of any programming for great dams in this country. We have to establish more dams and weirs for the conservation of water. Honourable members will be aware that Australia is the driest continent in the world. We would be very pleased if this matter were taken up and some action taken by this Government and the various State governments. It is only through co-operation with the State governments that results can be achieved.

Another problem facing the meat industry, not only in our country areas but right throughout the nation, is the meat inspection service. It is pleasing to note that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is making every effort to establish a single meat inspection service. At present we have two inspections, and in some cases even three inspections, with local government, State government and Commonwealth meat inspectors. The Minister for Primary Industry recently told the Australian Agricultural Council that he wanted it to review two options for meat inspection services. Those options were: The delegation of commonwealth responsibility for export inspection to those States who wish to assume it; or the Commonwealth to assume total responsibility for inspection at export establishments. The dual system of meat inspection has caused tremendous increases in costs. Most meat works have two sets of inspectors, one for the export market and the other for the State market. If we can get the service down to a single inspection the cost of meat to the Australian housewife should be reduced, as well as the cost to industry generally.

I turn now to coal development in the Hunter Valley. My electorate of Paterson has the greatest coal production in Australia at the moment. We are extracting even more coal than is being extracted from the great mines in Queensland. Severe problems exist in development, which is growing very rapidly. Oil companies such as BP Aust Ltd, the Shell Co. of Aust. Ltd, and Caltex Oil (Aust.) Pty Ltd are putting capital into very big coal mines at Warkworth, Singleton, Muswellbrook and over the range to Gunnedah where I live. Local government is having a great problem in providing the infrastructure for these great mines.

Unfortunately the New South Wales Government has lacked the foresight to provide the rolling stock to take this coal to the seaboard. It has not provided the rail facilities. Most of the coal from Singleton and Muswellbrook is being carted on our highways in 27-tonne semi-trailer trucks. As a result, the devastation that will take place on our highways will cause a grave financial situation. The shire councils of Singleton and Muswellbrook are running out of land which is needed to provide homes for people who are employed at the mines. There is a need for infrastructure such as increased schooling facilities, increased housing and increased water and sewerage. The people in these areas are facing great problems. The New South Wales Government and the Federal Government will have to give them assistance.

Coal companies in Queensland have provided infrastructure and the coal companies in the Hunter Valley will have to be approached to assist in the infrastructure that is required. The committee which I represent has been to the mines in Queensland. We have seen what Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Thiess Brothers Pty Ltd and Utah Mining Australia Ltd have provided at Blackwater. The mining companies have provided houses and swimming pools-the whole infrastructure. They have built roads and railways. The mining companies in the Hunter Valley will have to assist in the development of the infrastructure in this region. Over the last few weeks railway shunters have followed a practice of permitting trains travelling to the ports of Newcastle, Sydney and Port Kembla to carry only 500 tonnes of coal at a time. I often travel by train in this area and I have seen eight or nine trucks being pulled by a diesel locomotive down to the port of Newcastle. Because of this practice, ships are taking up to eight or 10 days to load instead of two days.

I have travelled to various countries-Japan, Korea, China and Hong Kong-which import coal from Australia. I am informed that these countries are very dissatisfied with the delays that are taking place not only in the export of our coal but also in the export of wheat and other products. Last week 36 bulk ships were waiting off the port of Newcastle to load coal, wheat and iron. I understand that the same situation existed in Sydney.

I want to say something about the Australian economy. We are fortunate we live in this country. Unfortunately, we do not have a truly nationalistic outlook. We should all be working like eager beavers to attain the good things of the world but we are not doing that. We seem to have people who, at the drop of a hat, are prepared to create industrial problems. They are injuring only themselves, their wives and their kiddies-they are doing this nation a great disservice. The economy of Australia is sound. The consumer price index increased by 2.1 per cent in the December quarter and by 1.3 per cent over 1980 as a whole. So that gives honourable members some idea of the sound state of our economy. Both retail sales and new passenger vehicle registrations showed strong growth in the December quarter. Employment growth remained strong. The combination of a steady current account deficit and stronger private capital inflow resulted in an overall balance of payments surplus of $288m in January. Private dwelling approvals rose further in the December quarter. Our overseas trade is suffering because of the delays in shipping which I have mentioned. We are lucky people to live in this great country. This is the greatest country in the world yet we have people who are endeavouring to destroy it.

This week we were visited by executive members of companies involved in the great North West Shelf project. This is the biggest project of its type ever attempted in the world. It is estimated to cost $4,000m on 1980 values. It is 48 per cent Australian owned despite what we hear from some honourable members opposite and other people in this country. The project is made up of Woodside Petroleum Development Pty Ltd, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, California Asiatic Oil Co. Shell and Hematite Petroleum Pty Ltd. BHP has huge holdings in the project. It is based on gas fields located in the Dampier sub-basin approximately 130 kilometres offshore from the port of Dampier. The project will initially produce liquified natural gas for Western Australia and, of course, for export. Just imagine the employment possibilities that this huge project will give young Australians. Production platforms will have to be erected, ports will have to be constructed and pipelines will have to be laid. Also, there will be a greater requirement for shipping. The infrastructure development will lead to more employment opportunities in the towns. As I have mentioned, the project will be the biggest undertaking of its type ever contemplated in Australia and, indeed, the world.

We are very fortunate to have such natural resources as coal, iron ore, petroleum, natural gas and uranium. Unfortunately the left wing and the socialists of this country will not allow us to get on with the mining, milling and marketing of yellowcake. Anybody who opposes the mining and milling of this valuable commodity is socialistic, communistic or left wing. These people want to stop this country from exporting uranium. When one asks members of the French Parliament what the French communists and socialists think about uranium, one is told that they want France to import this material. By 1983 France will be producing 47.5 per cent of its electric power by nuclear means. This country ought to get stuck into the export of uranium. We should forget about the socialists and the left wingers and export our yellowcake. Yellowcake is not dangerous. It becomes dangerous only when treated with such chemicals as texachloride. The export of yellowcake could assist our balance of trade position. If we do not find more petroleum as the years go by we will be faced with a huge balance of payments problem. However, by exporting uranium for power generation purposes we will be able to balance our Budget. The export of uranium will be of benefit to Australia and to all those people who have the great fortune to live here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the next speaker I would remind the enthusiastic House that it is the honourable member's maiden speech. I would ask all honourable members to extend to him the courtesy of silent attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I feel I must decline both the traditions of this House and your protection. The electorate of Kalgoorlie would feel it very churlish were I not to do so. May I commence my speech by thanking the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe). I felt he spoke for my benefit. I have met him socially. I thought that his speech was very relaxing. It showed the sort of light humour that puts one at ease in this very nervous situation of making a maiden speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I stand today in this place by virtue of the will of the electors of Kalgoorlie. It is a source of great pleasure to me that I was afforded the privilege of returning the seat of Kalgoorlie to the Australian Labor Party. Kalgoorlie is an area of great historical interest for the Labor Party because, since Federation, we have held the seat for all but 14 years. It is a great source of personal pleasure for me that I was able to end the last five years in the wilderness for the electorate. The electorate of Kalgoorlie-I wish that a few Tasmanians were here to hear this-is twice the size of Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania put together. It produces for Australia most of our iron ore, lead, cobalt, mineral sands and just about every other mineral one can think of. I feel sure that it would even produce bigger and better apples. Within its boundaries are some of the best wheat land and some of the best farmers in the whole Commonwealth. It has a potential for coal and there is evidence of reserves of oil that will be improved through the continuing exploration at Dongara.

The resources of the electorate do not stop at the coastline however. We have the greatest per capita income from fishing. We have the reserves of the North West Shelf about which I hope I can give some facts to this House at a later date. Within this area covering approximately one-third of Australia, we have a sort of super-Queensland. The area is bigger and better than Queensland without the attendant paranoia that goes with that State. I make this last observation with some reservations for, in our State Government, we have the same irrational extremism, incompetence and bigotry that makes the government of Queensland the focus for international scorn and embarrassment that it is.

The fact that I and not the former member stand today in this place indicates a vote of no-confidence in the policy of the Fraser Government. In the limited time available to me, I shall refer to some of these just grievances. They include: The Government's policy of virtually giving away our minerals, its blatantly dishonest approach to the reduction of air travel costs and the outrageous treatment of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares chaired by Mr Holcroft. I will dwell, however, on three areas of concern. I refer to the action of governments, both State and Federal, on Aboriginal affairs, mining and taxation.

Liberal governments, both State and Federal, have a lot to answer for in their treatment of my Aboriginal constituents. They have pushed Aboriginal affairs to the bottom of their lists of priorities. How else can one explain why, although the Aboriginals in the Kimberleys have a 70 per cent unemployment rate, nothing is done about it? How else can one explain why, with record infant mortality and a high incidence of disease in Aboriginal communities, funds for Aboriginal medical services are being cut even more?

The Western Australian Premier has shown a callous disregard for Aboriginal sensitivities over many years. The Noonkanbah confrontation last year was unusual because it was one of the few times when an Aboriginal community had resisted the forces of big government. When, with the style for which he has become noted, our fuhrer sent his panzer divisions into Noonkanbah, the $1m it cost the taxpayers was the least cost. In terms of international disapproval and future distrust on the part of the Aboriginal community, the bill for the future will be infinitely greater than that. The Western Australian Government has not granted a pastoral lease to an Aboriginal community since 1977. It has even come to arrangements with people for far less than Aboriginal communities were prepared to pay. The Western Australian Government did this in 1977 in relation to one of the stations for which there was an application and again last year at Lamboo where the applicant, Monty Gordon, was recognised as one of the most experienced cattlemen in the whole of the Kimberleys.

When it appeared that the Aboriginal disenchantment with Liberal policies might lead to a Liberal member losing his seat, the Western Australian Government introduced a Bill to disenfranchise the Aborigines. That was a very novel ploy. It was the first time in the Commonwealth since 1920 that it was not legal for a fellow elector to witness an electoral card claim. Responsible Ministers of this Government, if not actually abetting these practices, certainly abandoned their charges to the State hardliners. Let there be no mistake: The Aboriginal people of the Kalgoorlie electorate are under the protection of this Parliament. In 1967, the electors of Australia gave the Federal Parliament and Federal Ministers responsibility for Aboriginal affairs. Even the imperial government in London when it granted Western Australia responsible government in 1890 retained the control of Aboriginal affairs because it felt that the government in Perth could not be trusted. The government in Perth today cannot be trusted. My constituents want action from Canberra. The platitudes and the sweet talking of Fred Chaney are not enough. Fred was one of those people who believed in the maxim that there was no problem, no matter how big or how bad, one could not run away from. He met his Waterloo, however when he failed to sweet talk the thugs who now control the Liberal Party in Western Australia into giving him preselection in Curtin. In short, when the coup comes, as come it will, the Government will be able to install its own gilded bird on the peacock throne.

I wish to mention a little about mining. Let there be no mistake that the Noonkanbah exercise was designed to show the mining and exploration companies just who was boss. It was evident that the mining companies were able to come to terms and be far more reasonable and equitable with our Aborigines than our State Government was. Sir Charles needed an example and the Noonkanbah community, emerging as one of the most successful and organised groups, made an excellent target. He knew that if he could crush this group, he was in a position to demonstrate his power to the mining companies. I was present at Noonkanbah on the day that Amax (Exploration) Australia Inc. decided to pull out. It realised that it had no chance of finding oil. Its representative quoted me odds of 400 to one. The geological expert of another major mining company said to me: 'If there is any oil at Noonkanbah, we will have to tear up all the scrapbooks and forget everything we know'. He added: 'All the text books will be no good to us at all'.

Amax never wanted that confrontation. There was nothing in it for the company. It knew there was nothing there. It was a victim of the Court Government's fiction that said that there was a legal and binding commitment to do the drilling. That legal and binding commitment was, of course, to the Western Australian Government which could have removed that commitment with the stroke of a pen. Instead, it chose to threaten and to intimidate the company. Although Amax is a multinational company, in Australia it is very small potatoes and has absolutely no political clout. Throughout all this Amax was on the horns of a dilemma. On the one hand was its international good name and, on the other, it was conscious of the large amounts of money and potential which it had invested in Western Australia, all vulnerable to the whims of the Court Government.

After all, Amax had seen Sir Charles persecute Lang Hancock and take from him several exploration areas, in some of which millions of dollars had been invested. The fruits of Lang Hancock's expertise and the years of his time and experience were stripped from this great pioneer of the iron ore industry in the most fascist fashion. Why? The reason is probably that in his own desire to be seen as a pioneer of northern development Sir Charles was prepared to falsify history and belittle the achievements of those who went before him. In my talks to senior mining men-I mean the senior men, not the middle management people who make up the converts to the Liberal Party-it has become apparent to me that they are frightened of the Court Government. They see it as irrational, myopic and increasingly as an agent for Japan. They realise that the right honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) in his capacity as Federal Minister for Trade and Resources could help them but they recognise that he is quite impotent and will do nothing.

I refer to a speech made in this debate by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume). On 3 March he said that he would like to see a tax, a surcharge, put on the export of all minerals. I think his contribution was significant. It illustrates just how few members of the Government understand how the free enterprise system really works. Export levies put an arbitrary term on the economic life of a mine, as a resource rent tax does not. Obviously, if a company is in the pursuit of a market share and selling below the opportunity price it is cheating the Australian people: In that case, an export levy is just common sense. For the honourable member to suggest that a levy or export taxes be applied to iron ore which is operating in an intensely competitive world market in an endeavour to promote the sale of fines or pellets ignores the simple facts of the free market system.

Pelletisation became quite uneconomic when this Liberal-National Country Party Government introduced its outrageous and regressive oil tax. With Arab-equivalent prices, every pelletisation plant in Australia was doomed. On top of that, the predominant world demand is for the lump form. Once any economic advantage was gone, so was the market for pellets and no amount of export levy could ever recover that. I point out to honourable members opposite that that is how the free enterprise market system works in this case. I admit that it is a very basic illustration, but it is obvious that very few of them understand even the basics. I doubt very much whether any of them would survive in a truly competitive free market system. But, of course, they would not have to: They would raise for themselves a cosy cartel, quota, captive market or levy. All of them are affected by the Murdoch syndrome.

Let us consider the Federal record. In the last general election, when the Fraser Government was looking down the barrel of defeat, no fewer than 61 promises, either dishonestly costed or not costed at all, were made. Perhaps the daddy of them all was the promise to build a railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin. In terms of cost-benefit analysis, that is the height of absurdity. It represents a craven government prepared to spend half a billion dollars of the taxpayers money to shore up its electoral chances. In terms of defence, a line running from east to west from Mt Isa to Port Hedland makes much more sense. On the basis of return on capital, that line at least would have a chance. It would open up a deep water port in the Pilbara for west Queensland coal, bringing cheaper power to the Pilbara and expanding the market for coal. It might even do something to establish secondary industries in that part of the world.

I refer now to the current taxation situation. My constituents are justly concerned with the Government's policy in that field. How could one not be concerned about the erratic course followed by our Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his Treasurer (Mr Howard), the 'Two Ronnies' of the financial world? The Australian Taxation Office is in a state of turmoil. It has trouble keeping up with the almost weekly changes in policy. If the Prime Minister is not dishonouring a promise on, say, personal income tax indexation, he is out pork-barrelling some Pitt Street farmers with another tax concession. My constituents are very concerned about the Government's attitude, especially its attitude towards the taxation of subsidised rentals. The Government's decision last year to enforce a tax on housing rental subsidies in isolated areas was ill-conceived. Such subsidies are a just compensation for the hardship and isolation endured by my constituents. Any tax on those subsidies would be inflationary. Mining companies would have to increase wages, which in turn would result in higher prices for everyone, including government employees and private contractors who would not receive any wage compensation.

A government policy of taxing housing subsidies would adversely affect rural industries in which low rents or free rents have been traditional. The Government backed down on that issue just prior to the last Federal election. However, it has not entirely rejected the option of a housing subsidy tax. I take this opportunity to warn the Government that I entirely reject the application of section 26E of the Income Tax Assessment Act in such a manner and let it know that Kalgoorlie will fight on the issue. That ought to frighten the Government!

Income tax zone allowances or remote area compensatory benefits, as they are more aptly termed, are of vital concern to my constituents. As honourable members may be aware, the whole of taxation Zone A in Western Australia falls within my electorate, as does 90 per cent of Zone B. The electors of Kalgoorlie are not impressed with the Liberal's performance in this field. Liberal government's have a long history of ignoring the needs of people in remote areas. It was a Labor government in 1945 that amended the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide tax concessions for people who reside in remote and largely undeveloped areas. In introducing the relevant legislation the then Treasurer, Ben Chifley, stated:
Some measure of tax relief should be granted, not only to employees but to all taxpayers who live in remote parts of the Commonwealth.

He recognised that there was a real need to compensate for uncongenial conditions, isolation and high costs of living. In 1975 the Whitlam Labor Government moved to increase substantially the value of the zone allowance by making it a tax rebate-that is, a direct refund of the specified amount rather than a deduction from taxable income. The Liberal Party has done nothing since the inception of those allowances to increase appreciably their level or ease the conditions of eligibility. The Government's big effort has been to institute an inquiry which has just received public submissions on the state of the remote area benefits. That is indeed a modest effort from a party that has been in power for 29 of the past 31 years, or since the Chifley Government which introduced zone allowances passed into history. For five years the present Government sat on the Asprey recommendation that a separate inquiry should be instituted to look into remote area zone allowances. If it took the Government five years to institute an inquiry, how much longer will it take it to act? I call on the Government to act and to act now. I call on the Government to increase the level of the benefits, to change the form of the benefits and to ease the conditions relating to eligibility.

I shall elaborate on those proposals. The present level of benefit is totally inadequate. Currently the taxation zone rebate is $216 plus 25 per cent of the sum of the dependant's rebate to which the taxpayer is entitled. In Zone B the amount is $36 plus 4 per cent of the sum of the rebate for each dependent child. Therefore, in Zone A a taxpayer with a spouse and two children gets a rebate of $574.50, whereas in Zone B a taxpayer in similar circumstances receives a rebate of $93.36. Expressed another way, the base component for a taxpayer without dependants is 59c a day in Zone A and less than 10c a day in Zone B. That is very small compensation indeed for the disabilities people suffer in those zones.

I do not think I need to recount in detail why the level of monetary compensation is totally inadequate as both the State parliamentary Labor Party and the Wickham Branch of the Australian Labor Party have done this extensively in their submissions to the current inquiry. I simply propose that the zone allowance should be increased in 1981-82 to an amount of no less than $560 and that an amount equal to 75 per cent of the sum of the rebate to which the taxpayer is entitled for dependants should be paid to remote area residents. I propose further that the zone allowance be in- dexed annually in line with movements in the consumer price index for the ensuing year and that regular reviews be conducted to ascertain the appropriateness of the base component of the allowance.

Since the introduction by a Labor government of a concession for people living in remote areas the benefit has taken many forms. I now propose that the remote area compensation benefit should be a direct cash payment made quarterly to the residents. That would ensure that people living on pensions and people whose incomes fall below the taxable limit-that is, the most needy members of the community-would not forgo their concessions. That might in turn mean that the new form of benefit is more appropriately administered by a government department other than the Taxation Office. I consider that such a new form of benefit not only would compensate all residents for the first time but also would do more to encourage decentralisation in remote areas.

Currently taxpayers who live in Zone A-that is, all of Western Australia above the 26th parallel-receive one benefit while people who live in Zone B receive another benefit. When the zone allowance was introduced the zone boundaries were delineated in terms of the degree of severity of the disability. The present value of allowances suggests that the degree of disability associated with Zone A is six times as great as that associated with Zone B. Clearly, that is not true. In my electorate one has only to compare Carnarvon with, say, Wiluna or Roebourne with Rawlinna to see that that is not so. I propose that Zone A and Zone B should be amalgamated to form a new Zone A. In the final analysis, the degree of severity of the two zones overlaps and is marginal when compared with the quality of life in Perth or similar developed areas. The alternative is a multi-zone system, which I once favoured. However, it would be extremely complex and costly and an administrative nightmare.

At the moment eligibility to receive the zone allowance is based on length of residence; that is, a person who has been a resident of a zone for at least six months of the financial year is eligible. That discriminates greatly against those people who reside in the area for most of the year but not for six months in any one financial year. I have read the submission to the inquiry from the Western Australian school teachers and I entirely sympathise with their case. I propose that the benefits should be calculated on a quarterly basis. Anyone who is resident for more than two months in any one quarter should be paid for that quarter. I think this would provide a much more equitable system.

In the time I have left, I indicate that I intend to adopt a bipartisan approach in this Parliament. I am very happy to give the Government the benefit of any expertise I hold on subjects on which it obviously is lacking. If Government members care to call on me at any time they will find me very willing, in any circumstances, to give them any help I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jarman Mr A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment His Excellency, the Governor-General on his address to this nation in declaring open the Thirty-Second Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. I was particularly impressed by his remarks that discussion of the economy and economic policy has become so abstract, so specialised, so dominated by statistics and rarefied concepts that the connection between it and the lives of ordinary people is in danger of being obscured if not lost sight of all together. I particularly commend the Young Liberal Movement in Victoria for its policy statement that it puts people first.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak tonight on behalf of the people of Victoria who for many years seem to have been unjustly subsidising other States of Australia. I believe that the Federal Government, if it fails to recognise the mood of the Victorian people in regard to this matter, can do so only at its peril. This was shown by the fact that although the Government polled well in every other State it lost seven seats in Victoria at the last election. Victorians are sick and tired of being the aunt sally of other States of Australia. In the next few months a new Federal-State agreement on tax sharing must be worked out. In a Federation such as exists in Australia income produced by one State should be used to assist the development of the less affluent States. No one would argue with that. However, any tax sharing must be based on a formula which is just and fair to all concerned and our present formula has long been due for a change to a more equitable system.

In 1942 the Commonwealth Government took over responsibility for income tax collections from State governments. A high uniform national tax was introduced at that time to fight the war in which Australia was engaged and also to control the economy in the wartime situation in which Australia found itself. The amount of tax which the Commonealth Government returned to the States was determined by the average amount the States had collected in the previous two years. At that time the minority Country Party Government of Premier Dunstan was in power in Victoria. It believed in minimum taxation but, by pursuing this policy, it allowed such essential services as education, hospitals, et cetera, to run down. The Victorian Government had a low level of expenditure during those years. Consequently, Victorian taxpayers were, and still are, being penalised because of the policies of that retrograde government. As a result Victoria contributes 29 per cent of the total income tax collected by the Australian Government but receives from the Commonwealth only 23 per cent of the tax collected.

The Victorian Government has pointed out on a number of occasions that the present system wrongly assumes that it is more costly to provide government services to low density States such as Queensland and Western Australia than to higher density States such as Victoria or New South Wales. It completely fails to take into account the effects of the enormous economic growth in States such as Western Australia and Queensland due to the vast mineral boom of the past decade in those States. The Bass Strait oil fields lie off the Victorian coast and therefore the State receives only a percentage of oil royalty revenue shared with the Commonwealth. This is not the case for oil, iron, bauxite and other minerals being developed within the boundaries of some of the so-called Cinderella States of Queensland and Western Australia. What the Victorian Government and the Victorian people want is a new formula to be worked out which is in line with the economies of the States at this time and not a formula worked out some 40 years ago. Victorians require the Commonwealth to return to each State an amount equivalent to the percentage collected from that State. The Grants Commission could then make scientifically based recommendations to the Commonwealth for any additional special assistance considered necessary to be allocated to any particular State because of hardship. Regular reviews by the Grants Commission could be undertaken to determine such special assistance.

It is obvious that other States which, for the past 38 years have been heavily subsidised by the Victorian and New South Wales taxpayers and are continuing to be financed by them, will not readily agree to major changes in the present tax sharing formula. Why should they? However, we are not just Victorians, Queenslanders and Western Australians: We are all Australians, and in the interests of justice and fair play the present inequitable system must be changed. It has just got to go. The Victorian Chamber of Manufactures forcibly stated this view recently in its November journal. The Chamber said clearly that the time had come for the resource-rich States to pay their own way. For too long Victoria has been forced to curtail growth and job prospects while Victorian industry and Victorian taxpayers have been forced to pay disproportionately higher taxes to subsidise development in the resource-rich States. Victorians are being squeezed by a discriminatory tax sharing formula which, as I have said, is 40 years antiquated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which State does the Prime Minister come from?

—I have, as the honourable member for Wills has reminded me, a report of a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) which is headed: 'Fraser lashes out at States on spending'. What the Victorian people are asking for, as the honourable member for Wills, as a Victorian, should realise, is not more spending on the States but a fairer cutting up of the cake. I would have thought that as a Victorian member the honourable member for Wills would have supported what I am saying. As I said earlier, Victoria contributes 29 per cent to the Federal income tax pool-I thought the honourable member for Wills would have known this-but receives only 23 per cent in return. In the present financial year Victoria will receive only $348 per taxpayer compared with $355 for New South Wales, $481 for Queensland, $575 for Western Australia, $533 for South Australia, and a massive $710 per head for Tasmania. Tasmanian taxpayers get back almost twice the amount received by Victorian taxpayers for what they put in. Tasmanians have been foolish enough for most of this century to elect inefficient Labor governments, but why should Victorian taxpayers or anyone else be forced to pay for the stupidity of Tasmanian voters in electing Labor governments? Let them live with the people they elect to their own parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that the Premiers of other States laugh all the way to the Federal kitty. It is no wonder that Mr Bjelke-Petersen boasts of the growth of Queensland and of the exodus of Victorians to his northern State. The inequitable distribution means that Victoria loses out in so many ways. Vital funds are not available to the State Government for programs and incentives to stimulate growth and jobs and the State Government is forced to rely more heavily on State taxes, including payroll tax, to fill the gap. The excessive tax burden on Victorians, particularly Victorian industry, constrains growth and further inhibits job creation. Those States benefiting from this outmoded forumla of Federal handouts are able to offer incentives to attract from Victoria the skilled workers essential to long term growth within our State. No wonder Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Sir Charles Court can sell their minerals overseas at a price which many believe is inadequate. It is time these two States learned to stand on their own economic feet.

In Melbourne fewer homes are being built and fewer building lots are being offered for sale than at any time during the last decade. A report in November by the Victorian Planning Department signified more bad news for home builders and land developers in Victoria, already hard hit by that State's building recession. According to the report only about 9,000 new lots came on to the market in 1979. The number of subdivisions in every Melbourne growth corridor except Melton decreased. New home building declined in every growth corridor except the south-east. It is not only in taxation and home building that Victoria is being penalised. Tullamarine Airport which, unlike Mascot, has no curfew is not used efficiently or to its capacity. Figures reveal that almost 15,000 more seats are available each week on flights into Sydney than on flights into Melbourne. This is a severe handicap to the tourist industry and the tourist promotion program in Victoria. The latest Department of Transport figures showed Melbourne had only 85 international services a week compared with 141 for Sydney, yet international flights can fly into Melbourne 24 hours a day, seven days a week, unions and the honourable member for Wills permitting. The position is even worse on direct flights. Sydney has 111 direct flights a week to other countries whilst Melbourne has only 34. The time has come when Victoria can no longer act as Father Christmas to the other States. Victoria may well be the garden State of Australia but no longer is everything in the garden rosy.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Relations with USSR-Radio Station 3CR-Insurance Industry -Investments-South Australia: Representation in Ministry-Domestic Air Fares

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) returned to his favourite occupation of verbally warring with the Soviet Union, and bravely announced that relations with that country would not return to normal. The fact is that Australia cannot afford those relations, particularly as to trade, to return to normal. I wish to record one simple fact. Australia's exports to the Soviet Union have doubled since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. In calendar year 1979, prior to the invasion, exports to the Soviet Union amounted to $506.1m. In calendar year 1980, the 12 months following the Soviet invasion, Australia's exports to the Soviet Union amounted to $998.3m, an increase of 100 per cent. This makes patently clear the double standards of the Prime Minister and of this Government. Young Australian athletes were hounded and branded as traitors, yet all the while Mr Fraser himself was selling wool to the Soviet Union and, as I have pointed out, Australian trade to the Soviet Union has jumped to record heights. This humbug and hypocrisy has been a mark of Liberal-National Country Party governments. Those of us who were here during the Vietnam War can remember the great attacks on Communist China, yet at the very time Australian forces were in Vietnam the Liberal and National Country parties were encouraging trade with Communist China, a country with whom we were in a state of war and a country that they themselves refused to recognise. That shows the humbug and hypocrisy of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, in his moment of glory statement of 19 February 1980, revealed that whilst the Soviet Union was a super power it was an unbalanced one in that it was defective in grain; that it needed access to Western grain. He proclaimed then that that access to Western grain would suffer. His statement was a gigantic fraud. The cold hard fact is that Australian grain sales to the Soviet Union have jumped from $217m in the year before the invasion to $748m in the 12 months following it. Only last week the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) regretfully announced that Australia could not sell more grain because the so-called restraint ceiling of 3.9 million tonnes could not be met due to the fact that the harvest had been affected by drought. An act of God was giving some purport to what the Prime Minister had maintained he would see as Australia's policy. The yawning gap between the words and actions of this Prime Minister, of this Government, deserve the condemnation not only of this House but also of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Radio station 3CR is well known to honourable members from Melbourne. It is generally regarded as a radio station that gives expression to left wing views. Usually the contents of its propaganda segments are too foolish to warrant serious consideration.
—Nonsense.

—The honourable member says 'nonsense', but for anyone who wants to bring himself up to date on the continuing revolution of the Albanian tractor workers or the latest production figures of the Soviet harvest, there it is-3CR, the continuing voice of the revolution.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in at least one field the broadcasts take on a nasty edge, and I refer to the promotion of the pro-Palestinian and anti-Israeli line. Not only are some of such programs anti-Israeli; they are anti-Jewish as well. The thinly veiled anti-semitic tone of these broadcasts has brought into the Australian community a distressing and disturbing racial and religious element from which in the past Australia has mercifully been free. There are several such programs, of which one called Par Avion and another called Palestine Speaks are probably the worst. The following is a short extract from the Palestine Speaks broadcast of 6 October 1980:

Israeli soldiers played a game of cards in which they received one card if they raped one woman, two cards if they raped two, and so on. The winner was the one with the most cards who had raped most women . . . Israeli soldiers killed Jordanian fishermen, tied them up and put a fish in their mouths and threw them into the sea . . . and babies whom the Israelis had buried alive . . .
I quote now another extract, this time from the 3CR program Par Avion of 2 August 1980:
Women members of the Australian delegation-
That is at Copenhagen-
were incredibly upset at the heavy blow which was obviously struck by the Zionist lobby in Australia against progress for women and humanitarian ideals.

That statement must be regarded as particularly insulting to the Jewish community, especially in view of that community's concern for humanitarian ideals in general and those in the Soviet Union in particular. The evil of such statements is that they are an attempt to foment hatred of the Jewish community. That can only be divisive of the Australian people and should be condemned.

Station 3CR has a licence which comes up for renewal later this year. Sectional groups should, of course, have freedom to express their views over the radio and elsewhere, but station 3CR has abused this right and should not be allowed continually to poison the community with this hatred, as it is still doing. The station has had a chance since 1979 to rid itself of this practice and redeem itself but it has failed to do so. Therefore, it should now have its licence revoked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning at Question Time the Treasurer (Mr Howard) claimed that Mr Einfeld, the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, had not indicated the position of his Government on the need for legislation in relation to insurance brokers. This afternoon I received the following telegram from Mr Einfeld:

SPEECH.PARA: I completely support the principles inherent in the report of the Law Reform Commission regarding urgent necessity for legislation to protect customers of insurance brokers . . . it would be in the best interest of everyone if the Commonwealth would introduce such legislation and that if the Commonwealth refused to do so NSW will be forced to do it to protect customers. I have discussed with the Insurance Brokers Association of Australia and the Confederation of Insurance Brokers as well as the Insurance Council of Australia my desire to see insurance brokers clients protected by legislation . . . that Federal legislation would be preferable so that uniformity prevails . . . I hope you can convince the Federal Government to proceed as promised by the Federal Treasurer some two years ago . . . Its failure to take action will inevitably compel the NSW Government to move in this direction . . .

I suggest that this puts beyond question the support of the Government of New South Wales for such legislation. The need for legislation to cover insurance brokers is urgent. The Law Reform Commission reports-I have revised the figures since last night-that some $14m has been written off over the last 10 years, and $7m in the last two years. That is an appalling indictment. I can see that the legislation is not the panacea for all ills. I agree with the Treasurer that it will not solve all the problems. But, what this appalling legacy of broking house liquidations clearly shows is that there are areas where policy holders are entitled to receive legislative protections, and guarantees to this end can be embodied in law as set out in the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. Because brokerage houses handle vast amounts of premium money, their fiduciary responsibilities cannot be left to self-regulation. The $14m loss is more than ample proof that such an approach is an utter disaster.

The honest broker is crying out for legislation that will restore credibility to this very important sector of the insurance industry. Individuals and/or companies that pay premiums to a broker for insurance to cover a particular contingent liability have a right to expect that the coverage they seek is secure. The Treasurer knows only too well, as he indicated today, that most of the $3m lost in the Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd. collapse will be honoured by insurers, but that is not always the case. Certainly thousands of policy holders are forced to pay a second lot of premiums. This was the case in three company collapses in Western Australia. The Treasurer will concede that the disaster would have been worse had it not been for the fact that insurance companies have honoured the contracts where the brokers have failed. At the moment there is now law to compel insurance companies to honour the contracts. I suggest to the Treasurer in all seriousness that, whether it be in the field of insurance brokerage or the corporate sector, laws must be enacted that deny corporate shysters or corporate incompetents the opportunity to float companies, rake off millions of dollars of policy holders' funds and then deliberately strip off the assets and dumping the company into liqidation, leaving a train of heartbreak, sacrifice and enormous financial loss for thousands of ordinary people.

This matter has been canvassed for four years. There is identical legislation in the United Kingdom. It is long overdue here and I ask that legislation be introduced as quickly as possible. We cannot protect those who have suffered already but the insurance legislation is badly in need of overhaul and it must be carried out as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) has reminded me of two things in regard to insurance. The first is that regulation is not necessarily the answer, because in many cases regulation merely extends the problem and, secondly, that in this case the New South Wales Government has taken no action although it has had ample opportunity. I want to talk about investment because I read last week of discussions in this place about the need for having Australians invest more in our own resources. I believe it is just a matter of what we in this country believe in regard to investing more in our own country, and so owning more of our own resources. The Government and Opposition agree that we do not own enough of our own resources and we do not reap enough benefits. It is easy to talk about these things. I thought that perhaps it was appropriate to put down some of the arithmetic. If we are to own more of our own resources-this is putting it very simply-we need to invest more. If we are to invest more we have to save more and if we save more, of course, some of that can be reaped off by the Government in government borrowing through the deficit. But, given that a responsible government is in power and that it tries to keep the deficit as low as possible and also to keep the State deficits as low as possible, most of the savings that we make will go into that investment. Unless we save more we will not invest more; that is for certain.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past three or four years I have found it strange to hear the statisticians and economists lament the fact that our savings ratio has grown. I was not in a position to comment adversely on that theory but it always seemed strange. I think that my ideas have been borne out in that when the savings ratio was growing it was actually a healthy sign and not such a bad sign. People said at the time that when the savings ratio was high it meant consumption must be low and we could not have a consumption-led recovery. When the savings ratio is high there is the other possibility that investment will also be high. At present we are also lamenting that we do not own enough of our own resources. If we are to keep pace with what we believe in-that is, that we want to keep as much of our country within the hands of our own people-we must save more and probably have a low deficit.

On the taxation side, and this is another part of simple arithmetic, we will probably need lower personal taxes, the taxes about which people do not exercise any discretion, and higher indirect taxes, the taxes about which people do exercise discretion. There is always the problem of devising a system under which the mix between those taxes will create problems for people on low incomes. That is exactly the problem to which we would need to address ourselves first. I am not talking about the numbers of and progression in taxes; I am talking about increasing discretion and reducing the lack of discretion that one has with high personal taxes. If there is an increased amount of discretion then there is an increased possibility that the savings ratio will be increased. As I have said, as a matter of simple arithmetic, we will have more scope for owning more of our resources because we will have more to invest. I am talking about arithmetic only, not politics. We are all proud of Australia. On both sides of this House I think we all believe that we ought to collect our own heritage. Now that we are getting out of the woods why do we not fight in this Parliament and in all places to see that our people reap the harvest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words tonight about my home State of South Australia. No doubt those honourable members who have visited South Australia have found it to be a very pleasant place. Adelaide is a very pleasant city. It is a nice, easy place to find one's way around. The political aspects of the State are a little different from what might be happening in some of the other States in Australia where benefits from the so-called resources boom are going to occur. In the period from 1970 to 1979, which was the period of the Dunstan and Corcoran Labor governments, the conservative element in South Australia continually talked down the opportunities that might occur there. They continued to give a jaundiced view of what the future of South Australia may be. In some ways I believe they persuaded people to keep out of South Australia. It has even reached the heights now where in the newsapers we see advertisements by the Avis Rent a Car System which tell people how Avis can help them to enjoy their business stay in Adelaide. It is really not Los Vegas.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us find South Australia a very pleasant place, but the conservatives played a very big role in telling everybody in Australia and elsewhere that South Australia really did not have much going for it. Of course, now they cannot stop it. People have the view that perhaps South Australia is not as well off as some of the other States. To a very large extent it is true. In some of the traditional industries of South Australia, particularly the car industry, which has not experienced a growth in sales, the employment opportunities and the number of employees have dropped rather dramatically in the past two or three years. That is one indicator of how the States may be going. Of course, South Australia has the highest unemployment rate on the mainland. Almost 9 per cent of the total work force in South Australia is registered as unemployed.

The reason I raise these points tonight is to put forward the view that South Australia has some specific problems that ought to be looked at by the Federal Government. One of the reasons that I believe South Australia has not been looked at seriously by the Federal Government is that South Australia is grossly under-represented in the Fraser Ministry. South Australia has one ministerial representative. He is a very junior member of the Liberal Party from South Australia. I refer to Senator Messner. He was not widely known when he was appointed a Minister. I am not critical of his appointment but it does mean that South Australia has only one very junior person in the whole Fraser Ministry. Through the resignation of the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, now Mr Justice Ellicott, there is an opportunity for the appointment of another South Australian. That may cause some difficulty. When one looks at those people who are being suggested in the Press as possible Ministers-people such as 'Curly' Carlton and 'Mumbles' Connolly-it would not hurt if another South Australian were given the opportunity.

I do not expect the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to elevate the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) straight into the Ministry because over the years the honourable member for Boothby had great difficulty in his clash of loyalties. I think the Prime Minister is well aware of what he may have to put up with if he promotes the honourable member for Boothby into the Ministry. He did elevate the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) to the position of a Parliamentary Secretary which gives one the view that perhaps the honourable member for Sturt was in line for a ministerial stake when the opportunity arose. It seems to me far more important at the moment that South Australia be given another voice in the Ministry and that another New South Welshman not be selected. If some of the States are worried about missing out on the benefits of the so-called resources boom, some of the smaller States like Tasmania and South Australia ought to have representation in the Ministry so that they can raise their voices. Tasmania does have that influence. Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria all have representation over and above that given to South Australia. It seems to me that the Prime Minister must have some special reason for excluding South Australian representation if, with the opportunity he has now been given from the Ellicott resignation, he does not appoint another South Australian to the Ministry as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that South Australian members of Parliament will welcome the support given to them by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) as I am sure it will count very heavily with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).
—You are gone. You have no chance now. Mick just sacked you.

—I thank the honourable member for Wills for his support also. I wish to comment on speeches which were made by honourable members on both sides of the House tonight. I refer to the speech made by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Jarman) who is concerned about the situation in Victoria relating to the tax reimbursement formula. I refer also to the speech made by the honourable member for Port Adelaide who is concerned about the industrial and investment situation in South Australia. I relate the comments made by those two honourable members to the remarks made by my colleague, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury), who quite correctly pointed out that, if Australia is to own more of Australia, there has to be a rise in savings and a rise in investment.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to go further to express some concern about the direction of that investment. I think that over the next few years we will have a very good opportunity to ensure that the money that we save is directed towards activities which will create more Australian ownership and more Australian employment. Certain industries in Australia are getting themselves into greater and greater difficulties-some of these are located in South Australia and some in Victoria-because they are unable to face up to the kinds of changes that have to be made so that investments in those industries are more productive. In a gentle fashion, I ask this question: If certain policies which help to direct investment by way of providing protection or providing subsidies are leading to further difficulties in certain industries, is it sensible to add to that protection or to increase the effect of those policies which are creating unemployment problems or depression in certain regional areas? I merely say that that question has to be asked, and asked sincerely. I regret very much--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about removing some of the subsidies?

—I am prepared to look at removing subsidies from all sorts of areas, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I say that over the next couple of years many decisions will be made which will have an effect on the direction of investment. I expressed some concern last year over the fact that people were proudly pointing to an investment in Australia of approximately $35m in the case of one company in the textile industry. If one were advising any set of investors about where to invest $35m to the best effect as far as jobs and future profits are concerned one would hardly direct those people to the Australian textile industry. Yet that $35m was proudly invested by that company. That was a decision taken by the directors of that company, and they will spend a lot of time over the next few years in Canberra rather than in their management offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter to which I wish to draw attention is the forthcoming report by Mr Campbell on the financial system. This report will affect the direction of investment. If Australians are to face up to owning more of their own country, then they have to question whether they should, for example, be putting so much of their discretionary income-I am thinking here perhaps of the better off people who have this discretionary capacity-into adding an extra room to a house or into buying a much more expensive house in an expensive area, and whether that will continue to be possible at effectively subsidised rates of interest when that money might be put into owning more of our natural resources and not having them owned so much by foreign interests. It is very comfortable indeed to sit in a very good residence in a comfortable part of a capital city and to be on a very high income and to deplore the lack of Australian ownership and at the same time to drive in one's Volvo to an even more expensive suburb to look at a house with six bedrooms for a family with three children.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not talking about Port Adelaide?
—I know we are not talking about Port Adelaide.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, much publicity has been given to aspects of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares that have related to Western Australia. This discussion has obscured one of the major weaknesses of the inquiry, a weakness wholly induced by the early closure of its investigation; that is, that of the four main areas of interest to Western Australians only one was dealt with in any detail. These areas were: Cross-subsidisation of jet flights, intrastate air fares in Western Australia, the availability of Qantas Airways Ltd seats for cross-country travel and, finally, the problems that the Western Australian tourist industry suffers because of the international gateway status of some eastern States airports.

SPEECH.PARA: Only one of these matters was dealt with by the inquiry in any detail at all, and that was the one that gained publicity-the question of jet routes cross-subsidisation. This is what the inquiry was compelled to confess of its curtailed investigation. The task of identifying the degree of cross-subsidisation is immensely complicated. In this instance the problem was aggravated by a lamentable lack of studies of price and income elasticities of demand on the various routes and their implications for the management of the national network. Because of the limited time available to it, the inquiry had no option but to accept this important shortcoming, and this, of course, constitutes a qualification to its findings.

The inquiry, of course, revealed a $23m per annum rip-off of the Western Australian traveller. Yet the committee had to hurry its investigation of this matter and was unhappy about the amount of detail it could gather. Earlier this week I spoke on the question of intrastate fares in Western Australia. Here again the inquiry was compelled to say that whilst the matter was in its terms of reference it did not have the time to investigate it. On the vitally important question to Western Australians of the use of Qantas cross country seats which could provide discounts of up to 50 per cent, which has been the subject of persistent representations by the member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) and the fair air fares campaign, the inquiry was reduced to dealing with it in a couple of short paragraphs. While it raised some difficulties with the question, the inquiry stated:
What can be said is that the reduction in costs associated with the introduction of larger aircraft . . . would be significant.

This desirable step would, of course, be precluded by the new agreement. Finally, on the question of points of entry, the Holcroft committee was obliged to concede that here again Western Australia suffered but nothing could be done about it in the time available. This is the report which the Government said would clarify the Western Australian position. This is the report whose early unwilling conclusion Western Australian Liberal members have supported. This is the inquiry that was set up, according to the Government, to enable those of us from Western Australia to have the benefit of its advice before we debated the airlines agreement. I grieve for the members of the inquiry in their embarrassment at their inability to report on these key areas of their reference, and I worry about Western Australian air travellers who have been denied valuable evidence to promote the case they have established prima facie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m. the debate is interrupted.
—I require the debate to be extended.
—The Minister requires the debate to be extended. The debate may continue until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reply very briefly to the contribution of the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) whose interest in insurance matters is respected and appreciated on both sides of the House. I simply wish to make it quite plain that the concern that I expressed earlier today about the New South Wales Government was that the New South Wales Government had not responded to a request made by the Federal Government in accordance with the arrangements worked out between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Premier of New South Wales for a view on the report of the Law Reform Commission insofar as that report related to insurance brokers. It may well be that Mr Einfeld believes in legislation of a particular kind. I am sure he does; he has told me that on earlier occasions. I am quite sure that he would not personally misrepresent the situation. The Government naturally wants a response from the New South Wales Government, and his view may or may not necessarily carry the day. I am sure that the honourable member for Hawker appreciates that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government intends when it has received all the responses to the Law Reform Commission report to analyse them promptly. We received responses from the principal industry bodies only yesterday. We will then give early consideration to the matter. That is the advice I have received. I note the crease in the brow of the honourable member for Hawker, but I can assure him that that is the information I have been given. It is our intention to give very prompt consideration to the issue. I do not believe I have as high a threshold of expectation about what regulation can do in this area as the honourable member for Hawker has. I share the view of my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) that simply adding to the bulk of regulation does not necessarily produce a more efficient, or indeed, a more honest industry. I suggest, with respect, that it puts into context some of the remarks made by other speakers tonight to the effect that another sector of the economy, namely, the money market, has benefited in recent months from a degree of deregulation that was undertaken by the Government early in December. I think anybody who understands the operation of the Australian financial system would recognise that that decision has made a significant contribution towards a more realistic and more stable situation in the money market.

So the balance is by no means in favour of regulation. In my view the onus is always on those who assert that there should be more regulation, as the insurance brokers do, to establish the public benefit. It is easy for an industry to argue for more regulation. It is often an example of that truism in politics that people are in favour of things in general but are opposed to them in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for their own.

—The universal view expressed to me by members of the Australian business community is that there should be less government intervention except, as my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar reminds me, insofar as it often relates to their own particular industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it plain to the honourable member for Hawker in recognition of his intelligent contribution to debate in this Parliament on the insurance industry that we will reach a conclusion as speedily as possible. The matter has been under consideration for a while. He is correct in saying that. We did retreat from the more extensive regulation that was first mooted in 1976 but for good and proper reasons. There has been a further extension of time, waiting for the Law Reform Commission report. I think the matter ought to be brought to a speedy conclusion, but I would again counsel him not to expect my views about the degree of regulation that is required to correspond with his.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate having concluded, the House stands adjourned until 2.15 p.m. on Tuesday, 10 March.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government decided to dispose of land formerly held by the Cities Commission in 1975 for the Holsworthy Investigatory Project for the planning, development and servicing of 500 residential blocks to demonstrate new social and physical planning and development arrangements, if so, (a) what arrangements have been made and (b) when is disposal to be effected; if not, what use is proposed for the land.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes.

It was agreed that the matter would be pursued between the two Governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he indicate, in a letter dated 5 September 1979, to the General Secretary of the Australian Council of National Trusts, that consultations with the Queensland Government were proceeding.
(2) Have these discussions been concluded; if so, why is there still a delay in nominating the Great Barrier Reef for inclusion on the World Heritage List.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is available to the Commonwealth to obtain the return to Australia of an historic Supermarine Spitfire Mk VIII, serial No. MV 154, which has allegedly been exported from Australia without authority.
(2) Has action been taken or is it proposed to be taken against the alleged exporters, if so, what.

(3) Has he determined that the situation in the United Kingdom concerning the import of historic aircraft to the United Kingdom from Australia is in breach of the Australian Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question of commencing legal proceedings in the United Kingdom for the return of the aircraft to Australia has been under consideration but serious legal difficulties are involved.
(2) Informations have been exhibited in the Court of Petty Sessions, Sydney, for the recovery of pecuniary penalties against those involved in the alleged illegal exportation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government accept the conclusions of the National Energy Advisory Committee in its 9th report which states that a policy of strategic stockpiling over and above the industry's normal commercial stocks, is warranted to provide a greater degree of insurance against supply interruptions and further that Government initiatives to ensure such stockholding either by direct action or indirectly through arrangements for meeting the costs of stockpiling, are essential.
(2) Does the Government also accept recommendations (g) and (h) of this report.
(3) If so, what action will the Government take and when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3). In his statement to the Parliament on energy policy and related resource development on 26 August 1980, the Prime Minister said that the Government had been concerned to provide greater security of supply of petroleum products to Australian consumers. One of the elements of supply security is the holding of adequate stocks. The Prime Minister explained that the Government saw as a prudent objective the holding of stocks equivalent to about 75 days of total consumption of crude oil and petroleum products. He indicated that discussions were under way with the oil industry.
The discussions with the industry are continuing with a view to identifying effective and equitable arrangements for achievement of the stock holding objective.

The recommendations of the National Energy Advisory Committee in its 9th Report are generally compatible with the Government's views, and will be taken into account when final decisions are being made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Australian Electoral Office finalise results for the 5 Senate seats at the 1980 election in Queensland.
(2) When will details of Senate voting results for each Queensland electoral division be published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The position in relation to the finalisation of the 18 October 1980 Senate election in Queensland was as follows:
(a) James Bernard Keeffe, Florence Isabel Bjelke-Petersen and Neville Thomas Bonner were elected on 3 November 1980;
(b) Gerry Norman Jones was elected on 5 November 1980;
(c) Michael John Macklin was elected on 11 November 1980;
(d) the Poll was declared at 11.00 a.m. on 18 November 1980;
(e) the Writ was returned to the Governor of Queensland on 18 November 1980.

(2) Details of Senate voting results for each Queensland electoral division were published under the title The Senate Election 18 October 1980-Result of Count of First Preference Votes by the Australian Electoral Office in February 1981. Copies of the publication can be purchased from Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops for $7.40 each. Copies are also available in the Parliamentary Library.
